One: A Transgender Woman’s Operatic Path to Self-Acceptance","url":"http://www.out.com/entertainment/music/2014/09/11/one-transgender-woman-chamber-opera","link_image":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbvhz0UnjU1qj4zn5_og.png","description":"Kelly Markgraf & Sasha Cooke share the role of the transgender protagonist in ‘As One’ | Photo by Lynn Lane Often, as queer folks, our stories are told as reactions to those around us. \nComing out tales generally revolve around how that act is received by ________ [Fill in the blank: friends, family, religion, community, etc.] and the suspense is whether they will accept us. We’re just American Gladiators navigating an obstacle course of bigotry, bullying and rejection. In a theatrical or literary context, this makes some sense: Coming out provides conflict; it makes good drama.\nBut the brilliance of As One, the new chamber opera that had its world premiere this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is that the drama is (mostly) internal. With only one character, Hannah, that choice allows for a complex and nuanced portrayal of the coming out experience on stage. There are no “there’s something I have to tell you” scenes, no dramatization of strained relationships. Hannah doesn’t have to justify her identity to the outside world. Instead, drama is wrung from the obstacle course within, where she must scale mountains of confusion, transverse gulfs of isolation and dodge bullets of self-doubt.\nThe story of Hannah is inspired in part by the story of Kimberly Reed, a filmmaker and Out100 honoree, whose 2008 documPresented by American Opera Projects. Photo by Ken Howardentary Prodigal Sons explored her transition from male to female and the strained relationship with her adopted brother. Reed is a co-librettist here, sharing the writing credit with Mark Campbell. The simplicity of their language gives the opera a stream-of-consciousness ease and accessibility; they prefer small, sometimes humorous, personal observations to the sweeping pronouncements often favored by opera Like, whether it’s about size, shape, muscle tone, what you’ve got in your chest area, what you’ve got in the junk department, or anything else I haven’t mentioned as of yet. It’s disgusting that people are shamed so much for their bodies that it’s hard for some people to just walk outside. Some people develop eating disorders, others get surgical enhancements, others have reconstructive surgery, and so many other things, all because of this fucked up oppressive institution of body image that the world has created. It’s absolutely ridiculous that people will literally broke themselves or risk going to jail for insurance fraud just so we can feel comfortable in our own bodies. Meanwhile, other people will literally die by their own hands because they just couldn’t get to a place they felt comfortable with their own bodies- and I mean that not only because of suicides, but also because folks with eating disorders oftentimes become very ill, and can actually die because of this.\n\nFact is, even the people who aren’t put in situations as extreme as these (or other extreme situations I didn’t mention) are still affected by this. The vast majority of our society has fallen prey to the camps this wretched power structure has set up in their own minds, and every person in our society has fallen prey to the outward workings of said power structure. This shit is literally everywhere, poisoning all of us.\n\nThe worst part is, much as we may fight it, we’re still nowhere close to stopping it, and that’s scary as all hell.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"mila-the-benevolent","id":97542670645,"post_url":"http://mila-the-benevolent.tumblr.com/post/97542670645/its-almost-here","slug":"its-almost-here","type":"text","date":"2014-09-15 04:43:23 GMT","timestamp":1410756203,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"PQrx43KP","tags":["birthday","to me this is momentous","mtf","trans","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZPusMr1Qr-mar","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"title":"It's almost here.","body":"I need a crown and a scepter. It worries me because I value control and with hrt I have to trust. I have to place my trust in a second puberty when the first was for all purposes disfiguring. I would hope that the second would be relieving and rid me of my dysphoria or at least some of it. But I don’t know. Will I see the dramatic results that some of my trans sisters have seen? I don’t know. Will it help the world see me as the woman I am or will it leave me in some middle state? I don’t know. Will it be able to do enough to “fix” the damage that testosterone has done? I don’t know. I hate the fact that all the hrt guides and knowledge bases have told me everything that wont change and all the rest is “ymmv” aka good luck. I get why that is necessary but still it doesn’t help a mind that worries. Also the guides and advice and knowledge is all over the place. No two sources agree on everything. \n\nAlso I have been told 1000 times that I shouldn’t care if I pass or not, but I do. I am not hoping to be a super model. Hell I don’t even care if I am “attractive.” I just hope hrt lets me live the rest of my life as an ordinary woman. I only care that I can be treated like a woman and more over a person. I just want to be another face in the crowd. Another woman on her way to work or out for a stroll. I am scared that I wont pass and will be forever treated as a monster or something to be mocked, ridiculed and disgusted of.\n\nBut what scares me the most is that I am going through with it. Because it feels like my only option. I have wanted this for as long as I knew it was a thing. Since I was in 8th grade and I was holding that birth control pill and I knew it had hormones in it and all I could think was maybe it would make me a girl. I knew then. I knew before then. I knew after then. I know now. I just hope I’m not too late. I know its never too late to live an honest life but I just hope I can right this ship and still have a life. I have to trust in the hrt. I have to trust in people. I have to trust in my family. And I am going to have to trust myself. I’m going to have to trust. A lot. And that is scary to 03:25:00 GMT","timestamp":1410751500,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"1klFwc2V","tags":["transgender","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZEgH9y1QrewpW","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"","body":"I’ve always felt connected to the transgender community because I grew up in a small, conservative, southern town where it was a constant struggle to feel comfortable in my own skin.\n\nOkay so I am hate-reading this author’s interviews and here’s a quote. It’s not the only place she’s said this, it’s come up in multiple interviews.\n\nLook. Let me preface with your experience is not my experience. That said:\n\nI grew up in the South. Plenty conservative, considering my high school principal resigned over us trying to start a GSA.\n\nFeeling comfortable in one’s skin? While many people want to fold in the T with the LGB, and some experiences are similar - gender identity is not sexual orientation.\n\nTrying not to get caught looking in the locker room, wondering why you get that feeling in your stomach when your best friend’s hand presses on your shoulder - not similar at all to being called the wrong name, being forced into the wrong bathroom, being surrounded by an entire world of people who don’t understand you.\n\nAt least there’s a word for girl who likes girls, even if it’s whispered, even if it’s a slur and written on the bathroom stalls. That is at least a word you can put into Google or look up in the dictionary; a place to start. In the small town, conservative South, there’s no word for “when puberty feels wrong” and “why don’t i look like the other gender no matter how hard i wish at night.”\n\nI really cannot believe the gall of this author to say she empathizes with the trans community, that the discrimination we face keeps her up at night in anger, and that’s her motivation to write this book. Wow, must be nice to have such mental fortitude to get to anger - because you’re not in fear, or sorrow, or anger from being helpless because you’re held back by a system designed to work against you.\n\nForget all that - you’re profiting off the backs of the very community you sought advice from for this goddamn book, and then silenced. Maybe giving a portion of the proceeds to the local LGBT youth charity was guilt, but I doubt it. this story isn’t really new or recent, but I feel like it needed to be told.\n\n  Last year, I came out as transgender to my parents (female to male)…I was extremely nervous, scared terrified. I knew for a fact that they wouldn’t kick me out or disown me, but I didn’t know exactly how they would react. I was expecting them to question me or try to change me etc. But instead this is how the conversation went:\n\nMe: *big long speech about gender vs. sex…you don’t have to like it, you just have to love me….i can’t change who i am….I’m still the same me… please love me etc….*\nMom: Okay, cool….and what would our new son like for supper….I was thinking tacos…that cool with you?\nMe: O___o *speechless*\nMom: The way I look at it….When I was pregnant with you, I would have been happy if you had been a boy or a girl….All I wanted was a healthy, happy baby to love….Why should that be different 16 years later?\n\n  Moral of the story: i have the best mom in the world Yes, some parents are simple-minded, but not all of them. Be who want to be; be who you are. If they don’t “love” you after you actually start being you, then there’s an extra bedroom at my place for you to crash 01:57:23 GMT","timestamp":1410746243,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"R7SgELhX","tags":["recovery","trans","gender queer","ftm","me","ed recovery","health"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnAEXq1QrCLdk","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"text":"Dear Sarah,\n\nI’m sorry that I hurt you. I know that to you passing privilege means scars and back aches from poorly-made binders worn in the hot summer heat, blood blisters and pulled muscles from running too much on the unforgiving asphalt. I know you didn’t understand why I didn’t feed you when all you were trying to do was keep me alive, I know that after twenty-one years I should have learned your language by now. We never really harmonized, I guess I tend to forget that you feel my pain, too. \n\nDear Sarah,\n\nI’m trying to forgive you for being the daughter my parents always wanted. I’m learning that taking care of myself means taking care of you, too. They told me that I’m supposed to look a certain way to be trans, they told me men weren’t supposed to have curves, but after years of trying to starve my jawline out of our face in the hopes that maybe you would disappear, I’ve learned that just because you are gentle does not mean you are weak. I’m sorry I let them convince me that you were the one with the problem. 01:07:00 GMT","timestamp":1410743220,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Odczfxxq","tags":["trigger warning dysphoria","ftm","trans","gender","sexuality","personal","me","anon","truths"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZhkQXw1QqyRqD","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":20,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"I'm sorry, but how would you ever expect a straight girl to date you?","answer":"Well first I’d ask on her on a date silly.\n\nHowever, that isn’t the question you are asking.\n\nThe simple answer is I’d treat her well and like a lady and all I would ask in return is she respects who I am, and that is plainly a man. \n\nThe compound answer of “but your body is abcd.. and she wants efgh” is simple to me too. I am a work in progress, and so is everyone else. If a girl only dates a guy because she absolutely needs “real flesh made at birth penis” then I suppose she would not date me. However, dating someone is about so much more than one anatomical part. It’s about holding hands while you watch tv, wrapping your arms around someone, feeling each others heart race when you see one and other, kissing, etc. Those crucial relationship peices are not based in gender. \n\nI am a man, no more or less then anyone else. But i am honest about my past always. But frankly not part of dating me is like dating a girl- I would know, I date them! And if someone can’t accept my past then that has nothing to do with orientation but sexual preference and that is just a whole different subject. \n\nSo yeah, a straight girl could date me and they already have before. birthday. I was born on Sept 15th, 1990.\n\nOn Sept 25th, it’ll be one full year on hormone replacement therapy.\n\nI always get sappy around my birthday. I always think “It’s that one day where I’m celebrated! Me! Woo!” And then always get… disappointed I guess you could say. A year ago, I was a wreck. I was dirt broke, couldn’t afford heat in my house, nowhere to live, taking handouts from friends, my mom had just passed away from cancer, and I was just struggling to get through day to day. Sitting here today, I’m a year on hormones, Passing everyday, my surgery appointments for SRS are all scheduled practically for next year, I’m in university, walked away from //another// car accident that should’ve killed me, and I’m sitting here with basically no worries. Everything that can be going right, practically is. \n\nIt’s my birthday. So why do I feel like shit? Like I’m alone? Like I’m not important in any of my friends lives? That even though I’m finally achieving success and proud of myself for once, that it still doesn’t matter? I’m happy with so much in my life, and figured that once I had myself figured out, then I could meet people, become friends with people, develop relationships with people and just… thrive. University set my hopes so high, that maybe I’d find like-minded people here. So far… Nope. I’ve been nothing but that “One trans person in history class that contributes a lot” \n\nThe simple answer is I’m fucking lonely. I realize this. I //know// this. I have so many awesome friends that are the best people in the world, but I dont feel important enough to them. I have two friends locally that I haven’t spoken to face to face in months. Everyone else is online. It’s been almost a year and a half since I’ve had anything resembling a relationship, but because of my transition, it dosen’t exactly put me in a very sought for spot in society. I haven’t had anyone I could call a “perspective partner” in forever.\n\nI’m unhappy, but I know //why// and I know what I //need// But I cant fucking get it. IT","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"redheadtalkinginallcaps","id":97520556196,"post_url":"http://redheadtalkinginallcaps.tumblr.com/post/97520556196/so-i-wanted-to-re-blog-this-photo-again-after","slug":"so-i-wanted-to-re-blog-this-photo-again-after","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-15 00:09:00 GMT","timestamp":1410739740,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"0zF4p0HH","tags":["homophobia","gay","lesbian","bi","trans","intersex","homophobic","nazi","the more you know","facts","morgan freeman","love","history","interesting facts","gendered worlds"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZPSRYx1QqhPYa","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"caption":"So I wanted to re-blog this photo again after reading the chapter on sexuality in Gendered Worlds. The word “homophobia” was coined in 1972, when George Weinberg was trying to figure out what had happened during the nazi regime. A man (if you can call him that) named Heinrich Himmler hated gay men and had over 100 thousand gay men arrested, half of which were imprisoned with many going to concentration camps. Gay men and suspected gay men even had to wear special arm bands with a pink triangle on it. It is believed Himmler hated gay men because he thought they were weak and “like women” and would ruin the “Aryan” race. So Weinberg used the term “homophobia” to describe this and described it as being an actual fear of being “gay” by the very fact that you associated with gay men, “fear of contagion”, that maybe you could “catch” the gay. Basically, it’s more a fear that your masculinity would be questioned, rather than a legitimate fear of actual gay men individually. Anyway, it’s now (well, and then obviously but they didn’t use the term as loosely as we do now) used as a justification of acting like a dickhead and used to explain why someone would commit a hate crime. It’s not an excuse and I’m just sharing this because I think the origins of where these words and expressions we use today came from are fascinating. But regardless and in conclusion, this quote still holds true, you are a complete asshole if you think your masculinity, or femininity, would be in question if you just let people of another sexuality than you just live their life the way they see fit.","image_permalink":"http://redheadtalkinginallcaps.tumblr.com/image/97520556196","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":500,"height":750,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":600,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":375,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":150,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":500,"height":750,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/30c0041bd3bbfc3301a48e5373427962/tumblr_nbx1s55fAs1qjad5so1_500.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"vanquishedvaliant","id":97520417184,"post_url":"http://vanquishedvaliant.tumblr.com/post/97520417184/i-had-someone-come-and-tell-me-today-that-id","slug":"i-had-someone-come-and-tell-me-today-that-id","type":"text","date":"2014-09-15 00:07:52 GMT","timestamp":1410739672,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"o6d651h3","tags":["Kaptains Log","trans","trans*","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZZFZzw1QqgtcW","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"","body":"I had someone come and tell me today that I’d inspired them and helped them realize that they were trans. gender binary.\n\nfirst of all: the idea of being trans. i have been told several times that it’s not ‘male trapped in a woman’s’ body and vice versa. no one has really… explained it to me. i’d like trans men are kind of terrible to trans women. like, how are they being mean? why are they being mean? shouldn’t they, like… find solidarity in each other? this goes for other person who are outside the gender binary: why are people being such dicks to you?\n\ni, on no way, want to offend any person with what i’m saying. i think it’s my responsibility to know these things so i can educate myself and reevaluate how i think, and also help other people understand things.\n\nif you have knowledge of these things, please, pop by my ask. i would appreciate it so out with txt in my dream:","body":"MoM: Since you’ve been with him for 5 years I guess you aren’t a lesbian after all. \n\nMe: Mom I’ve never been a lesbian. I’m bi.\n\nMoM: But your with a guy. So your straight.\n\nMe: Mom If that’s your logic, technically I’m gay. \n\nMoM: How are you a lesbian if your with a man.\n\nMe: I’m a man. I’m with a man. I’m queer as they come. Promise.\n\nMoM: what do you mean your a man, I changed your diapers.\n\nMe: and you saw a vagina right? That’s genitalia mom. That does NOT define who I have to be. Just because I was born with female characteristics, Doesn’t mean mentally I am not a man. Mentally I battle this everyday. Mentally I’m still bi. Mentally I am myself and no one see it. Mentally I’m free. Physically? people see what they want to and say what they want never considering the possibility that maybe their minds are too closed to see the reality, and maybe I’m just a big gray blob on a black and white canvas. Physically, is all people acknowledge because in reality everyone judges on appearances and no one takes the time to look at what’s going on with someone mentally. I don’t cut my hair short because I’m “butch” so please stop saying that. When I wear guy clothes, its not because I’m too lazy to get prettied up. I DONT WANT TO. THATS NOT ME. Stop asking why I’m wearing my partners clothes. THEY ARE MINE. I bought them for me. These boxers are mine. It’s not that I am conforming into what “men have to wear” But because I am comfortable in these clothes. And that doesn’t mean I am a tomboy. I am not a girl who likes to do “boy” things. I’m a guy just doing what I like, and avoiding what I don’t. I’m just another person in this world who is misunderstood. I’m just one more person in this world searching for answers and discovering myself. And no mom, that doesn’t mean I am confused or mistaken, I could be, but in full honesty I doubt I am. I have found solace In discovering things about myself and coming to an understanding about all this fucked up shit Ive been going through, that I should have never had to but I did. I’ve come to accept the things I cannot change. That although it goes out of what society expects people to be or become, THIS IS WHO I AM. I do not put blame on anyone, because it is not a fault. It is my strength. Mentally mom, I am a man. I always have been even if you never saw it, or even if you don’t believe it now. Physically I am trapped in my own body. I may never fully escape this cage. I only hope you try to help me unlock all the padlocks and chains imprisoning me. your son. I only hope that one day you can open your mind and accept it.\n\nI wrote this all down as soon as I woke up a few nights ago when I stayed at my parents house. One day I hope to have this conversation with my Mom and Dad. one day.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ryleymichael1993","id":97512466395,"post_url":"http://ryleymichael1993.tumblr.com/post/97512466395/i-was-just-thinking-i-think-im-going-to-look","slug":"i-was-just-thinking-i-think-im-going-to-look","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 22:23:39 GMT","timestamp":1410733419,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"0coyd62k","tags":["transgender","trans","ftm","female to male","testosterone","t","hormones","hrt"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z1B00o1QqCYVR","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"I was just thinking…\n\nI think I’m going to look pretty attractive when I start testosterone and see all the changes in me.","can_reply":false}]

II","ISO":160,"Aperture":"f/2","Exposure":"1/100th","FocalLength":"85mm"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"tharook","id":97510702617,"post_url":"http://tharook.tumblr.com/post/97510702617/im-attracted-to-trans-women","slug":"im-attracted-to-trans-women","type":"link","date":"2014-09-14 22:01:30 GMT","timestamp":1410732090,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"M406ElJx","tags":["transphobia","cissexism","transmisogyny","trans","allies","ugh"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZaSMJy1Qq5puP","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"title":"I’m attracted to trans women","url":"http://www.salon.com/2013/10/22/im_attracted_to_trans_women/","link_image":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbwvuimP6k1qc0hzj_og.jpg","description":"After years of confusion and shame, I’m ready to stop hiding the truth about my desires — and I’m not alone\nWhat am I supposed to think about this person? Am I supposed to give him a cookie.\n\nI’m glad he acknowledges that it’s harder to trans women than it is for “trans-attracted” men, but seriously, how can I respect that as a sexual orientation? I mean\n\nI came across two terms that described what I was feeling. Trans-attraction and trans-orientation. Neither one is official or common, but their use is growing due to the increasing demand for a way to categorize people who are attracted to transgender people.\n\nhow\n\nI don’t always describe myself as trans-attracted, but the label helped me feel like I had a place in the queer community and it helps others understand my sexuality.\n\ncan I\n\nSo why bother coming out? I could easily hide this, since I am attracted to cisgender women, too.\n\nrespect this?\n\nI mean, I’m glad he acknowledges that society’s messed up in this regard, but I absolutely cannot respect “trans-attracted” as a trait, let alone as a sexual orientation. That he feels part of the queer community simply for not being incapable of attraction to trans people makes me feel sick. How can I feel respected by this, when we’re still being othered?\n\nPlacing “trans-attraction” as a trait that needs affirming only serves to reinforce cis-normativity. It holds exclusive attraction to cis people as the norm, not addressing it for what it is—transphobia. Don’t “come out” as not being transphobic, challenge instead those who are! \n\nThere’s already a far better term than “trans-attracted”: straight but not transphobic. Though I’d be careful that you’re not still fetishising through trans phases? I don't want to be like this for the rest of my life","answer":"Being trans is super amazing\n\nI don’t think people go through trans “phases”. Like even if you only ID as trans for a little while that stuff sticks with you. Like you can be a communist for a while but that will still shape how you view things for the rest of your life so it’s not just like a ‘I used to be this thing but that’s 100% over now’.\n\nPhases are what parents say you go through when they don’t like what you’re doing. We’re not moons.\n\nSo no, you don’t go through trans phases, though you can be trans for a while and realize it’s not you. But if you’re like ‘I’m hella trans and I hate it but I’m still hella trans’ it is not likely to stop. A “trans phase” doesn’t really exist in the world anyways because no one thinks trans people exist anyways so feeling trans is a trans thing or being exposed to a tooooooon of trans people. Not like being a rebellious teenager.If you wanna talk more off anon we can. \n\nHope I explained this well enough. Also broadening your vision of gender helps because you might not feel 100% a binary gender and therefore gender is hard and shitty so yeah.\n\nBeing trans is great, cis people and cissexism just sucks. [{"blog_name":"robo-nerds","id":97506116789,"post_url":"http://robo-nerds.tumblr.com/post/97506116789/can-we-have-some-body-positivity-that-doesnt","slug":"can-we-have-some-body-positivity-that-doesnt","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 21:06:19 GMT","timestamp":1410728779,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"a5nZUKVm","tags":["text posts","body positivity","overweight","intersectionality","trans","transgender","women"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZxxG1o1QpqKIr","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"can we have some body positivity that doesn’t fixate on cis people who are on the upper end of the scale of average weight….like….this shouldnt be this hard guys lets do this….","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"transacrossamerica","id":97505853104,"post_url":"http://transacrossamerica.tumblr.com/post/97505853104/new-resources-added-to-trans-across-america","slug":"new-resources-added-to-trans-across-america","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 21:03:00 GMT","timestamp":1410728580,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"BCTxFw8e","tags":["trans","trans*","transgender","genderqueer","trans health","indiana","minnesota","minneapolis"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZRgv1n1QppJwm","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"New Resources Added To Trans Across America: Minneapolis!","body":"For today’s continuation of our Great Lakes updates we’ve added two new medical providers in Minneapolis. But that’s not all! We are also currently in talks with local organizations in Indiana about republishing their information. Assuming those are successful, we will be adding a number of medical providers in Indiana for our update this week. Make sure to check back then for our last Great Lakes update!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"askatransguy","id":97505824553,"post_url":"http://askatransguy.tumblr.com/post/97505824553/hey-can-i-get-some-advice-with-a-personal-issue-a","slug":"hey-can-i-get-some-advice-with-a-personal-issue-a","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-14 21:02:49 GMT","timestamp":1410728569,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"vqO8fMEn","tags":["trans","transgender","aceofsplades"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zhn-Ho1QppCyf","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"asking_name":"aceofsplades","asking_url":"http://aceofsplades.tumblr.com/","question":"Hey! Can I get some advice with a personal issue. A couple of people in my life have wanted to talk to me about gender questioning.  They're AFAB and went through big tomboy stages where they felt jealous of boys and wished they were boys.  They talk about it as if they were passing phases but I'm not sure that's true.  Can you give me advice on helping them explore this? I'm not out to either of them (they know me as a boy) and I'm not the expert on male identity they want me to be! Thankyou x","answer":"I can see how that would be tricky! Honestly, it’s probably going to be a lot of the same things you went through, but in a different way. Lots of introspection and self examination - would they feel more comfortable using male pronouns? Do the labels “girl/woman/female” make them uncomfortable/do they not really associate with them? Something I found that helped was looking into a mirror and saying “I am a girl”, “I am a boy” and “I am not a girl or a boy” and seeing what I felt most comfortable with.\n\nGender is really complex. “Male identity” is still something I’m learning about. I’m still figuring out how to express my masculinity in ways I’m completely comfortable with. Because there isn’t just one way to be male. People associate masculinity and manliness with many different things, especially as you move into the trans community. So encourage them to educate themselves, and consider what masculinity means to them. So I guess I do it as a way to cope with the dysphoria of not passing because when I don’t past I feel like I need to change something. And the thing that I can change all the time is my hair.","photoset_layout":"2","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_1280.jpg"},{"width":422,"height":750,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_500.jpg"},{"width":338,"height":600,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_400.jpg"},{"width":225,"height":400,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":178,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cfbe9556a7a18eb471f93ddb29e4a3a9/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o1_1280.jpg"}},{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_1280.jpg"},{"width":422,"height":750,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_500.jpg"},{"width":338,"height":600,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_400.jpg"},{"width":225,"height":400,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":178,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/21d60c69e9fcc5d05ca6e0136e20488e/tumblr_nbwqos13Ez1rbxaf5o2_1280.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"girlwhocriedsupernova","id":97500584442,"post_url":"http://girlwhocriedsupernova.tumblr.com/post/97500584442/hrt","slug":"hrt","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 20:02:03 GMT","timestamp":1410724923,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"6WNvRKD1","tags":["gender","trans","o"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZiDNks1QpVDdw","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"title":"HRT","body":"I think that there are a lot of experiences that trans women, transfeminine people, and generally AMAB trans people have in common, that we largely don’t know about because we don’t talk about them. With that in mind, therefore, I would like to share my experiences with deciding whether to start hormone replacement therapy, which I did, in hopes that it will be helpful to someone out there.\n\nFor those who don’t know, HRT is the process of replacing or supplementing the hormones naturally produced by your body, particularly the sex hormones (testosterone/androgens, estrogen, progesterone, etc.). It is used to treat both cis and trans people, and in trans people it is used to trigger a second puberty in order to relieve dysphoria.\n\nWhen I first figured out that I was trans, I didn’t think I would seek HRT or any other medical transition treatment. It’s just a body, I reasoned. It’s not me, I just happen to live inside of it, so who cares what it looks like. That is an incredibly unhealthy attitude, but one which I had necessarily developed as a child in order to protect myself from dysphoria.\n\nAs I continued processing things, however, I began to change my mind. I discovered that just as I had erected mental walls to protect myself from fully experiencing social dysphoria, I had erected even taller, thicker walls to protect myself from my body. These walls had been very effective, but I immediately started poking at them (trying to actually see myself when looking in the mirror, for instance). Bad idea.\n\nSo I figured out pretty quickly that I was interested in HRT, but I was still very apprehensive about it. It felt like a very permanent thing, and I was very scared about making a choice that I might later regret. On the other hand, I might also regret the choice to delay any longer, because I was almost 25 and bodies age differently according to what hormones are in them.\n\nAt this point, I would like to break to tell you some fun facts about sex hormones:\n\nBoth testosterone and estrogen have permanent effects during “first” puberty, such as affecting bone structure.\nTestosterone has permanent effects whenever in life it is started (facial hair, deepening voice).\nEstrogen has practically no permanent effects when started post-puberty. The only two things it does that cannot be undone by switching back to testosterone are breast development (which can be partially undone, but requires surgery to be fully undone; doesn’t even start for a month or two, isn’t noticeable for closer to sixish months) and infertility (that is, for people with testes, not for people with ovaries, obviously; declines gradually, usually gone after a year, maybe less)\nAll of this creates double-edged sword for AMAB trans folks: hormones alone cannot undo some of the things we might be dysphoric about (although I promise there are other means for dealing with the hair and the voice, it’s just more work); however trying HRT is relatively risk-free for us.\n\nMy therapist told me that many trans women who are not totally sure about HRT just try it for a little, and use that as a test to see if they are comfortable, knowing that they can stop and turn around at any time. For most cis men, HRT will likely make you feel depressed - for most dysphoric trans women it will make you feel less depressed. Obviously this is not universal, but it means you can try HRT for a little bit and see how you feel as a test for whether it might help you to be on it, which is what I did.\n\nThe first physical effects you are supposed to notice are softer skin and thinner body hair. For me, however, the first thing that happened was that I felt dramatically less anxious - like in a week or two, there was a dramatic effect. I still deal with anxiety on the regular, but the only times it goes back to what it was like before are when I forget to take my hormones! Which is pretty good affirmation for me, that I made the right decision.\n\nSo I felt pretty good, and I therefore never made the decision to stop HRT. I did have one crisis about it that lasted for a few days. I think this happened after three or four months on estrogen. One night in bed, I was lying there thinking, “I’m going to have boobs now. That’s just how it’s going to be from now on and soon enough there will be more or less no going back.” I was very dysphoric about not having breasts my whole life, like my upper torso felt this strange emptiness, but I think the permanence of it really got to me, because I had never had breasts before and now I was just going to choose to have them forevermore. Change is scary I guess. I talked it over with a couple friends and my therapist and realized that even though it was scary it was what I needed.\n\nAnyway, it’s been about 22 months since I started HRT and about 16 months since I’ve been on a full, stable dose/had my hormone levels in the medically designated “female” range. It was absolutely the right decision for me. My body is definitely not the body I would have chosen, if I could choose what my body would look like, but it is definitely a body I can live in and often be present in, none of which I could have said two years ago ago.\n\nI would encourage anyone considering this to talk to a good gender specialist about this, if you are able to (what constitutes a “good” gender therapist is a whole ‘nother story, and maybe I or someone else can make a post about that sometime - you may or may not have access to one depending on health care coverage and where you live), and maybe try it for a couple weeks to see how you feel (again, if you are able to do that - access to health care, especially what is deemed “trans” health care is very spotty almost everywhere, so you may need help trying to navigate that labyrinth as well). I am 100% always open for questions from trans or questioning people about this topic.\n\nGo in peace and be well and remember to love yourselves as much as you can manage, and if you can’t manage, find some friends to do it for you.\n\nReblogs are encouraged on this post if you think it will help your followers.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"helloiammaggie","id":97500400192,"post_url":"http://helloiammaggie.tumblr.com/post/97500400192/lazy-sunday-selfies","slug":"lazy-sunday-selfies","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-14 am Transgender\n\nAllyson Robinson at TEDx Nightingale Bamford School:\n\nI set out on this journey to become the person, the woman that I had always known myself to be, not to become transgender. I mean, who wants to identify with a medical condition, right? Who would willingly embrace a label that brings with it such fear and such loathing? […] Because of it I shook with fear under barrages of slurs and threats hurled at me by strangers on the street. I shuddered in pain under needles and scalpels as my body was remade to affirm the image of myself that was imprinted on my mind.\n\n  Somewhere along the journey, something changed: Despite all of the pain and travail, I grew not only to accept my journey, but to treasure it. Today I am accepted by the world without question as the woman I am and have indeed always been and I no longer have to wear a maligned and misunderstood medical condition as my identity. And yet today I choose to.\n\n Today I say it with pride: I am transgender. And with no small amount of gratitude either. Because today I see it as one of the greatest gifts that I have ever received. I am thankful that I am transgender because being trans has shown me that there were other perspectives, other ways of viewing and experiencing the World that were just as valid as my own, maybe even more so.\n\nAllyson Robinson was recently ordained a Baptist LGBT* Youth Group in Walthamstow, East London","body":"Club Mellow Youth Group is a space for lesbian, gay, bisexual or trans* young people aged 13-21yrs who would like to meet up with others in a friendly, safe, supportive environment with a host of opportunities for participating in a programme of facilitated activities, sharing experiences, enjoying good company, joining in discussions, or just relaxing, chilling & have a little mid-week fun away from the scene. We have activities for all tastes, including some just for fun, some to challenge our brains, some to bring out our creativity, and some for our health, wellbeing, empowerment & safety. \n\nJoin us every Wednesday 6-9pm at the ELOP Centre, 56-60 Grove Road, London E17 9BN. Admission £1. \n\nNew members always welcome & group facilitators are always at hand to introduce & support new people as needed.\n\n  We also have a small snack bar, an LGB&T community library that you can join, plus rainbow goods merchandise, plenty of comfy relaxing sofas, a pool table, games corner & more! Come & experience for yourself.\n\nIf you require any further information regarding this email or the group itself please contact us on 0208 509 3898 or email us info@elop.org","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"nbselfielove","id":97489179093,"post_url":"http://nbselfielove.tumblr.com/post/97489179093/ive-never-felt-like-a-girl-but-i-have-a-girls-body","slug":"ive-never-felt-like-a-girl-but-i-have-a-girls-body","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-14 17:45:35 GMT","timestamp":1410716735,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"f2eGHs5p","tags":["gender neutral","genderfluid","dyshporia","trans","trans masculine","genitalia mention","misogyny mention","problematic language","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZpReno1Qopj7L","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":10,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"I've never felt like a girl but I have a girls body which is ok. (Although there is some penis envy but mostly cos you can play WAY more with it. Like even have fun while peeing..!) If someone asked what gender I feel like inside \"neither\" would probably be most accurate, but i usually feel more masculine/not girl when around other girls. Genderneutral sounds right to me cos spirit isn't gender but can you explain the difference between that and genderfluid?","answer":"I do love questions!\n\nOne thing to keep in mind is that the definitions of gender aren’t all-inclusive things set in stone. There’s no one right way to be any gender (or lack of gender).\n\nBut I am comfortable speaking in generalities. In general, genderfluid people are more than one gender, and that gender changes. It can change from day to day, or throughout the day, or over the course of a longer period of time. For example, I’m genderfluid. Sometimes I’m a girl, sometimes demiboy, sometimes androgyne, sometimes agender. Some people shift between male and female, or female and agender, or any other combination of genders. Genderfluid people may also be more than one gender at any given time, but the “fluid” part suggests that there are changes involved over time.\n\nFrom what I have seen, people who are gender neutral do not all agree on what that means as a gender identity. Some say it is a lack of gender. Some don’t really feel it’s a gender identity, but a gender presentation: a way to look and act that doesn’t identify you as any specific gender. Maybe some folks who identify as gender neutral can chime in with their experiences? \n\nA couple of things to keep in mind when you’re talking about gender: if you’re not a girl then you don’t have a girl’s body. There are men and non-binary people who have vaginas, breasts, etc. If you want to specify what gender the doctors and your parents picked for you, you can say you were assigned female at birth (AFAB) or designated female at birth (DFAB). \n\nAnother word that you may find helpful is trans masculine. Trans masculine people are AFAB folks who identify as at least somewhat masculine.\n\nAs you share experiences with being trans, people are going to bring up dysphoria. In the most general terms, dysphoria is simply knowing that you’re a different gender than you were assigned at birth. But it can also be used to talk more specifically about things like “penis envy.” If you feel you would be happier with a penis and/or you experience distress because you don’t have one, then that can be described as sex dyshporia. Being uncomfortable with being identified as female by other people (like when they use the wrong pronouns for you) is often called social dysphoria. (ps, be aware that the concept of “penis envy” is rooted in misogyny).\n\nIgnore anyone who tells you that dyshporia is required to be trans, because they don’t understand what dyshpria actually is, and they distort the meaning of it in order to exclude people they don’t like.\n\nA final note, to hopefully ward off the kind of people who make a fuss about this: there are folks out there who will tell you that gender neutral is not a gender identity, that it just refers to presentation. But they’re wrong. There are people who identify as gender neutral, and there’s nothing wrong with that. If it is right for you, that’s what’s important.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ineffablyfebruary","id":97488187337,"post_url":"http://ineffablyfebruary.tumblr.com/post/97488187337/morning","slug":"morning","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-14 And don't expect me not to be upset when you don't even try.","body":"","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"radicallia","id":97477795410,"post_url":"http://radicallia.tumblr.com/post/97477795410/even-if-being-gay-was-a-choice-i-would-chose-to-be","slug":"even-if-being-gay-was-a-choice-i-would-chose-to-be","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 15:20:57 GMT","timestamp":1410708057,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"TQj3DFZG","tags":["lgbt","lesbian","gay","bi","trans","lgbtqa","queer","asexual","bisexual","transgender","gay pride"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZbgnYn1Qo8HvI","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"title":"","body":"even if being gay was a choice I would chose to be gay I mean have you seen girls","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"theshadowofall","id":97477639363,"post_url":"http://theshadowofall.tumblr.com/post/97477639363/how-do-i-go-about-buying-clothes-anyway-i-am-a","slug":"how-do-i-go-about-buying-clothes-anyway-i-am-a","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 15:18:49 GMT","timestamp":1410707929,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"lf2jEjcj","tags":["ftm","trans","transgender","lgbt","fashion"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zu1nHv1Qo7hp3","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"How do I go about buying clothes, anyway? I am a pre-T (possibly staying no-OP) transmen and I am TINY. Like 4 foot 11” tiny. My shoes are size 3Y. I have a hard enough time finding clothes that fit me in the girls section as it is. And how do I go about buying boxers/briefs/boxer briefs? It makes me nervous for some reason? Any suggestions on fashion, buying underwear and finding good sizes?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"an-andreja-pejic-blog","id":97477588983,"post_url":"http://an-andreja-pejic-blog.tumblr.com/post/97477588983/how-andreja-pejic-fashioned-her-own-version-of","slug":"how-andreja-pejic-fashioned-her-own-version-of","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 15:18:11 GMT","timestamp":1410707891,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"5i2A2TSX","tags":["andreja pejic","andrejapejic","buzzfeed","ashley c ford","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z8g7tu1Qo7VVt","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":21,"source_url":"http://www.buzzfeed.com/ashleyford/how-andreja-pejic-fashioned-her-own-version-of-womanhood#2ifgujn","source_title":"BuzzFeed","title":"How Andreja Pejić Fashioned Her Own Version Of Womanhood","body":"By Ashley C. Ford \n\nWhen she was 13 years old, Andreja Pejić googled the word “transitioning.” Puberty was approaching, and she was loathe to see her body grow into something even further away from what she wanted to see in the mirror. Google helped her find the answers she needed. “I discovered it was a national community, and there were doctors, and medical help. It wasn’t something ‘freaky’ or ‘bizarre’; there was a system.” She describes herself as a “geeky boy” eager to become physically female.\n\nThe visual of a “geeky boy” is hard to reconcile with the ethereal supermodel we see draped in couture fashions today. Known for her ability to conquer the runway dressed as a man or woman, androgyny has been her schtick since Andreja was known as Andrej. In 2011, New York magazine named Pejić “The Prettiest Boy in the World,” a title Pejić wasn’t altogether comfortable with. “The plan was to enjoy modeling, then get out, and transition. The more and more known I became, the harder that goal was. The whole world already knew me.”\n\nWell before the world knew her name, Pejić lived with her family in a Serbian refugee camp. Despite their living conditions, she describes her childhood as carefree. “I remember playing in the street a lot. I adored South American soap operas and pretending to speak Spanish. I had a happy childhood, but not a lot of material things.” Pejić’s mother, Jadranka Savić, had been formally educated as a lawyer, but took a series of a rural jobs to support her children, Andreja, and her brother Igor. Pejić’s parents were divorced, and even with the help of her own mother, Jadranka found it difficult to provide for her family.\n\n“I think my mom and grandma struggled a lot to provide for us. There were almost no jobs. We could barely afford honey.”\n\nOnce the family immigrated to Australia, they found slightly less financial hardship, but now had to deal with assimilating. At 9 years old, Pejić did not blend into her new surroundings seamlessly. “I was a very shy child. I was learning how to navigate a different world in several ways: a whole new language, a whole new culture. It was very different from European culture. Even things as simple as asking your grandmother to pack you a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, instead of a lasagna. I did that just so I could fit in with the other Australian kids.”\n\nWhat Pejić found hardest to assimilate to in her new surrounding wasn’t the culinary fare, but gendered expectations she was reluctant to take on. “I could no longer get away with playing with dolls. I had to integrate into a boy. In order to not be bullied, and not be seen as weird, and not be an outsider. I learned how to behave like a boy and suppress my natural characteristics, the way I walked and the way I talked. It was just about getting through the day without too much trouble. It wasn’t the best time in my life.”\n\nPejić believes she survived this particular time in her life due to a rich fantasy life inside her own head. “I was saved by my imagination. I would imagine what it would be like to go shopping with my mother as a girl. Some would say these were really mundane things, but I would dream about what life would be like as a girl, and it made me very happy.”\n\nPejić’s decision to transition was not as sudden as it seemed. She’s been transitioning since she was 13 years old. “I ordered medication online, saw doctors, and I came out to my mom. Once I had the support of my family, I had more confidence. Then, I started going to a liberal high school.” It was at University High that Pejić first embraced an androgynous identity. “Androgyny became a way of expressing my femininity, being pretty, and wearing girly clothing or unisex clothing. I didn’t have to explain things about gender identity, sexuality, or genetics. It didn’t have to go that deep and I felt like my peers wouldn’t understand what it means to be trans.”\n\nStill, it was her androgynous look that first got her noticed in the fashion industry, and ultimately catapulted her into a career as one of the most sought-after high fashion models, something Pejić says she never saw coming. “I didn’t expect to become famous. I didn’t expect to have the career that I have. I became kind of a poster child for androgyny. In the beginning I wasn’t ready to talk about wanting to transition or my internal feelings about gender dysmorphia, because it’s one thing to come out to your mom; it’s another to come out to the public.”\n\nPejić notes the intensely image-conscious fashion community as just one of the reasons she didn’t initially come out as trans. Despite her involvement in the community, few knew about her desire to transition. “Some people were very supportive and some people thought I would lose something, that I would no longer be special. I’m still the same person with the same ideas. But I had to do it for myself. I couldn’t worry about doing it for anyone else.” So how did she get to the point where she felt safe to tell the world she was a woman, and have the surgery she’d wanted since she was 13? “At the beginning of last year, I sat myself down and stared in the mirror and said, ‘Do you want to spend the rest of your life wondering what it would be like to feel completely comfortable in your own body?’”\n\nPejić felt she was at a place where she had a lot to lose if her industry would not accept her as a trans woman. While recognizing this could be true, Pejić decided she didn’t care. “You can’t let your career decide anymore when you’re going to do this. If I didn’t do it then, I wouldn’t have done it. I would have put it off for way too long, and I would be miserable. There was a need. A constant internal need. It was always there.”\n\nNearly 10 years after searching Google for a way out of her body, Pejić decided to have sexual reassignment surgery. She slowly let her close friends know what she was planning to do and received their loving support. One friend, filmmaker Eric Miclette, went even further than support and immediately encouraged Pejić to film the process of her transitioning. “We’ve worked on small projects before, and when I said, ‘I’m going in for SRS in a few weeks,’ he said, ‘You need to get some footage. You have one chance and you need to tell your story.’”\n\nAt first, Pejić was reluctant. “I can’t say that I wanted to capture that or that having a camera around was the way I dreamt of it being. It was a very personal thing and I wanted it to keep it that way. I’m a very private person, and yes, very shy. It wasn’t my dream to have a camera there. But he really changed my mind about that. He asked me to think about the people who’ve had to hide their whole lives and who will find inspiration because you decided to go public with this.” They decided to collaborate on an intimate documentary, with Pejić insisting she didn’t want a lot of cameras involved, just Miclette.\n\nFor his own part, Miclette asked for access into the model’s life, past and present, though neither of them wanted the documentary to be a “vanity project.” In their commitment to this shared goal, Pejić is in no way involved in the film except as its focus. “I remain a subject of the documentary. I’m not a producer or a director. I think in order to create a critical work, an objective work, I needed to be a subject with no creative influence. I had to show the true me, and allow [Miclette] into my life completely, and not worry about looking good all the time or saying the right thing. I had to let go of all of that.”\n\nFor now, Andrej(a) is still in production with a Kickstarter campaign that has already raised over $25,000 to see it come to fruition as a distributable film. Since the launch of the campaign, Pejić has been most excited to see messages and mail from the people she believes need to see this film most. “We’ve been getting all kinds of incredible messages, many of them from parents. I think parents are a big target for this because I was lucky to have a family, and to have their support. Too many kids in the LGBT community are being abandoned. It’s not right. Everyone should have their parents’ support. I hope this film brings parents understanding.”\nPejić says that while her mother was supportive, she was also concerned about the quality of life her child could expect to lead as a trans woman, something her daughter worried about as well. Ultimately, it was the desire for a life lived most authentically that gave Pejić the confidence she needed to “feel comfortable in her own skin.” That happiness is something she thinks all parents want for their children, and something more trans folks can have access to with more understanding. She said, “Transitioning isn’t just physical, it’s also social. It’s not enough to just change your looks and your body; you also have a need to be accepted by society and the people around you in the gender role that you feel you are. I definitely feel like I’m more comfortable. I feel like I can live the life of being a girl I’ve always wanted.”\n\nFrom BuzzFeed","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"shemail-delivery","id":97477373503,"post_url":"http://shemail-delivery.tumblr.com/post/97477373503/um-so-i-ordered-a-m-sized-binder-and-it-doesnt-do","slug":"um-so-i-ordered-a-m-sized-binder-and-it-doesnt-do","type":"text","date":"2014-09-14 15:15:00 GMT","timestamp":1410707700,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"LJQpEhIS","tags":["underworks","binder","ftm","trans","chest binder"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z_D5yp1Qo6gu-","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"Um so I ordered a M sized binder and it doesn't do shit??","body":"I figured since I’m a 36-38 C/D (sometimes) that M would be the correct size, well it didn’t do shit and I’m pretty upset. Dresses and makeup are for every gender, it really sucks that a lot of people don’t think that, especially when it’s people close to you like your family! Clothes do not define gender, listener, not at all! Please believe me when I say that you are a real boy. \n\nWhat your mother said was absolutely wrong, gender is an issue everyone should explore at some point in their life, it’s no different to becoming ‘obsessed’ with eating or breathing. Feeling comfortable with yourself is a necessity. \n\nKeep faith in yourself Listener, continue to ask your family to respect your pronouns and gender and keep strong in the knowledge that you are as much of a boy as you feel, no matter what anyone says. Maybe you could try and explain to your family how clothes do not define gender or say that girls aren’t real girls unless they wear dresses all the time. Comparisons are always good, sometimes it is necessary to turn a situation on it’s head so people can see how they’re wrong.\n\nEither, any and other way, I hope everything goes well for you listener, and even if it doesn’t, you will not be with your family forever. Soon you will be with lizards instead. Lizards that understand and want to help.\n\n- (AP) — Women’s colleges are revisiting policies around enrolling transgender students as institutions of higher learning — single-sex, coed and those with religious affiliations — demonstrate varying degrees of acceptance for changing norms.\n\nMills College in Oakland, California, recently became the first U.S. women’s college to declare it would accept undergraduate applications from “self-identified women” and people “assigned female at birth who do not fit into the gender binary,” effective the semester that starts January 2015.\n\nMount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Massachusetts, followed with a similar announcement last week. Lamar Kick Off GenderFluid Spreading Awareness (And Shade)","url":"http://www.nextmagazine.com/content/laverne-cox-and-brother-m-lamar-kick-genderfluid-spreading-awareness-and-shade","description":"Two aesthetically opposite worlds converged on the stage of the Baruch Performing Arts Center on Tuesday night during a conversation between Orange is the New Black star Laverne Cox and her identical twin brother, artist M. Lamar. “This just proves you can be identical twins, grow up in the same household, and be different,” said Cox, whose blonde hair and white dress was in sharp contrast to Lamar’s black hair and punk inspired ensemble. \n\nThroughout the night, Lamar would make jokes about his sister’s appearance, relating it too Beyoncé in a sarcastic way. “So this is how it’s going to be?” said Cox. “You don’t understand. My brother loves to throw shade.”\n\nThe conversation between Cox and Lamar was the kickoff event of Baruch College’s weeklong GenderFluid festival. Running through Sept. 13, this week of binary-challenging performances and events is organized by Spin Cycle NYC. It celebrates trans and genderfluid artists and features the legendary gender outlaw Kate Bornstein, Holly Woodlawn and more. When Cox and Lamar took to the stage, Lamar quipped a bit about literal “gender fluids” such as the many fluids men and women could secrete.\n\nCox took a slightly more serious approach to introducing the topic after Lamar talked about how people don’t see him in the light of stereotypical black masculinity. “Gender isn’t something anyone should decide for you,” said Cox. “We need to live in and out of our own terms of gender.”\n\nThe evening often played out in this sort of debate. Lamar, for instance, was more critical of mainstream corporate culture during the discussion, while Cox advocated for the other side. Lamar even went so far as to criticize his sister’s claim to fame, Orange is the New Black, saying he is not interested in black roles written by white people.\n\n“My job is not to judge the material,” said Cox. She went on to say that her main efforts are put towards bringing humanity and her personal interpretation to all her work. She continued, saying she has really enjoyed everything that OITNB has done for women.\n\nLamar, further fueling apropos discussion with his sister, called into question her potential tokenism, feeling that Hollywood may assume it has fulfilled its black, trans woman quota.\n\nCox responded with a quote by Sidney Poitier, who himself felt that black people didn’t overcome with his winning the Oscar because he was the only one. She feels like it’s her job, while she has this time in the spotlight, to push other trans women forward and to continue to discuss the death rates and mistreatment of trans women of color, which, statistically, is more than other members of the LBGT community.\n\nLamar applauded his sister’s efforts.\n\nThings got a bit emotional for Cox when the two began to talk about their upbringing. Lamar hasn’t spoken to his mother in 15 years. Though the two had different opinions about their alleged familial trauma, Cox articulated that some topics are hard to discuss, but there is such a need to push through, without feeling judged, in order to create safer spaces for people to talk through their trauma. Vulnerability is necessary for connection.\n\n“When we begin to connect with people, healing happens,” she said. “Real love starts with [the] self. After that, we can really love each other. I heard once, ‘Justice is what love looks like in public.’”\n\nCox has proven through the last year that she’s among the finest and most poised trans public figures today. Tuesday night showed her in full I hate my body. I like girls clothes. I hate body hair. But like. I dunno I just don’t think I click with that label anymore. I guess genderqueer would be more accurate? I’m not really sure. confused","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"awkwardtransboy","id":97464152156,"post_url":"http://awkwardtransboy.tumblr.com/post/97464152156/what-is-the-best-binder-for-someone-with-a-size-c","slug":"what-is-the-best-binder-for-someone-with-a-size-c","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-14 11:16:49 GMT","timestamp":1410693409,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uNEe1GFy","tags":["trans","binding","afab trans","resources","chest binding","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZCXAjn1QnKF1S","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"What is the best binder for someone with a size C chest?","answer":"it really depends on what type of c you are! your size depends both on strap length and cup size. like a 34B and a 32C have the same cup volume but different strap lengths. and a 32D has the same cup volume as a 34C, but the smaller number means smaller strap lengths, so they fit differently. if you have a bigger cup volume, you’ll have to go bigger with the binder size\n\ni was a 34C before i started T and afterwards my size actually reduced a little bit, which was nice but ofc i had surgery anyways cause i still had significant breast tissue. \n\nmy preferred type of binder is velcro short ones, because they bind well but also you can loosen / tighten them easily. i used these two different kinds for most of my binding needs, and they worked great. \n\nwhen binding, it’s important that you find a binder that fits you well, and that doesnt impair your breathing. remember that you shouldnt wear it for extended periods of time, and if you have to wear it continuously, go into a bathroom or something to take like 5 minute binderless breaks every once in a while. binding can be dangerous. also, never sleep with your binder on!!!\n\nu could bruise or break your ribs or develop breathing problems if you bind too tight or for too long. so please be careful. \n\nlesloveboat is my favourite site for trans related stuff cause they have so many options in terms of binders, including binding swimwear. and they also have lots of resources for packing and scar treatment after surgery. basically theyve got it all! definitely check it to Transgender in the Workplace demonstrates, there is a strong business case for treating transgender workers with dignity. Its tips, guidelines, and policy examples will help organizations enhance the bottom line, while keeping the workplace harmonious. The most in-depth and informative volume on transgender workers ever written, the book offers useful tools, practical information, and a variety of resources that will enable business leaders and organizations to deal effectively with the transgender phenomenon. It will also help workers struggling with their identities and will give strength to those who are secure, but have yet to come out.\n\nThere is no doubt that this guide will become the leading resource for every business owner, CEO, manager, HR/EEO professional, and transgender worker. Better yet, it will improve the cultural climate and quality of life for transgender workers and the organizations that employ them, resulting in increased productivity and improved voice","ftm singing voice","puberty 2.0"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZfkLgm1QmVDU9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"Confirmation and fear.","body":"Today we saw a couple of friends that we hang out with a handful of times per month anymore, one of whom is our former roommate (and also my bro/best friend type person). She says that my voice is definitely deeper, there’s some facial changes, and the same shoulder/neck thing that Kari has pointed out =). She is pretty excited for me for everything, and while I fail at knowing how to take it, it’s nice.\n\nMy only real issue emotionally arose tonight, when my singing voice was mentioned. It prompted me to look some things up, and I am extremely nervous that I may never sing well again. I’ve read research stating that low dose testosterone over time is best if you wish to maintain a singing voice that isn’t trashed, and I am already on a higher dosage than that allows for (.5cc weekly, which will increase somehow when I go in on Thursday this week). It’ll probably just take time and being over puberty 2.0 before I’m good enough to go out for karaoke again, but damn. I don’t want to give anyone the opportunity to validate a negative assumption about my mental health, either as a trans woman or porn performer. Booth"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbtqblogs","id":97442761423,"post_url":"http://lgbtqblogs.tumblr.com/post/97442761423/watch-meet-trailblazing-two-spirit-performer-iceis","slug":"watch-meet-trailblazing-two-spirit-performer-iceis","type":"link","date":"2014-09-14 03:54:21 GMT","timestamp":1410666861,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"dOSJvquu","tags":["two spirit","trans","transgender","trans*","lgbtq","lgbtq news","lgbt","lgbtq current events","lgbtqia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBCnOy1Qm2ehF","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":14,"title":"WATCH: Meet Trailblazing Two-Spirit Performer ICEIS Rain","url":"http://www.advocate.com/politics/transgender/2014/09/13/watch-meet-trailblazing-two-spirit-performer-iceis-rain","link_image":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbv59kG8jC1qb6re5_og.jpg","description":"ICEIS Rain is opening doors for indigenous gender-nonconforming artists, reports Canada’s CBC News. This week, the entertainer — who identifies as both female and male — became the first two-spirit person to perform at the Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards.\n\nICEIS Rain is also Massey Whiteknife, a 35-year-old member of the Mikisew Cree First Nation, who identifies as as a man sometimes and as Rain, a woman, at other times. Being two-spirit, he explains to CBC, means “you have accepted both your masculinity and femininity and you embrace both your spirits.”\n\n“Two-spirit\" is an identification used by some First Nations people to describe their nonbinary gender identity. Some consider it most closely synonymous with the Western concept of \"bi-gender\" people and include it in the \"transgender umbrella\" of identifiers. Other sources, such as the CBC report below, equate \"being two-spirited\" with being \"gay.\" The term, however, is not exactly equivalent to either \"transgender\" and/or \"gay.\"\n\nFor Whiteknife, living his two-spirit identity means that, by day, he is a gay male business owner in the sub-arctic Alberta oil sands. At night, she is ICEIS Rain, a female karaoke performer. Whiteknife and Rain share the same body, he explained to CBC, but each has their own passions and pursuits.\n\nAs Rain, she gained notoriety last year as a featured performer in the documentary Oil Sands Karaoke, and is working on a singing career. As Whiteknife, he gained accolades as a business tycoon, building up several oil sands-based businesses very quickly into a multi-million dollar operation.\n\nWhiteknife says Rain, as his formidable, “queen”-like second spirit, helped him overcome childhood sexual abuse, bullying, and gang rape to become highly admired in both his careers as a businessman and as an entertainer.\n\nRain, who is known for her anti-bullying anthem, “The Queen,” has now been nominated for two Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards. Whiteknife tells CBC he is humbled by the attention and to be the first two-spirit person to take the award ceremony’s performance stage.\n\n\"I don’t even have the words to express the emotions,\" he added. \"I’m overwhelmed, I’m honored.\"","can_reply":false}]

I am overly concerned about her thoughts, feelings and opinions, and she couldn’t give a flying fuck about mine. Caring too much is something that I’m unlearning with her, I just don’t know what to say or how to say it. \n\nI figure since I’ve told my dad, and will be telling my mom, they can take the liberty of informing their respective sides of the family. I feel like i don’t owe anyone a conversation about my life and choices to improve my life. Me: I'd like to destroy the idea of \"coming out\" as a narrative of someone choosing to be brave w/o addressing the role that privilege plays and that the ability to be \"out\" is often contingent on personal safety","dialogue":[{"name":"Person","label":"Person:","phrase":"How are you?"},{"name":"Me","label":"Me:","phrase":"I'd like to destroy the idea of \"coming out\" as a narrative of someone choosing to be brave w/o addressing the role that privilege plays and that the ability to be \"out\" is often contingent on personal safety"}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"feministroosterteeth","id":97422807191,"post_url":"http://feministroosterteeth.tumblr.com/post/97422807191/when-you-came-out-as-trans-was-your-family-and-friends","slug":"when-you-came-out-as-trans-was-your-family-and-friends","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-13 23:13:01 GMT","timestamp":1410649981,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"mKBt7VeQ","tags":["Anonymous","frtasks","trans","transgender","misgendering"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZHQdjr1QksX2N","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"When you came out as trans, was your family and friends accepting? This is quite a personal question and you don't have to answer if you don't want to.","answer":"Didn’t have much of a problem, not compared to some anyway. My siblings were fine (like most kids, my brother just took it at face value. My other sibling is genderqueer themselves - they came out after me, but as you can expect, we’re both 100% accepting of each other). My mum was pretty good about it, she took me to all my appointments and that because I don’t drive. It took her a while with pronouns but she got there in the end.\n\nMy dad was less good, but still mostly accepting and still uses the correct names and pronouns for me (not so much my sibling though, which is shitty). I don’t see my dad much though.\n\nFriends were all fine - if they weren’t okay with it, they weren’t really friends.","can_reply":false}]

22:05:54 GMT","timestamp":1410645954,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"ecdKCRqR","tags":["ftm","transgender","trans","trans man","tw","trigger warning"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZhXF8v1QkZoO-","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":20,"title":"tw mild talk of anatomy and dysphoria.","body":"Have any other trans people wondered if they are intersex in the past or in any way?\n\n I have always thought that i’ve been male but that i have secondary female sex characteristics accidentally.\nThat one day people would realise the big mistake and everyone will notice how obvious it has been that i’m really male!\nI mean i’ve been thinking this since i was a little kid. Even like bathing and looking at lower body parts I was sure they were not female parts, that doctors and parents were just mistaken.\n\n It’s so weird to think about, i mean, once puberty hit it was like, oh, i have those inside bits. I was always like maybe, just maybe i had the correct parts (for me) all along hidden inside! like when you hear of testicles not descending in fetal stages and such. \n\n Even now, i think, well, maybe i have intersex chromosomes, that it can’t just be my brain that’s male. because it feels so physical and real to be transgender, and i think most cis people, and even trans, forget this.\nThat its so physical a feeling, not just an emotional one.\nLike when people say “was a girl” or “female to male”\nI’m so sure i’ve always been male, its just been a long weird trip of dressing up and going with the flow, wondering when people will discover the truth.\n\nThat’s why despite liking more “girly” things emotionally, or recreational activities, i am 100% sure i am a guy physically.\nThe two are very different for me, and it just makes me so sure being trans (for me) is a thing from birth and not a mental misalignment caused by life or interests.\nIt makes the transitioning process really annoying because there are hours and hours talking about childhood and life and interests and sexuality and none of these things have ever influenced my gender, the only things that have are peoples perception and language used against non-femme afab people, which made me think being masculine as an afab person was shameful. So i became hugely shy and withdrawn. \n\nEven if no one reads this it was useful to write. and read back.\n\ntldr; My gender is something i cannot control and has always felt as real as medical proof of maleness, despite the physical evidence.\n\nidk, someone talk to me about this?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lepsog","id":97417719274,"post_url":"http://lepsog.tumblr.com/post/97417719274","slug":"","type":"link","date":"2014-09-13 22:03:29 GMT","timestamp":1410645809,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"OxQX6Zqj","tags":["trans","transsexual","top surgery","hotbaradadmar","my bff","fundly"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZaTThr1QkZ6tg","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","url":"https://fundly.com/m2/marcus-transition-surgery","description":"Help my friend Marcus get top surgery. LJG’s wiki saying “she helped me be able to come out as trans!! i love her!” and like older “more seasoned” trans ppl coming along n saying “yeah she’s good for visibility and all but she betrayed the radicals and started playing boring music” and, i mean, yeah, that’s all valid, but it seemed to me to have a real “wake up, kid. man\ni, wrongly, i admit, will take (and have already taken) the indictments as indictments on my humanity, trans or otherwise, and while i can deal w that on tumblr or okcupid, i cannot on the public presentation and ubiquitous communication tool that facebook is for me. \nmy opinions are worth shite and, even if they are sometimes good, they are expressed in a real didactic way bc of a lot of earnestness/profundity, but, i mean, that disagreement is all about taste and there’s no accounting for that. that said, like, searching for a former clarity is perfect af. i also think “i was a teenage anarchist” to be a pretty great song and, taking into account interviews w/ LJG at the time, not as big of a disavowal or ideological shift as a lot of people took it to be. when i saw the song title when i was 18, i was pissed too, but listening to it years later, it moved me and, if the whole initial feeling of betrayal was based on thinking of listening to the music as a conversation of sorts, letting her speak thru those interviews and not just the tune made the it view it with more complexity. not to say that this could account for everything she could have to say, or that she
