sadness. Without hormones I am already quite feminine. I can get away with things a lot of pre-HRH people can’t. For that, I am grateful. But the fact remains that I am not going through HRH. I am at a standstill. I have been for a long time. I go on denying my misery, and try to be happy for what I have. But every now and then, something will trigger the realisation of the truth that at the moment there is no future. I have a destination in mind, I’m not even on the right road yet. Just dead ends. \n\nI feel happy, and try to be, because that’s the only way I can cope. I’m sick of only being happy for other people’s progress. that?” “they used to be my friend jesi.” SEE THATS NOT THAT FUCKING HARD. its not my fault if youre worried your friends will have a hard time understanding what transitioning is. its on you to deal 04:15:59 GMT","timestamp":1410495359,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"fL3nqOx7","tags":["rant","transgender","trans","ftm","mtf","transplant","dysforia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z64chx1QcCcik","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"For the last couple of years, I have been following many different people on YouTube going through their transition, whether it being female to male, or male to female. I can honestly say I find it to be so heart warming. The way their face lights up to finally say that they will be starting hormones/testosterone. That they will finally physically become the person they always were inside. Even if it takes a long time, they’re willing to wait as long as it takes because dealing with the body dysforia is torture and to be a man/woman physically is what they’ve always wanted. \n\nWhat breaks my heart is to hear that when some of these people come out to their families and tell them that they are transgender, they are practically shown the door. They get kicked out or even abused at home because they aren’t considered normal or because their family thinks they can beat the nonsense out of them. But they can’t. Its not possible. I dont understand how a mother and father could show their own child the door because they want to be what they are on the inside. Just because one is born with the parts if a female does not mean they are mentally a female or vise versa.\n\nBut honestly, what I find to be the worst is when families tell their child that “its only just a phase, you’ll get out of it” because its not. You might not know when youre a young that you are indeed transgender but you just somehow know deep down that youre different from everyone else and that’s all that matters at the time. It takes a while for most to realize who they truly are. On the days leading up to this appointment, I was really making an effort to prepare for the worst for the appointment. I wanted to make sure that if I was told I would have to wait a long time, or that I had some health concerns that would delay testosterone, I’d be fine and well prepared. \n\nI met with Dr. Eckler for what was about an hour long intake session. We talked about how long I’ve known I was trans, what I hope to achieve, why I want to transition etc. She was so amazing. Dr. Eckler truly, genuinely cares for people. She has a refreshing interest in improving the quality of healthcare and life for trans individuals. \n\nSo we talked about testosterone and the effects and all that medical stuff, and then to my surprise, she told me that she’d order my blood work and have me starting testosterone in the next couple of weeks. \n\nI have to say that I wasn’t expecting to be able to start so soon. oloud","id":97270077916,"post_url":"http://soulstooloud.tumblr.com/post/97270077916/i-was-walking-into-a-friends-house-earlier-and-a","slug":"i-was-walking-into-a-friends-house-earlier-and-a","type":"text","date":"2014-09-12 #4","body":"<!-- more -->I probably should have made this post about three weeks ago, but with classes starting most of my blog has purely been queue based- and now my queue is depleted. So please keep up with these poorly formed rambles about my life.\n\nSchool: My Principle (mysoginistic af) called me a “law suit waiting to happen.” I’ll just leave that there. Students are totally cool with my transition. A few jerks refuse to use my correct pronouns, but like who cares about those lames. Bathrooms have gone extremely smooth. Despite the fact that the staff at my school complained that I was going to “get raped.” This assertion is clearly problematic, but I digress. None of this has happened, and I have much more faith in humanity than that. My Guidance Councilor has gone to bat for me citing the law like it’s his job, so I am extremly lucky on that account. My teachers also have been amazing in complying with my pronouns, my nerdy little AP Physics teacher always calls me Sir, and I just adore him. \n\nFenway Health Updates: i had my gender evaluation and was completely cleared for everything in the first session. However, because of my age I was told I needed to attend six sessions. This bumbed me out to the max. Luckily, they shortened it to three for me. I have now completed two, so then i have one more- and the PRESCRIPTION FOR TESTERONE DAY. So excited to start taking T and have the physical changes. I am so close right now. Seriously, I would recommend Fenway Health a million times over- it’s certainly not the fastest option but you know you’re in great qualified hands. Also , it is very likely that Harvard Piligrim will cover my top surgery since i live in Massachusetts- which means I will very likely have my surgery in June!! Things are all coming I hope to expand my class’s opportunity to understand and accept the diversity we’ll see in the real world. I haven’t found anything in our text books that address the lives and care of anyone outside the binary.\n\n  I appreciate confidentiality and your privacy and if you choose not to give me your name I understand but I’d like to know what state you are from if it’s relevant to state/local laws. 01:36:31 GMT","timestamp":1410485791,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"y8FMBk8X","tags":["trigger warning","scars tw","poc","chubby","trans","gender","submission"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZMju4y1QbV11d","followed":false,"post_author":"fullmetalchampion","is_submission":true,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":164,"caption":"Trigger warning: self-esteem, self-depreciation\n\nAfter some encouragement and reading countless stories on this blog, I have felt a little more and more motivated to write down my account, for anyone like me who needs a little push, or a little encouragement to tell themselves that they are beautiful. I am so thankful that I have taken my first baby steps toward loving myself after all these years, and this is my first pebble I’d like to toss, to get the ripple effect going, one which says this: I am beautiful, and proud to be me.\n\nI will begin by saying this: I have been diagnosed with a few things out of my control, but not necessarily things that define me or my attitude. There are things I haven’t been diagnosed for, things I will come to accept or change about myself, once I come to terms with whether or not it’s a part of me that’s good for me.\n\nI was diagnosed first with a blood disorder, then bipolar II, then I made the biggest step forward in my life that has changed my life for so many good reasons: I told the truth about myself. I am a transgender guy. I was born with a female body, with everything else about me screaming YOU ARE MALE.\n\nFor years I thought the major part of my depression stemmed from my poor body esteem. For years I tried to cope and find me.\n\nMy poor body image, however, came long before I came out. I had been a few pounds underweight for a good portion of my life, but I still hated the small stomach I had. I never wore flattering clothes, and always tried to hide my body.\n\nI thought surgery would change this, as though eliminating the parts of me I was unhappy about would suddenly bring about a miraculous era of love for myself. Instead I was greeted with the side effects of medication and surgery: keloids and weight gain. The perfect chest I’d always dreamed of came with drawbacks, the scars will never heal and they caused 18 months of physical pain before I could finally afford help in terms of dermatology.\n\nI have had binge eating problems (where I eat, and feel guilty about it later, or “I eat my emotions.”) and now I am finally facing those issues because they are finally visible. Now I have stretch marks everywhere. Knees, thighs, back, stomach, arms, chest, you name it. My body image and self-esteem are at the lowest point they have ever been, and having the doctors tell me I need to lose weight repeatedly has never helped, or motivated me. Because of my chronic depression, I feel even less motivation to get around to “feeling better about me.” There was a time in my life where I absolutely thought I couldn’t take it anymore, and a year later I wound up checking myself into a hospital to prevent myself from taking my own life.\n\nYou know what though? I’m proud that I did that. I would not become the amazing person I am today if I had given in. And I’m proud that I admitted I needed help. Everyone thinks that if you go to a hospital for “mental issues,” you are crazy. I actually remember, however, this five day experience as one of the happiest times of my life. I learned that there was nothing wrong with me, I am beautiful the way I am. My second problem was that I didn’t love or accept the people around me, and that I couldn’t see that I am strong, wise, inspirational, and brave.\n\nI am still working on my self-esteem as I’ve said, but I want to truly love me, and part of me is loving and accepting this vessel I was given. You only get one, as they say. Part of loving me means loving who I am and what makes me the wonderful person I am.\n\nI want you to know above all, there are people like you out there. There are people whose surgeries didn’t give them the body of a god/goddess. There are people out there just like you who struggle just like you. I am one of these people. And I don’t care who you are or what your situation is.\n\nYOU. ARE. BEAUTIFUL, and I love you. Never let anyone make you feel/tell you otherwise.\n\nI am willing to listen if you ever need to talk, and also willing to make friends here.\n\nMy blog is: fullmetalchampion\n\nfullmetalchampion.tumblr.com\n\n  BE BRAVE! JOIN THE BODY PEACE nonconforming","genderqueer","genderfluid","nonbinary","gender","gender identity","south carolina"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZbNRjm1QbKl1t","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"Teen sues South Carolina DMV over license photo","url":"http://www.cbsnews.com/news/teen-sues-south-carolina-dmv-over-license-photo/","link_image":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbkzn3lBkU1tjgtym_og.jpg","description":"16-year-old says he was “humiliated” when officials made him remove his makeup for license photo\nI’m obsessed with this lawsuit. Good luck, Chase and TLDEF! You are clearly in the right. \n\nP.S. At first, I thought CBS was misgendering Chase, but TLDEF also uses he/him/his, and I trust TLDEF to use the correct pronouns.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbtqblogs","id":97262669196,"post_url":"http://lgbtqblogs.tumblr.com/post/97262669196/donna-rose-op-ed-some-advice-for-chad-griffin","slug":"donna-rose-op-ed-some-advice-for-chad-griffin","type":"link","date":"2014-09-12 00:58:06 GMT","timestamp":1410483486,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"84t3Wvi3","tags":["trans","transgender","trans*","lgbtq","lgbtq news","lgbt","lgbtq current events","lgbtqia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBCnOy1QbJesC","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"Donna Rose Op-ed: Some Advice for Chad Griffin","url":"http://www.advocate.com/commentary/2014/09/11/op-ed-some-advice-chad-griffin","link_image":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbqtoftDxj1qb6re5_og.jpg","description":"Last Friday, Human Rights Campaign president Chad Griffin stood in front of several hundred trans people, friends, and allies from around the country at the annual Southern Comfort Conference in Atlanta to say something that has been long overdue. He acknowledged and apologized for past slights and behaviors at the heart of a significant gap between HRC and the trans community in the hopes that fences can finally be mended. Just as important, he pledged that the organization would do better in the future.\n\nI’ve been thinking about this for a few days now, letting it seep in and settle in my consciousness. What happened in 2007, when then-HRC president Joe Solmonese stood on that very same stage making promises and commitments that would prove to be inconvenient and hollow less than six weeks later, continues to be a dagger between the shoulders for many of us who dared to believe back then. Perhaps nobody felt that pain more acutely than I.\n\nAt the time I was the first and only trans member of the HRC board of directors. I was the cochair of the diversity committee. Jamison Green and I worked tirelessly for the business council, and many of the workplace protections and benefits that have become such an important reality for many trans people today are a direct result of the work that we started. As a board member, I raised a significant amount of money to fund the critical work we were doing, and I spoke passionately and tirelessly at dinners around the country. I rolled up my sleeves and wasn’t afraid to fight on the front lines wherever and whenever necessary. Why? Because I believed. I trusted that the organization would stay true to the lofty ideals I thought we represented. When it proved that it didn’t, I had to go.\n\nKnowing what I know of the backstory of what happened, all I can say is that my sense of betrayal, anger, hurt, and frustration continues to this day. Time has dulled some of it, but the scab has still not healed. I realize we all need to put the past behind us in order to move forward, and I’m trying my best to do that, I really am. What happened was deeply, deeply personal, and there has still been no closure for me. But that’s water under the bridge at this point, and none of that is Chad’s fault.\n\nAlthough Chad stood on that stage and apologized last week, the truth is that he fell on a sword that wasn’t his to fall on. It was drawn by leaders in the organization who are no longer there and who I can say without hesitation were directly responsible for what unfolded and how. Chad inherited their ill-conceived legacy of anger and distrust, and has pledged to fix it. I respect him for that.\n\nIt’s important to recognize that HRC today is not the same organization it was then. At the same time, the collective trans community (and entire LGBT community, for that matter) has changed too. We have matured. We have weathered tests that strained the bonds of “community” and challenged our collective commitment to the high ideals I spoke of in my resignation letter. Whether we realize it or not, we have emerged the stronger for it.\n\nI have never met Chad Griffin, so I have no personal sense of his commitment to his words or his ability to keep his promises. Although I give him the benefit of the doubt, I hope to meet with him at some point to form my own opinion, as I trust my instincts. However, he’s off to a good start. The organization that he leads is already light-years ahead of where it was when I first got involved more than a decade ago. People I admire and respect greatly who left the organization around the “dark time” are back in leadership positions. Jay Brown, the director of foundation program strategies, is someone I’d stand with in battle any time, anywhere. Brandon Braud again leads the initiatives involving historically black colleges and universities with passion and skill. I met Hayden Mora, the deputy chief of staff, at Southern Comfort and came away impressed and hopeful. Internally, the organization has revamped and realigned its foundation structure to address the issues that affect the daily lives of many LGBT people.\n\nCan the organization do more? Of course it can. Per Chad’s speech, he recognizes that, and he pledged to address it through action. I have several nuggets of constructive personal advice for him. Let us help you keep the commitments that you made Friday. Don’t think you are doing things for us — do them with us. Actively reach out and engage those of us who may not have sipped the Kool-Aid yet, and take what we tell you seriously. Ask us what we need and what our priorities are; don’t presume to tell us. Don’t patronize us or placate us — it will only make us angry. Lead through example. Respect us, include us, embrace us, but most important of all, for God’s sake, realize that honesty and integrity must be nonnegotiable if this relationship is going to work. Without that, there is nothing.\n\nI want to believe that things are different now. I really do. It’s not that I’m a glutton for punishment. Rather, I consider myself a pragmatist first and foremost. We need to make this relationship work, not simply for the sake of the T but for the sake of all who define themselves by some letter of our continually growing LGBTQ+ alphabet soup. We’re either in this together or we’re not. Anything gained for some at the expense of others will ultimately prove itself to be a hollow victory for all. Been there, done that.\n\nErnest Hemingway once said, “The best way to find out if you can trust somebody is to trust them.” Based on Chad’s comments last week, all I can promise in return is to do my best to try. Let’s start with that and see where it goes. If enough of us feel similarly — well, I dare to dream.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"massagemybellyfat","id":97262630739,"post_url":"http://massagemybellyfat.tumblr.com/post/97262630739/im-thinking-about-the-name-maddock-nickname-mac","slug":"im-thinking-about-the-name-maddock-nickname-mac","type":"text","date":"2014-09-12 00:57:37 GMT","timestamp":1410483457,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"2liLkgQr","tags":["trans","ftm","renaming myself"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZFT-Wu1QbJVTJ","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"","body":"I’m thinking about the name Maddock/ nickname Mac. S800","ISO":1600,"Aperture":"f/3.5","Exposure":"1/13th","FocalLength":"6mm"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"slightlyirresponsible","id":97260477601,"post_url":"http://slightlyirresponsible.tumblr.com/post/97260477601/coming-out-as-trans-to-my-parents-thoughts","slug":"coming-out-as-trans-to-my-parents-thoughts","type":"text","date":"2014-09-12 00:28:52 GMT","timestamp":1410481732,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"t3nqOvLO","tags":["coming out","transgender","trans*","trans","ftm","f2m","coming out letter"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnJgZv1QbBHoX","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"Coming out as trans* to my parents - thoughts?","body":"Dear Mom and Dad,\n\n  Before I really begin writing this letter, I want to ask that you read the entire thing. Some things that I say here may be difficult to process, make you feel anxious, angry, hurt, or even scared. But I’m not writing this letter to make you feel those things. I’m writing this letter because I’ve struggled for a long time now to find the perfect way to tell you what it is that I need to tell you, and this is the best way I can think of that will both allow me the time I need to comprise all of my thoughts, and you the time to process what I’m going to tell you before you respond.\n\n  I am a transgender man. I have been living as male and as Ashton since December 4, 2013. I’m sure you may be wondering whether this is my way of fitting in with my friends, especially considering that my best friend, Jay, is also a trans man. Let me dispel that notion from the start. I have more non-trans friends than I do trans friends. I have never felt right in my body. I thought that coming out as gay would fix that, and in some ways, it did. It gave me access to the LGBT community, and I was able to find friends who were more like me. However, even after immersing myself in the LGBT community, I didn’t feel whole. I felt a rush of anxiety whenever I would shower or look at myself in the mirror, whenever I would shop in the women’s section for my clothes, whenever I would even hear the words “she” or “her” in reference to me, and for a long time, I didn’t know where that anxiety was coming from or what it meant.\n\n  When I came to Wayne State, I met my first trans man – my good friend, Charlie. However, because he was already out as trans and living as male when I met him, it didn’t ever occur to me that I might actually be transgender – it never occurred to me that trans was something I could “be” (I put “be” in quotes there because being transgender is not something that one chooses to do…it is something one IS). Then, I met Jay. When I met Jay, he wasn’t out as trans. It was almost 6 months into our friendship before he told me that he had always felt like a male, and that he was going to start transitioning. That was the first time I realized that I might actually be trans, but I was far too terrified to even admit it to myself, let alone to anybody else. I spent the next few years denying the feelings I was having. Whenever I would look in the mirror, whenever anybody would use feminine gender pronouns when talking about me, whenever I would introduce myself as a lesbian at the GLBTA Student Union Meetings, I would feel my gut tighten, and I would ignore that feeling of discomfort that comes hand in hand with lying to yourself.\n\n  Finally, on December 4 of 2013, I was able to say the words out loud. I told the members of the GLBTA Student Union that I was trans and that, from that point forward, I would like to be known as Ashton, and be referred to by male pronouns. Now, everyone from my friends to my therapist to the Dean of Students knows me as Ashton and refers to me by male pronouns. I have never felt so happy and so complete as I have in the months since I’ve come out as trans. I have also felt an increased anxiety about having to hide this huge part of myself from my family, who literally mean the world to me. I told Amy about a month ago, but I promised her that I would wait to come out to the rest of the family until after her wedding. Part of me wanted to make sure that I didn’t take any attention away from her on her day, because she deserved to have her moment in the spotlight. However, part of me felt that if I had come out in the chaos preceding Amy’s wedding, I would be more likely to get a negative reaction, and that terrified me. Even as I write this letter, I am more scared than I can possibly express that I will lose what means more to me than anything – my family – by telling you this. Believe me, if this weren’t literally a matter of life and death for me – and it is – I would not transition. It would be much easier for me to exist within our family as a gay female than as a trans male. But the thought of living a lie causes me so much anxiety, and puts me in such a deep depression, that I am actually afraid of what I might do to myself if I continue to hide from this.\n\n  I am hoping to start taking testosterone soon, so you will start to see some physical changes, including deepening of the voice, increased hair growth, and a general change in body shape (due largely to a redistribution of body fat). I realize this will be a lot to take in, and that it may be difficult to see me looking like a completely different person. I also realize that you may be afraid that I am going to have a more difficult life because of my trans identity. This may indeed be the case. I am not coming out because I think it’s going to make my life perfect. I am also not coming out so that I can get your blessing – I am well aware that this is going to be incredibly difficult for you to accept, and that you only have my best interest at heart when you feel inclined to oppose my transition. I am coming out because I feel that I have no other choice if I am to live a full, happy life. \n\nI am truly sorry for any heartache this likely causes you. Please know that it causes me just as much heartache to know that I have to run the risk of losing my family in order to be true to myself. If it would help you, I would love to set up a session with my therapist – we could speak either over the phone or via Skype (I can easily explain to you how it works, so don’t worry about not knowing how to use it). If you feel that you would be uncomfortable with that, please know that I am always open to answer any questions you may have about this. I also have several resources that may help you to understand both what I am going through and how you can navigate it as my parents. I want you to be informed, but I didn’t include any of the resources I have available to me here because I don’t want you to feel as though I am forcing any of it down your throat – I want to be sure that it is information you are seeking on your own.\n\nPlease know that I love you, and that without you in my life, I would be lost.\n\nWith love,\n\nAshton","can_reply":false}]

I’m mostly just trying to deal with that right now.”\n\nSo today in class we talked about Twilight and every single woman who spoke up in class, except my teacher, talked about how they want a man to protect them and all that stuff. The general consensus seemed to be that all other women feel that way as well.\n\nI wish I could say I proved them wrong but I couldn’t speak through the rage bubbling up in my chest. At that moment I was so aware of how alone I was. A woman with rage issues. An woman who is a loner. A singe Bi woman not looking for romance, marriage, or kids ever. A woman who has never dreamed a Cinderella dream of prince charming. A woman who wants to be prince charming.\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nI went out behind the gym after class and kicked the wall till I felt better. It’s things like this that make me never want to talk to women I don’t know. It’s things like this that make me wish I weren’t a woman. I’ve never had a sexist comment from a male class mate or teacher, never. I know it happens but not to me. Most conversations I have with women have one or two.\n\nWhat can I make of this? Go elsewhere.” Where am I supposed to go?\n\nAre there women like me? time","dysphoric","trans","ftm","self","queer"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z1WB6y1Qb4jJs","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":14,"caption":"Working on my body positivity","image_permalink":"http://princeofbellehair.tumblr.com/image/97258755318","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_1280.jpg"},{"width":422,"height":750,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_500.jpg"},{"width":338,"height":600,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_400.jpg"},{"width":225,"height":400,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":178,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":720,"height":1280,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/6cc8c3a1b5297279a0c30e24a0a82399/tumblr_nbrhl1EO6Q1qe2heso1_1280.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"popculturecatchall","id":97258655108,"post_url":"http://popculturecatchall.tumblr.com/post/97258655108/ive-been-working-on-my-voice-when-i-remember-in","slug":"ive-been-working-on-my-voice-when-i-remember-in","type":"text","date":"2014-09-12 00:04:01 GMT","timestamp":1410480241,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"yhiC0Ju7","tags":["trans","transgender","affectation","presentation","trans women","i had a metaphor i wanted to work in but it didn't fit within the flow so i left it out","for another time i guess"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-CYhu1Qb4Ks4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"I’ve been working on my voice, when I remember, in my car. I sit there for the thirty minutes or so of my commute and talk to myself. In fact, a sort of first draft, an oral version, of what I’m about to write came from today’s monologue.\n\nIt’s feels very strange and I feel very silly talking to myself the whole way home. When I pull up to a stoplight, or the traffic slows so that people can see clearly into my car, I stop talking and go into my pod people routine—you know, emotionless so no one suspects you haven’t been taken. All of this is enough to make it difficult to even practice. But it’s not really the most difficult part. I mean, who really gives a fuck if some stranger sees me talking to myself? Besides, they probably just think I have a phone on speaker or am a weirdo—either of which is fine.\n\nNo, the difficult part is hearing myself. Not because it’s bad, though sometimes it is. Mostly I can do a pretty good female sounding voice. I’ve always had a knack for altering my speech patterns and accents and impersonations—too much time watching SNL growing up or something. I can do a girl voice. And a lot of times it sounds natural and good and exactly how I desire (basically equally adept at talking about postmodern fiction and some dumb reality show on MTV).\n\nBut it is not me. Not yet. It is an affectation. A put on. An act. And sure, that’s to be expected. With practice it should become easier and more natural. And really what the fuck, right. I mean, of course it is an affectation—I need to affect this voice before I can have this voice. I’m not going to wake up sounding how I want tomorrow (though that would lead to some questions for my students if I did).\n\nSo why was I so hung up on this? Why was I so ashamed by the simple fact that I was trying? Red Durkin had a great post on this the other day too, about actively trying to not do things that would be construed as trying to pass and just the messed up head space you’re in when you try to navigate all this. It’s all this internalized transmisogyny and how it leads to these totally skewed thought processes. If I am trying to be a woman then I am not really a woman because women don’t have to try to be women, you think yourself into a corner.\n\nI bought a sports bra, a dress, and a belt a few weeks back. I don’t need any of them yet. The sports bra is sort of hedging against getting lucky early on and needing to hide a couple things in my male presentation. The others were a treat. I wanted girl clothes. I wanted clothes for me, because I felt fucking shitty with the coming school year and looking for shirts that were just another fucking reminder that every damn day starts with a lie to the world. But even though I don’t own any underwear, I bought the dress and the belt. Even though I wouldn’t have anything to put under it, I bought the dress. I bought it first because I felt strange as I thought about buying underwear. I couldn’t do it. It’s such a tired fucking cliche, the women’s underwear. And it felt like a confirmation of all the shitty stuff people say about trans women, that we’re just doing it for the thrills, that I needed to actively avoid it even though ABSOLUTELY NO ONE WILL KNOW WHAT I AM BUYING! And here’s a thing: women buy underwear every fucking day. It’s one of those things that literally everyone needs to do.\n\nI could buy the sports bra, because that I could legitimize in my mind as being utilitarian. It serves a purpose. I may need it in order to continue to look male.\n\nReread that last sentence. That one is the key here.\n\nMy everyday voice, my masculine voice, is a total fucking affectation. It is one that was gained through hours and hours of practice. Just in this case it was all unconscious. It was steered there by all the expectations and pressures that come with wanting to not be read as trans. It is just as constructed as my fem voice will be. Even what my voice is shifts throughout the day—as a teacher who talks in front of crowds a lot, I actively consider my voice and alter my speaking patterns all the fucking time. But when I don’t challenge the masculine assumption, when I don’t invite the criticism of the patriarchal response to a fem voice that resides in my own head, then it is assumed to be “authentic” or “natural.”\n\nIt is all presentation and it is all authentic. But when we look at how women affect their presentation suddenly it becomes artificial. We roundly criticize the use of make-up in our culture—think of all the stupid shit people say about liking a girl who doesn’t wear make-up—as being false. We value the honesty of a “natural” look. We also criticize those who reject this. Every paparazzi photo of a women without make-up ought to just read “What will the menz think when they see your face!” Women must present themselves for the male gaze, but still maintain the respectable standards men set. And of course make-up is for men, as every makeover special reminds us—however will you find a man if you don’t look pretty! Make-up couldn’t be for self-expression, or to attract women, or to feel confident in yourself. All these same little thoughts can be put there for voice, dress, whatever. And we could extend the logic along the axis of race instead of gender and see how the culture paints people of color as putting more effort into their appearance than white people. The dominant structure claims it is real and authentic and therefore all others should act either in aspiration or response. But that’s bullshit. It’s all a fucking act, and it’s all real.\n\nAnd by all, I mean all. That includes the slob dudes in their ratty t-shirts. That is an affectation—they are telling the world exactly what they do and do not care for. My brother was telling me once how he liked shopping at Costco because there’s no design, it’s barebones and because of that he knew their full focus was on just getting the job done. The Costco, in other words, was dressed like him. Plain jeans and a t-shirt, just going to work. It’s not as if Costco could have contemplated the look of their stores and considered the effect of design and decided that this exact look would convey the exact message my brother received. No, design was an unnecessary detail only. Ornamentation. All that frilly crap. But that’s a false dichotomy. It’s all design, and it is all an act. Sometimes it’s conscious, as with my voice, and sometimes it’s unconscious, as with my brother’s jeans and tee look.\n\nSo fuck those who tell you you are anything but real or try to tell you how you are unnatural. We are all natural and real and fake and artificial in equal measure. Trans women have just as much right to try on a look or a voice or anything as anyone else. Giving effort is not a sign of a lack of substance. It does not compromise our identity.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"anemicroyaltee","id":97258321912,"post_url":"http://anemicroyaltee.tumblr.com/post/97258321912/tomorrow-i-think-im-going-to-wear-my-lgbt-pride","slug":"tomorrow-i-think-im-going-to-wear-my-lgbt-pride","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 23:59:31 GMT","timestamp":1410479971,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"xd9nIzvA","tags":["lgbt","lgbt pride","gay","trans","transsexual"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZbrnCt1Qb33Vu","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"tomorrow i think im going to wear my LGBT pride shirt as a way of SLOWLY coming out. i hope no one says anything negative.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbtqblogs","id":97258300659,"post_url":"http://lgbtqblogs.tumblr.com/post/97258300659/we-need-a-national-conversation-about","slug":"we-need-a-national-conversation-about","type":"quote","date":"2014-09-11 23:59:12 GMT","timestamp":1410479952,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"L3HnTJBH","tags":["trans","transgender","trans*","lgbtq","lgbtq news","lgbt","lgbtq current events","lgbtqia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBCnOy1Qb2_Jp","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":153,"text":"We need a national conversation about transphobia, which dehumanizes, demeans and disadvantages a specific group of people. Wait - WHAT?!?!?! How the FUCK can a fucking LESBIAN be in a happy romantic relationship with a MAN?!?!?!?! The answer is simple: her lesbianism is mostly physical. She is sexually attracted to her husband's female genitalia. For that reason, he is not going to change his sexual organs. He may undergo hormonal therapy, but his organs will remain untouched as long as they are married, in order to accommodate her lesbianism. He is no less of a (trans)man for possessing and keeping his female genitalia, and she is no less of a lesbian for being in love with a (trans)man.","body":"Oh, and they are conservative Christians who believe that sexual activity should only happen within a marriage. \n\nFuck you transphobes (such as Onision) who would deprive this young couple of their joy, and fuck you LGBTQA activists who would deprive them of their identities. \n\nFuck the rest of you, who would condemn this couple for practising conservative Christian sexual morality. \n\nFuck all of you hypocrites.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"blakestransition","id":97257865340,"post_url":"http://blakestransition.tumblr.com/post/97257865340/day-six","slug":"day-six","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 23:53:00 GMT","timestamp":1410479580,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"bqqA7Un2","tags":["trans","transgender","transition","blake's transition","ftm","female to male","coming out","gay"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZqhoZm1Qb1K1y","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"Day Six","body":"I still haven’t talked to my mom about my coming out six days ago. I was an absolute fool to have some in the first place.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"elliottdeline","id":97257621909,"post_url":"http://elliottdeline.com/post/97257621909/life-update-from-wegmans-cafe","slug":"life-update-from-wegmans-cafe","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 23:49:45 GMT","timestamp":1410479385,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"4r7e7dbs","tags":["trans","transgender","ftm","queer","genderqueer","nonbinary","aspie","aspie problems","show trans","elliott deline","on a personal note"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZyKqew1Qb0OcL","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"Life update from Wegmans cafe","body":"I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed. I was asked to write a Syracuse Peace Newsletter article by Monday, and on top of that, Show Trans needs to be ready to go out to pre-orderers and reviewers around the same time. Joey is helping me to format and insert some images that I think really make the book. Screen-caps from awful grindr conversations, for instance, which some of my older followers may remember. I’m really excited about this book. Have I mentioned that? I’m excited about the article too, but man, deadlines stress me. \n\nI’m also figuring out book readings and other possible money-making schemes. I have secured one college gig at SUNY Fredonia. So that’s good. \n\nI’m also going through the hassle of figuring out how I’ll get my hormones now that I’m on Medicaid and not my dad’s insurance. And I need to figure out food stamps. Ugh. I hate this kind of shit. \n\nBut otherwise, life is pretty good. My partner is in the midst of a (unnecessarily) stressful divorce, and that sometimes drains us both. But such is life. I’ve got a home, I’ve got a good man, and I’ve got two adorable new kitties. I can’t complain. Well, I can, and I still do. But I’m doing well. \n\nI have noticed that my social anxiety is getting pretty wretched again. Oh, and I may have a wheat intolerance. I’ve felt a lot better since I cut it out of my diet. I suggest trying it if you are often nauseated and sluggish after eating and have joint pain. Holyoke.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"theartoftransliness","id":97256957948,"post_url":"http://theartoftransliness.com/post/97256957948/almost-every-time-i-do-think-or-say-something-i","slug":"almost-every-time-i-do-think-or-say-something-i","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-11 23:40:36 GMT","timestamp":1410478836,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"nJCPePCt","tags":["social dysphoria","trans","gender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZXo_lx1QazsVy","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":42,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Almost every time I do, think, or say something I always then think \"that was too feminine\" or \"that's what a girl would say/think/do\" and I hate thinking those things. Do you have any suggestions for how to stop feeling that way? The only way I really ever stop feeling like that is when I'm trying hard to be masculine.","answer":"Zak: I feel that way a lot. I don’t really have an answer for how to make it better, although one major thing that has helped me is just paying attention to other guys and realizing that there isn’t one set standard for masculinity. Yeah, I might cross my legs in a way that I feel is too feminine, but there are also plenty of other guys out there who cross their legs that way (or gesture when they talk, or call things “adorable,” or whatever). Some of it is just self-acceptance. I’ve kind of come to terms with the fact that I’m not a super masculine guy and I’ll probably never be one. This self-policing is pretty common, though, I think. We feel like we need to prove/justify our genders to the rest of the world, and even to ourselves. Ideally, though, we should just be able to be ourselves without having to worry about it.\n\nTrans guys aren’t the only ones carefully policing their genders and worrying about this stuff, I’ve met plenty of cis guys who are also concerned about coming off as too feminine. It’s practically an epidemic. So, I’d say try to find a way to accept the more feminine things about yourself and relax about it. Easier said than done, I know, but that’s really all I have to recommend.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"officiallyblake","id":97256821094,"post_url":"http://officiallyblake.tumblr.com/post/97256821094/2003-vs-2014-age-6-vs-17-ive-come-a-long-way","slug":"2003-vs-2014-age-6-vs-17-ive-come-a-long-way","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 23:38:41 GMT","timestamp":1410478721,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"zBwUACjk","tags":["me","trans","transgender","trans man","transman","trans boy","transboy","transmale","trans male","transguy","trans guy","ftm","ftm transgender","male"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZjTYim1QazL5c","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":15,"caption":"2003 vs. 2014. age 6 vs. 17. Members of our community are homosexual, bisexual, heterosexual, pansexual, asexual, and anything else you can or cannot think of. And we all stand or fall together.","can_reply":false}]

[{"blog_name":"forevertestosteronemofo","id":97251401997,"post_url":"http://forevertestosteronemofo.tumblr.com/post/97251401997/i-was-getting-tired-of-people-misgendering-me","slug":"i-was-getting-tired-of-people-misgendering-me","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 22:24:41 GMT","timestamp":1410474281,"state":"published","format":"markdown","reblog_key":"Fzbf5fCg","tags":["ftm","trans","transgender","misgendering"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zd9p8t1Qaeg4D","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"title":"","body":"i was getting tired of people misgendering me. today i finally told someone that i was a boy, and that i wasn’t a girl. she responded with “how?”. when i told her i was trans and explained what that was, she said “so you’re still a girl”. i told her i wasn’t, and then she asked me what my “real name” was. when i told her it was Riley, she refused to use he/him/his pronouns, and refused to let go of the fact that Riley “wasn’t my name” and that i “wasn’t a boy”\n\nthen she proceeded to tell me that she doesn’t judge anybody and respects people. no. just… no.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"bigbadbaeddelborgs","id":97251295040,"post_url":"http://bigbadbaeddelborgs.tumblr.com/post/97251295040/manhood-trans-men-are-suspicious-when-you-have","slug":"manhood-trans-men-are-suspicious-when-you-have","type":"quote","date":"2014-09-11 22:23:17 GMT","timestamp":1410474197,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"O53r9CPd","tags":["transmasculine","trans men","ftm","trans","feminism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zg3ham1QaeFz0","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"text":"Manhood\n\nTrans men are suspicious. When you have trans men, a population marginalised both for being trans and for having experienced a semi-marginalised status from their assignment at birth, the shocking incidence of misogyny, transmisogyny, MRA-esque bullshittery, “truscummery”, a much higher rate of heterosexuality than trans women3 (55% versus 27%) – which is, especially male heterosexuality, a patriarchal institution – and general chauvinistic grotesqueness, I can’t help but start to question this state of affairs. What’s causing this? Bigotry is so much more endemic in trans men’s communities than should be expected of similarly marginalised groups. There’s definitely something going on, and I’m not intellectually lazy enough to presume mere accident.\n\nJust like there’s no such thing as a non-exploitative bourgeoisie, there’s no such thing as a non-sexist man, so how exactly do you sit down and think about gender then reach the conclusion that misogyny and exploiting women is the thing for you? Trans maleness, by definition, means overt identification with manhood and the decision to join the ranks of the patriarchs. The political and social signals that “moving into manhood” sends are not desirable at all. Having been on the receiving end of manhood from birth, cis men aren’t moving into it like trans men are, and are maybe not by necessity as active a participant in maleness as them.\n\nThe trans men who feel bodily dysphoria should absolutely and in no way be denied any opportunity to get that fixed (I understand that pain all too well), but critical self-examination is still required, manhood is still fundamentally and irredeemably a reactionary identity and social position. Does fixing bodily dysphoria require active identification with maleness? I don’t think so, and I don’t think that someone wanting to move into that space should be entirely trusted either.\n\nIt’s highly hypocritical on the part of trans activists to at once state that social conditions (transphobia, transmisogyny) are a deterrent to transition, but in the same breath say that social conditions (male privilege, for trans men) aren’t an incentive to transition. Trans men, upon transition, get a pay rise,4 after all.\n\nThe only progressive way forward is for men – cis and trans alike – to strive to give up manhood, to abdicate their patriarchal throne. To consciously decide to fight sexism at every opportunity and to disassociate as much as possible from their privileged position, masculinity, and exploitation of women. To try and undermine their own social position at every turn. Progressive men should stop trying to envision a “better” manhood or a “better” masculinity; men hurt themselves, other men, women, and non-men when they assert their masculinity, and they should stop trying to imagine ways to redeem themselves without fundamental change.\n\nJust like I strive to give up and end my position and the category of first world labour aristocrat, my position of whiteness, and my position of physical abledness, I call on men to strive to give up manhood. It doesn’t mean I shrug off the label “white” or “labour aristocrat”, just the positioning of those identities as good, or at worst neutral. It means that I recognise that they are fundamentally oppressive social positions and that the only possible use for them are as political organising labels and for the recognition of my own privilege.\n\nThe call for the abolishment of gender isn’t quite correct, or at least requires a bit more nuance and elaboration. Women and men are not the problem, to be abolished on equal terms, it’s men who are the main problem. That’s where we need to focus our energy. You don’t abolish classes by trying to abolish the proletariat and the bourgeoisie both together, no, you focus on the bourgeoisie. You focus on the exploiters and the dominant class in the dialectic – you abolish men first and foremost.\n\nWomanhood\n\nWomanhood and manhood are defined by their existence through each other and their violent struggle against one another. You can’t have one without the other, a contradiction (and an antagonistic one at that) in dialectics parlance. One is the struggle of the oppressed and one the struggle of the oppressor. It’s for this reason that a trans woman identifying with womanhood is fundamentally different from a trans man identifying with manhood. One is the reflexive cry of the downtrodden, and the other can be an angry request to be let into the exploiter clubhouse.\n\nWhen I say “I’m a woman” I’m not saying I innately “feel like a woman” (I don’t think you can ever construct a non-patirarchal justification for that), I’m instead relating myself to other women and our shared experience as a class under patriarchy. I’m stating that my material interests and experience of the world are aligned with womanhood; my liberation is therefore fundamentally and intimately bound up with other women, and thus as far as I’m concerned, “woman” describes me.\n\nI “identify” with womanhood because it describes my political experience. It’s the category, or near enough (“genderfreakhood” is also pertinent), that is imposed on me. Like the other oppressive social constructs – blackness or queerness for example – identification with them isn’t reification, but a recognition of the political and social reality of other’s reification of the concept.\n\nMy birth designation doesn’t matter. When I’m walking down the street, people gender me as “not male”, as a woman, and it makes me uneasy. When people spew biotruths or make sexist jokes, I know it’s aimed at me. When I see women objectified over and over and over again, I can’t help but learn to hate myself. When I hear about rampant rape, sexual assault, and general violence, I wonder, might I become one of those statistics? Even before I transitioned and started changing my body, the sexism I encountered was still generally aimed at people of a body type I needed for my health. Whenever I interact with a man there’s always a nagging in the back of my mind, how are gender relations coloring this interaction? Again and again, I constantly face misogyny – I face womanhood.\n\nIt’s for this reason there are little points of unity between trans men/some CAFAB gendequeers (those who benefit from transmisogyny) and trans women/those who face transmisgoyny. I have a lot more in common with cis women than I do the majority of trans men. When CAFAB trans people talk about their relationship to “trans” and “gender”, it’s quite often in a decidedly “non-political” or non-radical manner. This isn’t how I feel about being a woman, my womanhood is strictly political.\n\nFor many trans men their transness is some kind of “subversive” gender performance, some sort of flight of fancy (to put it perhaps a little crudely). They adopt “he/his” pronouns and change their haircut and clothing in a limited capacity, and then just go on with their lives, coming first in the oppression olympics, winning various book deals, getting a multitude of spoken word performance awards, and so on, all on the backs of trans women (mostly of color).","source":"Trans People and the Dialectics of Sex and Gender: Against Radical and Liberal Feminism","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"pagingmisspage","id":97250650553,"post_url":"http://pagingmisspage.tumblr.com/post/97250650553/at-a-car-dealership-up-in-ocala-shooting-a-spot","slug":"at-a-car-dealership-up-in-ocala-shooting-a-spot","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 22:14:33 GMT","timestamp":1410473673,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"1Hcs4M5X","tags":["transgender","trans","dmab","amab","maab","mtf","male to female","transition","daily life of a trans woman"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZP9ewn1Qabocv","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":7,"caption":"At a car dealership up in Ocala shooting a spot for a news business program. The outfit, not the ouchie. But I did get “ma’am” and since I took my girlfriend as my assistant, we got “ladies” a date":"2014-09-11 22:06:40 GMT","timestamp":1410473200,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"ydNp9Pu5","tags":["trans","transgender","transmale","transman"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z7fOEx1QaZUk6","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"Little things with transitioning","body":"So, as a newly transitioning trans-male, it’s starting to become more giddy to transition. I was never allowed to get men’s body wash or deodorant because my mother does not believe a ‘woman’ like me should be using it. Now that I, and my partner, have money, we’re able to buy me things that I’ve only wished I could get for a while.\n\nI’ve had such a desensitized feeling towards women’s clothing now because of how long I had to wear them. Even though I’m a taller biological female, and have large feet (Usually a size 11.5 in women’s, USA), my mother always went out of her way to buy me women’s sneakers and such. Now that I own my very own men’s sneakers and my own socks that I didn’t have to steal from my brothers… It’s honestly nice. You would never think a person would get so emotional or happy over getting a new pair of tennis shoes or a new wallet that actually fit who they feel like.\n\nBeing able to look at your face and see more of a man through your clothing and your accessories is a life saving feeling to me. After being able to throw away all those women’s clothing, it almost feels so surreal to be able to basically not wear any female clothing or have any female accessories anymore, but in a good way.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"prudence-lana","id":97249990273,"post_url":"http://prudence-lana.tumblr.com/post/97249990273/why-i-dont-need-surgery-to-be-transgender","slug":"why-i-dont-need-surgery-to-be-transgender","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 22:05:53 GMT","timestamp":1410473153,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"reSCYmp1","tags":["mtf","trans","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z03e6n1QaZHQ1","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"title":"Why I don't need surgery to be transgender.","body":"<!-- more -->\n\nIn the year 2000, a young boy puts on his clothes and eats his lunch. He is thinking hard about himself, something he’ll continue to do a lot in his life. The boy turns to his mom and says “Mommy, I want to be a girl.”\n\nThe mom, being a conservative Christian at that time, says it’s not possible. So the boy grows up to 15 before these feelings show themselves consciously again.\n\nThis boy notices that through his entire life, he’s always been girlish, from his personality right down to his slender curvy build. He notices that he’s always wanted to be “one of the girls” ever since he got friends in his old town.\n\nThe boy is long gone from the suburban town where he lived as a three year old. Now he is in a big city and his parents have converted from Christianity to Atheism. So this boy, after speaking with a very special friend about what being transgender is, begins to have the thought: “What if I’m just masquerading as a boy?”\n\nIn that moment, it dawned on her. She is a girl. She never expected it coming, but she could feel the glass defog and she saw herself clearly. This is what her identity was missing. This is why she felt incomplete before. Because she was born without the right equipment.\n\nHer friends and family were mainly supportive and she is extremely thankful for that. But one surgery she gets asked often is, “Are you going to get surgery?”\n\nNow, at first she dodged this question by saying she didn’t know. But she did heavily consider it. When she factored in all the money, time, and effort that this surgery would take, she knew that she would be completely happy with a penis.\n\nSome people tell her “You aren’t trans unless you are transitioning!” but they don’t understand that she is transitioning. Her identity as presented to other people is transitioning. The parent-son relationship she once had with her parents is changing into a parent-daughter one. Her life is transitioning from how she used to live, to how she truly wants to live.\n\nSo yes, she is transitioning everything except the physical aspects. And that’s her choice. It makes her no less of a woman than any other woman on Earth. She is an MtF transgender person.\n\nNow it’s 2014, and she is happily living as a girl. She has been fully accepted by her parents and all of her friends support her. A few still misgender or use her old name, but it happens so rarely (and almost always accidental) that she doesn’t even get upset anymore. She is finally secure with herself.\n\nI hope you have all learned something from my experience and have a lovely day~","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"birolesmantic","id":97249715521,"post_url":"http://birolesmantic.tumblr.com/post/97249715521/alex-queerture-zazzle-com-store","slug":"alex-queerture-zazzle-com-store","type":"link","date":"2014-09-11 This just keeps popping up over and over in my travels! “She-man” is a 20th century slur against… Wait for it… GAY MALES! “But a lot of trans women say it’s a slur against them and therefore gay men aren’t allowed to reclaim it!?” Nope! It’s a slur that can be used, and in fact had its origin, against gay men also. [{"blog_name":"k-con","id":97245099012,"post_url":"http://k-con.tumblr.com/post/97245099012/do-you-have-sensation-in-your-nipples-i-had-peri-but","slug":"do-you-have-sensation-in-your-nipples-i-had-peri-but","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-11 21:02:00 GMT","timestamp":1410469320,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"vbeUH2bs","tags":["Top surgery","queer","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zvndbw1QaGdG4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":7,"asking_name":"mean1mrgrinch","asking_url":"http://mean1mrgrinch.tumblr.com/","question":"Do you have sensation in your nipples? I had peri but I'm curious because I was told by my surgeon it would be lost permanently with double incision.","answer":"One of my biggest fears going into surgery, aside from death, was the fact that I would permanently lose sensation in my chest. I was really afraid of waking up to a permanent state of chest numbness. Fortunately, those fears turned out to be unfounded!\n\nMy nipples don’t become erect anymore but they can seriously feel everything! It definitely feels different but for me, it’s a better different! Before surgery, my nipple sensations felt awkward and not the least bit arousing.\n\nNow, I find nipple stimulation to be quite pleasurable. My nips are totally an erogenous zone. Most sensations are brain powered anyway. For example, people with paralysis still experience erections. At this point in time, my nips might have less nerves than most, but they are still alive and full of sensation!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"teddywolfsong","id":97245081214,"post_url":"http://teddywolfsong.tumblr.com/post/97245081214/im-an-angry-vulcan-baby-trans-gay-transboy","slug":"im-an-angry-vulcan-baby-trans-gay-transboy","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 ow-long-on-t-did-it-take-for","type":"audio","date":"2014-09-11 20:35:00 GMT","timestamp":1410467700,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"ZZY9DRLI","tags":["Testosterone","queer","trans","ftm"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zvndbw1Qa8VDB","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"caption":"Anonymous said:\n\nHow long on T did it take for your voice to drop? How much did it drop, and can you still reach your higher register?\n\nGood question! \n\nWithin a couple days of starting Testosterone I developed a cold. From that point on, my voice changed. It didn’t necessarily sound deeper, it was just different. Listening to old recordings, I’d say my voice started sounding noticeably deeper around 6 months on Testosterone.\n\nAt this point, I can’t reach the higher registers that I once could… but my voice is still pretty high, considering. I’ve included a clip of my voice today, for future reference. I’ve got a cold so I sound a lot more nasally than usual.\n\nAccording to the Endocrine Society’s Clinical Guidelines for the Treatment of Transsexual Persons, the voice starts deepening around 6-12 months. The Endocrine Society has a timeline of the “Masculinizing effects in FTM transsexual persons,” which I’ve opted to include below. \n\nHope this helps!","player":"<embed type=\"application/x-shockwave-flash\" src=\"http://assets.tumblr.com/swf/audio_player.swf?audio_file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tumblr.com%2Faudio_file%2Fk-con%2F97242968907%2Ftumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo&color=FFFFFF\" height=\"27\" width=\"207\" quality=\"best\" wmode=\"opaque\"></embed>","embed":"<iframe class=\"tumblr_audio_player tumblr_audio_player_97242968907\" src=\"http://k-con.tumblr.com/post/97242968907/audio_player_iframe/k-con/tumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo?audio_file=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tumblr.com%2Faudio_file%2Fk-con%2F97242968907%2Ftumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo\" frameborder=\"0\" allowtransparency=\"true\" scrolling=\"no\" width=\"500\" height=\"85\"></iframe>","plays":100,"audio_url":"https://www.tumblr.com/audio_file/k-con/97242968907/tumblr_nbr7ugEtkx1r65qdo","audio_type":"tumblr","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"brandonrandy","id":97242973030,"post_url":"http://brandonrandy.tumblr.com/post/97242973030/top-surgery-thoughts","slug":"top-surgery-thoughts","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 20:35:04 GMT","timestamp":1410467704,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"8glCqSiB","tags":["ftm","top surgery","garramone","transgender","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zty5Gt1Qa8WDc","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"Top Surgery Thoughts","body":"When I first began my transition I paged through top surgery results and always seemed to land on the same doctor, Garramone. Every time I would see a guy’s chest that I had thought had come out particularly well they had always gone to him. So, it seemed an obvious choice once I found out he was only a couple hours from where I lived. How convenient is that?\n\nI’ve been spending the last fifteen months saving money for surgery, and at this point, I have about a third of it ready to go. That’s enough to at least book. To pick a date, and get myself prepared/save the rest of the money.\n\nBut for some reason, I haven’t made the call. I can’t really explain it. I don’t have a particular reason. I guess maybe there’s this part of me that just cannot imagine that I am about to spend this much money. I’m not really the type to buy big ticket items for myself. I see this price tag in my head as a new car, a down payment on a modest house, a way to invest in the future.\n\nI keep thinking, what if I hold out a little longer? Maybe I could get medical insurance that will cover my surgeries. Then, I start thinking about the process of waiting for that kind of approval, finding a new doctor, possibly ending up with horrible results. It’s a lot to reconsider on a timeline that may or may not even exist as a possibility. There’s no guarantee insurance will ever cover transgender surgeries.\n\nThere’s the picking a new doctor aspect of it to- I mean, who’s to even say I made the “right” choice, no one is flawless. Dr. G does great work, obviously, but there’s this part of me that knows I only get one shot at this. If something doesn’t heal quite right it doesn’t look like he’s much into revisions unless you’re ready to shell out another $8,000. But who’s stuff is better and within such a close distance to my current location? No one as far as I know.\n\nAs many concerns as I have regarding the surgery itself, anesthesia, pain, everything- overall, if it weren’t for the money this would already be done. So that line of thinking leaves me wondering- now that it looks like saving this money may be possible, what ultimately is keeping me from making this call? Why do I feel so guilty about doing something I know will make me a happier and more well-adjusted person?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"bumpulp","id":97242796456,"post_url":"http://bumpulp.tumblr.com/post/97242796456/i-always-think-i-have-my-shit-so-figured-out-and","slug":"i-always-think-i-have-my-shit-so-figured-out-and","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 20:32:49 GMT","timestamp":1410467569,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Gm1H41WV","tags":["i need help","what is self acceptance even","trans","help me","suicide tw","self harm tw","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zi2Mom1Qa7r6e","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"I always think I have my shit so figured out and I’m soo comfortable with who I am but i think actually\n\nI’ve just learned how to be comfortable being male and I never learned how to be comfortable with being trans and that might be like an important thing to do maybe but I don’t know how??\n\nbecause actually i’m still like how do i do the trans thing without killing/hurting myself???\n\nand like i’m pretty sure I dont want to kill myself buuut","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"atlasvertebra","id":97242549074,"post_url":"http://atlasvertebra.tumblr.com/post/97242549074/more-ugh-i-dunno-actually-blogging-makes-me","slug":"more-ugh-i-dunno-actually-blogging-makes-me","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 20:29:36 GMT","timestamp":1410467376,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"gfdePrqj","tags":["trans","dysphoria"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-xiZm1Qa6ujI","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"<!-- more -->\n\nugh I dunno, actually blogging makes me feel a bit better, having somewhere to go with my love of the stuff I blog about and my trans and asperger’s feelings\n\nbecause, like…. Not that there’s anything wrong with being feminine, but ehhhh???\n\nWhen friends I’m out to continually misgender me or try to reassure me that my female body/other female characteristics are great and wonderful and I’m like ??? please don’t, I hate them.\n\nI feel often like I’m competing somehow. IDAHOT 2014 Reports","url":"http://www.transviolencetracker.org/index.php/articles/87-tvtp-reports/91-tvtp-idahot-2014-reports","description":"IDAHOT Reports on Transphobia","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbtqblogs","id":97240681216,"post_url":"http://lgbtqblogs.tumblr.com/post/97240681216/angelica-ross-the-dynamic-entrepreneur-who","slug":"angelica-ross-the-dynamic-entrepreneur-who","type":"video","date":"2014-09-11 20:04:55 GMT","timestamp":1410465895,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"H8yi8K1P","tags":["trans","transgender","trans*","lgbtq","lgbtq news","lgbt","lgbtq current events","lgbtqia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBCnOy1QZ-mi0","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":94,"caption":"Angelica Ross — the dynamic entrepreneur who recently founded Chicago-based nonprofit TransTech — has personally seen the best and worst of what a transgender person can face on the job market.\n\nThat’s why she started TransTech, which will offer a training academy and apprenticeships for aspiring trans web developers and graphic designers this Fall.\n\n\"TransTech emerged from my story, [which] is the same story for so many trans women of color,\" Ross tells The Advocate. “When I began my transition, I was fired from my job, estranged from my family, and introduced to sex work and the adult industry.”\n\nSoon the technologically-inclined Ross decided to teach herself web coding and graphic design, and was able to become successfully self-employed as a freelancer.\n\n\"Over the course of 10 years … I discovered technology as a path to independence for trans people. I no longer had to face on-the-job discrimination and harassment if I didn’t want to,\" she explained. \"I could log-in and make money without people caring about what I look or sound like.\"\n\nHer experiences with Internet freelancing, as an Apple employee, and a stint in beauty school planted the seed for TransTech, which is now becoming a reality through help from an Indiegogo fundraiser.\n\n\"It is my mission to make TransTech the Apple of the nonprofit industry!\" Ross says.\n\nMore specifically, the project’s ultimate goal is to empower trans attendees to become self-employed independent contractors in the tech industry. Apprentices will accomplish this by practicing their skills in a training setting, similar to beauty school students. Customers will pay an affordable rate for web and graphic design, and apprentices will be able to earn income; any extra profit will be used by TransTech to continue the next cycle of apprenticeships.\n\nRoss says tht the program’s unique setup came to her after she began observing other employment programs in Chicago. “[They] were focusing heavily on training people for food service jobs or manual labor jobs,” she recalls. “The attitude was that tech skills would be over-the-heads of the populations typically served by social services. But I knew for a fact this wasn’t true, and I set out to prove it.”\n\nTech skills are, Ross believes, going to be increasingly in-demand in our tech-savvy world. She hopes TransTech will set its participants up for “economic improvement,” and help ease the “extreme levels of poverty, discrimination, harassment, and violence towards the trans community, especially trans women of color.”\n\nShe refers to this approach as “social enterprise:” the maximization of both individual and community well-being, rather than profit. In the video below, she beams with confidence at how needed a program like TransTech is at a time like this. Trans community advocates — including Trans*H4CK founder Dr. Kortney Ryan Ziegler, coder Naomi Ceder, and GLAAD Media Strategist Tiq Milan — have agreed, coming out on social media in vocal support of the nonprofit.\n\nRoss’ only lament so far, she says, is her inability to do more. “We have received roughly 30 applications and they are still pouring in; my email and phone are bombarded by hopeful apprentices,” she tells The Advocate. “But we can only afford to enroll 2 people [in the first session], which breaks my heart.”\n\n\"That’s why,\" she concludes, \"even though we are only looking to raise $15,000 to get us through the first 12-week apprenticeship, I am hoping the rest of the community understands how much of a difference TransTech can make in the lives of trans people and the LGBT community as a whole.\"\n\n\"The more money we raise, the more trans people we can enroll, pay, and set on the path to independence.\"","permalink_url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MAkIrmcgMoY","html5_capable":true,"thumbnail_url":"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MAkIrmcgMoY/hqdefault.jpg","thumbnail_width":480,"thumbnail_height":360,"player":[{"width":250,"embed_code":"<iframe I don’t use the stp part of my packer so i can just take out the tubing and use it as a packer!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"returnthegayze","id":97238777931,"post_url":"http://www.returnthegayze.com/post/97238777931/excited-to-announce-that-we-will-be-performing-at","slug":"excited-to-announce-that-we-will-be-performing-at","type":"video","date":"2014-09-11 19:39:22 GMT","timestamp":1410464362,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"u4srX26q","tags":["darkmatterrage","lamama","performance","queer","trans","southasia","desi","india","poetry"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zeieis1QZuW1B","followed":false,"post_author":"queerlibido","highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":19,"caption":"Excited to announce that we will be performing at the International Queer Arts Festival in New York City. Get your tickets before they sell out, but in the mean time watch this interview about the upcoming show.","permalink_url":"https://vimeo.com/105792338","html5_capable":true,"thumbnail_url":"https://i.vimeocdn.com/video/488836877_295x166.jpg","thumbnail_width":295,"thumbnail_height":166,"player":[{"width":250,"embed_code":"<iframe src=\"//player.vimeo.com/video/105792338?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0\" width=\"250\" height=\"140\" frameborder=\"0\" title=\"DarkMatter\" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>"},{"width":400,"embed_code":"<iframe src=\"//player.vimeo.com/video/105792338?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0\" width=\"400\" height=\"224\" frameborder=\"0\" title=\"DarkMatter\" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>"},{"width":500,"embed_code":"<iframe src=\"//player.vimeo.com/video/105792338?title=0&byline=0&portrait=0\" width=\"500\" height=\"281\" frameborder=\"0\" title=\"DarkMatter\" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>"}],"video_type":"vimeo","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"brutereason","id":97238580773,"post_url":"http://brutereason.tumblr.com/post/97238580773/ben-barres-is-a-biologist-at-stanford-who-lived","slug":"ben-barres-is-a-biologist-at-stanford-who-lived","type":"quote","date":"2014-09-11 19:36:37 GMT","timestamp":1410464197,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"OOuQBkcJ","tags":["trans","lgbtq","men","women","gender","work","sexism","bias"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z_X7Rx1QZtlub","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"bookmarklet":true,"note_count":277,"source_url":"http://www.newrepublic.com/article/119239/transgender-people-can-explain-why-women-dont-advance-work","source_title":"newrepublic.com","text":"Ben Barres is a biologist at Stanford who lived and worked as Barbara Barres until he was in his forties. For most of his career, he experienced bias, but didn’t give much weight to it—seeing incidents as discrete events. (When he solved a tough math problem, for example, a professor said, “You must have had your boyfriend solve it.”) When he became Ben, however, he immediately noticed a difference in his everyday experience: “People who don’t know I am transgendered treat me with much more respect,” he says. He was more carefully listened to and his authority less frequently questioned. He stopped being interrupted in meetings. At one conference, another scientist said, “Ben gave a great seminar today—but then his work is so much better than his sister’s.” (The scientist didn’t know Ben and Barbara were the same person.) “This is why women are not breaking into academic jobs at any appreciable rate,” he wrote in response to Larry Summers’s famous gaffe implying women were less innately capable at the hard sciences. “Not childcare.
