18:08:00 GMT","timestamp":1410458880,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"MmZOKcSj","tags":["radfem","trans","TERF","libfem","feminism","women","gender","What is"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z6gxtx1QZXmxS","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":55,"title":"What is: To feel like a woman or a man","body":"Regarding why trans people say things like:\n\nI have always felt like a woman\nor\nI have always felt like a man\nor\nI have always felt like I am not a woman or a man\nor\nI have always felt like a woman and a man\n\nor similar expressions of such, what they are trying to express in colloquial and layman’s terms is the concepts of sex identity and gender identity.\n\nNow that is Two (2) concepts, each distinct, heavily conflated, because in layman’s and colloquial terms, they are readily intertwined and intermingled in actual life. \n\nRoughly translated, the whole thing means that a Trans person is aware that they are a woman, man, both, or neither, at the same core level as they are aware of themselves as a person, distinct from other people.\n\nSome people, primarily those who are ignorant and misinformed of what these concepts are, or who apply their own prejudice towards trans people and thereby discount 60+ years of proven science, would prefer to argue that what this is suggesting is that there is a “brain sex” — and yet, that’s not what this is describing.\n\nIt is describing a sense of self-awareness — which, while decidedly part of the brain’s physiology, is really part of the existential notion that one exists, and therefore is not part of that argument, nor even related directly to biological systems.\n\nThis is important to note, because what it means is that when someone talks to or about a trans person about this and says things like “do you mean it is about clothing, or about sexual intercourse, or about physiological process or genitals” or similar stuff, they are being fundamentally dishonest and deceitful, and displaying their ignorance and incompetence because they do not understand what the trans person is saying to them, and therefore not listening, and so are talking about something other than the actual concept being discussed.\n\nThese questions are a form of gaslighting of trans people, and seeks to corrupt and twist the words of trans people for the purpose of furthering their oppression, not proving something “true” about trans people, since they have nothing to do with the idea being expressed, which is that the trans person exists.\n\nFurthermore, if these people do not, themselves, have the ability to say what it means to them to feel like a woman, it is incredibly difficult for them to be honestly making a judgement about someone else’s understanding of themselves.\n\nThis is like looking at a person and telling them they are actually a dog, and they know they are a dog, but not willing to admit it. Seems pretty nasty, doesn’t it?\n\nTrans people are not immune to this — and indeed, often when pushed, trans people will resort to all manner of reactions and arguments and justifications for this because they often are no more knowledgeable about this than anyone else.\n\nWhat that means, as well, is that this description has nothing whatsoever to do with biology, and therefore arguments about biology aren’t valid when contradicting it.\n\nIt would be akin to saying that the United States Army shouldn’t exist because of broccoli.\n\nThis all comes together in the core aspect here: like sexual orientation, this is part of what creates the sense of self in people, and it therefore is part of how they know that they exist as an individual human being, and is a part of that.\n\nSo the same question of how you know can be answered in as many different ways as there are people, and it is the still same way that those asking the question know what their social sex identity is.\n\nThis effectively makes it the trans version of the question “how do you know you are gay?”, with the same accurate answer of “I just do, because I know I exist.”\n\nThe answer may not satisfy those seeking some sort of concrete answer, but it is inevitable that they themselves will discount any answer because for them the same question remains unanswered in a way they would accept from a trans person, usually due to cis privilege.\n\nSo asking the question, especially in a venue such as Tumblr, is a form of logical fallacy and a trap, meant to defame and ridicule and provide justification for hate speech and violence against trans people.\n\n  This is especially a common tactic among transphobes, who can be identified using expressions described here.\n\nDO be sure to reference the links earlier in this post, as it is a part of the What is Series.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"princesshollycollie","id":97232391671,"post_url":"http://princesshollycollie.tumblr.com/post/97232391671/sweet-light-up-halloween-shirt-from-the-thrift","slug":"sweet-light-up-halloween-shirt-from-the-thrift","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 I’m stuck in a binary mindset that I totally can’t seem to shake. It sucks because like I am totally not trying to be ignorant or hurtful. \n\nSince being out full time I have gotten the stares and the glares, but for the most part I don’t have confrontation or get misgendered… I know that I don’t have an ideal female figure coming from an hyper-masculine athletic guy being in the infantry, but I haven’t let that limit me in being me. It also helps that I was able to change my voice psychologically and it clearly passes as feminine. \n\nI still have to try to pull off male which I fail at for the army and I get gendered correctly (female) when I am trying to pull off an infantry soldier (only males) which in turn makes some people weird with me. \n\nI totally don’t know what I am ranting about anymore as I can was continually interrupted in making the post. *sigh*\n\nI guess I just wish that even though I know that the trans community is a minority in the public and in society that it wasn’t so feudal and butt hurt amongst itself as with others. Seeing things like die cis scum and transphobes or transphobia makes feel irksome amongst the community. I know that we aren’t accepted for the most part and that some of us come from cis privilege still expecting that privilege, but like sometimes you gotta just except what it is that you are giving up to be true to yourself. Like it sucks how many friends and how much family I have lost and it sucks that I continually have to face hardships not only within myself, but in public as being trans is hard, but like I don’t think that it is right to whine so hard that the world doesn’t accept you. Even if you were born cis most likely the world would seem like it is against you with every step that you take. Life is hard regardless. Trans just makes it even more harder, but once you free yourself from the constraints of everything that is holding you back you need to realize that is strength in itself. You might never truly pass, I might never fully pass, we all might never fully pass, but that is alright. As long as we live true to ourselves and try to be the best versions of ourselves we can make it in this world and we can be accepted by society. The first step is accepting ourselves and realizing that is who that matters at the end of the day. \n\nWith the current state that the trans community is at I fully believe that even though I am a part of it, I know that until it changes and becomes a source of power and support, that I don’t want to be involved with it because the backlash of trying to be proud for representing as trans in your own way seems to offend people who have different views or beliefs on what it means to be trans. In destroying the gender binary and realizing that there is many ways to being we have to realize that not everyone will look at how to be who they are the same way you are. \n\nI’m femme, I like girly things and try to live up to certain stereotypes. I am ok with that. I am ok with society the way it is. I am ok that I know I am going to have to fight for every inch that I can get in the world. I am ok with the fact that some people won’t accept me no matter how much I prove myself. I am ok with the fact that people will dismiss me because of my represented gender, race and that I am trans. I am ok with having to be different and I know that maybe I’ll stand out. I am still proud to be trans, but the same kind of proud that Jen Richards, Janet Mock or Laverne Cox represents. To me it is just a factor in my existence not a limiter. \n\nWe all limit ourselves from the world and from our true potential because we believe in can’t. I believe in can and I can do anything that I want. Yes, there is the scary factor that I will be targeted for hate because of my existence, but that goes for all people. We can die at any moment and have horrible things happen to us for no reason, but that is life and if that point is reached I want to know that I lived a proud life of who I am and aimed at who I want to be. \n\nThis is how I represent trans and I still have much to learn, but hopefully I am somewhere on the right track.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"princesshollycollie","id":97231378126,"post_url":"http://princesshollycollie.tumblr.com/post/97231378126/hello-2-everyone","slug":"hello-2-everyone","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 I haven’t achieved this by using hormones or anything as such, simply by being free and open to be who I’ve always been inside without the fear of abuse or rejection hanging over me anymore\n\nAnd I couldn’t be happier \n\nOver and out,\n\nJake","photoset_layout":"2","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":480,"height":640,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/2c17b9ad11b7a3bd938582b37ad485b5/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":533,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/2c17b9ad11b7a3bd938582b37ad485b5/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":333,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/2c17b9ad11b7a3bd938582b37ad485b5/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":133,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/2c17b9ad11b7a3bd938582b37ad485b5/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/2c17b9ad11b7a3bd938582b37ad485b5/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":480,"height":640,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/2c17b9ad11b7a3bd938582b37ad485b5/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o1_500.jpg"}},{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":480,"height":640,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/c5d0371dccbc86b6945815fd1d311dea/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o2_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":533,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/c5d0371dccbc86b6945815fd1d311dea/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o2_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":333,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/c5d0371dccbc86b6945815fd1d311dea/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o2_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":133,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/c5d0371dccbc86b6945815fd1d311dea/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o2_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/c5d0371dccbc86b6945815fd1d311dea/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o2_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":480,"height":640,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/c5d0371dccbc86b6945815fd1d311dea/tumblr_nbqxkuzpTX1tlg3w4o2_500.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"kay-leacock","id":97228166711,"post_url":"http://blog.kaycl.co.uk/post/97228166711/observations-on-trans-support-activism-within-the","slug":"observations-on-trans-support-activism-within-the","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 16:49:00 GMT","timestamp":1410454140,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"kLYshEOL","tags":["trans","gender","age","nonbinary","mogai","lgbtqia","lgbtq","lgbtqai","mogii","intersex","activism","ageism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZMr1Gq1QZG1Ot","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":12,"title":"Observations on trans support & activism within the community.","body":"One thing I’ve been noticing, very increasingly, lately, is the age gap in trans support and activism.\n\nWe’re very intent on focusing on support for the next generation of trans youths, and incorporating them into our activism. This is no bad thing, in fact, this is quite a good thing. The other side of this, however, seems to be that the current generation of trans people, the ones in the 25-45 or so age bracket, often end up being ignored.\n\nBear in mind that throughout this post, I am speaking in generalisations. I know there are exceptions, and I know that not everyone will have experienced this, but I am speaking from my own experience, and it is not my intent to alienate anyone.\n\nExcluding places with incredibly large queer populations, like Brighton or London, it seems that support groups for trans people start with groups for youth and young adult ranges, serving people in age brackets like 15-18 or 16-25. And then you’ve got your groups for the older people in the community, who are dealing with the issues of transitioning later, or dealing with their transitions later on. Unfortunately, however, there’s rarely anything for the less older adults, leaving a gap in the market. A lot of the groups attended by the older generation don’t appear to have age brackets, but the fact is that these groups end up attracting those people, and often feel uncomfortable for the younger folks - who aren’t welcome at “youth” groups, because they’re too old - because their support needs are different. There also appears to be a feeling within the medical and general support communities that people in this age bracket do not need support or help, which is clearly wrong. This is apparent in mental health services, I feel it is mirrored within support for the trans community as well. The support needs for people does differ between the different age brackets, however the current method of “youth” and “everyone else” is not working.\n\nThis is mirrored in activism as well. If you look at the majority (again, generalising) of the big name trans activists, they’re all older folks. Activists from our age bracket just ended up being branded as “social justice warriors” or “attention hogs”. But then you move down in the age gap slightly, and queer media is raving about the teenagers and young adults who are standing up for themselves and changing the world around them. I do feel that this needs to be celebrated and promoted, but it needs to be done in a way that isn’t at the expense of other people who are fighting the same fights.\n\nI’m completely aware that nonbinary identities are “relatively new” in the public perception, that intersex people have often kept quiet and out of the spotlight, and that trans people who don’t transition generally hid it in the past, but the public is hearing about us now. But they’re not hearing about us from ourselves. They’re hearing about us from the perspectives of trans people who fit the “typical trans narrative”, the older trans activists, and generally in reference to the current generation of young trans people. And in many cases, these activists are acting in the role of allies, but they’re often speaking for us, not to us. Our voices are not being heard because trans activists will not leave a space for us to speak ourselves. There is an apparent “handover” going on, where we’re preparing to hand our fight from the older generation of big names to the younger, but in doing so, we’re skipping the people who are dealing with things right now. Just like the aforementioned support needs differ between the different ages within the trans community, so do the activism needs, and that’s not being addressed - no one has left a space for us, so we shout louder to make our own space. But then, instead of being activists, we’re “oversensitive”, “social justice warriors”, “loudmouths”, “whiny”, “attention seeking” or “just being difficult”. And it’s people within our community that are telling us these things as readily as the people outside our community.\n\nThe recent Stonewall situation, for example, where a handful of the big name activists were selected for the initial meeting with Stonewall about including the trans community at large - yes, in this instance, the attendees for the meeting were selected by Stonewall themselves with little consideration for the rest of the community. However, while several of the attendees were willing to speak to the rest of the community and find out how they felt about the issues, and what they wanted brought to the meeting on their behalf, there was no shortage of people who were just willing to tell us to get over it while they speak for us. And I believe a large part of this is either because of our age, or because of the fact that we’re not big-enough-name activists, which I also believe is related to our age.\n\nThis is a trend that needs to stop. We have voices, and they will be heard. We have needs that need support, and we will get it. The question is, does the trans community at large want to help, or do they want us to do it for ourselves? This is not dissimilar to the situation that the trans community as a whole has been in with LGB(“T”) activists for quite some time now, where they’ve left out trans people (again, both in support and activism) or spoken on their behalf - but are we going to improve it, or just repeat what’s happened to us before?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"fromthecloudofowlyquill","id":97228014584,"post_url":"http://fromthecloudofowlyquill.tumblr.com/post/97228014584/boys-dont-spy-page-1-boys-dont-spy-page","slug":"boys-dont-spy-page-1-boys-dont-spy-page","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 16:47:00 GMT","timestamp":1410454020,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"xUCZI1ZC","tags":["transgender","transsexual","furry comic","trans","spy","spycraft","spying","spies","spy fiction","furry"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZMZtsr1QZFSFu","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"caption":"Boys Don’t Spy, Page 1.\nBoys Don’t Spy, Page 2.\nBoys Don’t Spy, Page 3.\nBoys Don’t Spy, Page 4.\nBoys Don’t Spy, Page 5.","image_permalink":"http://fromthecloudofowlyquill.tumblr.com/image/97228014584","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":1000,"height":987,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_1280.jpg"},{"width":500,"height":494,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":395,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":247,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":99,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":1000,"height":987,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/015d63858c7fa6fe957e1c1590d41487/tumblr_nbqxangOLT1surt6ro1_1280.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"sawyerthetransboy","id":97227883018,"post_url":"http://sawyerthetransboy.tumblr.com/post/97227883018/woodland-faerie-prince-is-applying-for","slug":"woodland-faerie-prince-is-applying-for","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 15:38:41 GMT","timestamp":1410449921,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"HS5qbHAY","tags":["trans","transgender","what tags are even relevant anymore?","I should probably start a side blog for this but yolo"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zd761u1QZ17d4","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"The first of a series: Essays on being trans and living on both sides of the fence.","body":"One of the few good things about being transsexual is that is gives a unique insight into the way that both men and woman live, something few people will ever get to experience. Now, of course, this is not an absolute thing: Some trans people do not and never will pass, and we obviously cannot turn back time and experiences our childhoods as if we were the other sex.\n\nBut it does grant you conditional entry into the social reality of the opposite sex. It also, if you are being honest with yourself, forces you to confront these realities and the fact that men and women are treated very differently within our society from the very moment we are born.\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nNow, first I want to say that I don’t know a lot about feminism, queer theory, sociology, or any of that stuff on any side of the issue. I haven’t read any books on the subject (one part lacking time, two parts not knowing where to start). The extent of my education on these subjects is essentially reading statistics and the words of some very articulate women here on tumblr. That said, my beliefs tend to be most in line with radical feminism, a conclusion drawn partly through my own lived experiences and partly through reading the words of women.\n\nSecond, I want to establish my reasons for starting to write about this. For anyone who’s been following me for a while, you know that I very rarely write about being transsexual, and even more rarely write about it in depth. I will occasionally reblog something or throw out a comment or two, but that’s pretty much as far as I go. I am a hockey blog, first and foremost, and that won’t change (beware, all ye who enter for anything but hockey. Winter is coming).\n\nBut I wanted to start writing more about my experiences because there seem to be very few female transsexuals within this discussion. I have seen some FTMs and a few detransitioned women in discussions, but overall females who are trans or who have a history of being trans seem to be rarer than MTFs. As I said, I am not very educated on these matters, but I am well versed on my own experiences, and I like to think I am insightful enough to say something meaningful at least once or twice if I write a whole bunch of those experiences down.\n\nI also want to write more about this for personal reasons. I have thought long and hard about my transition and why I am doing it, but I rarely write anything down. I see this as a sort of way not only to share my experiences and hopefully contribute something to the discussion, but also as a way for me to organize my thoughts and analyze my choices and thought process. Ultimately, I am always on a journey to bring together my reality as a female person and my decision to take male hormones and socially transition to being a man.\n\nThird: Me. I am Jimmy. I am 24 years old. I am a female to male transsexual, and I spent the first 22ish years of my life living as a woman. I like hockey more than is probably healthy. I am a writer and a lover of the English language, for all its pitfalls. Reading has been the best teacher I’ve ever had and writing the best therapist. I currently attend school online full time and also work full time as a live in nanny. I live in Arizona, which I hate both because of the politics and the weather.\n\nFeel free to comment on this or any future such posts to agree or disagree or simply spread the information. Keep in mind, though, that I do not, nor am I trying to, speak for all transsexual men. I simply want to use this as a means of documenting my experiences and organizing my thoughts.\n\nSome topics that I intend to explore in the future: Looking back at the differences between how my brother and I were raised, examining how losing my mother at a young age and being raised by my father impacted my life and especially how I interact with gender, my frustration with the trans movement as a whole, and many tidbits of analysis regarding how I have been treated as a man versus as a woman.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"makarad","id":97224149135,"post_url":"http://makarad.tumblr.com/post/97224149135/alright-so-i-dont-make-a-lot-of-personal-posts-on","slug":"alright-so-i-dont-make-a-lot-of-personal-posts-on","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 15:36:42 GMT","timestamp":1410449802,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"wqtgJfbA","tags":["inky spills","trans","transgender","ftm","misgendering","dysphoria","I don't know what else to tag this as","looking for advice","why is this so damn long","it's not even noon and I'm already rambling"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zg69su1QZ0iYF","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"alright so I don’t make a lot of personal posts on here, because I usually just reblog fandom posts and important news posts, but I don’t even know where to start for this.\n\n(everything under a cut because it’s longer than I thought it would be. misgendering and dysphoria and unsupportive parents, if you’d like a summary.)\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nabout a month ago (august 10th) I finally confronted my mother, hoping I’d just blown things out of proportion in my head after I’d tried to tell her I only liked girls, and wasn’t interested in guys. I told her I was trans(gender), and that I wasn’t a girl. that I am a boy, and I like girls. our “conversation” - if you can even call it that - lasted an hour and a half. it only ended because I was sick to tears and wanting to express my pain in unhealthy ways.\n\nnaturally, she decided that the conversation - no, the entire topic - was over and done with after that.\n\nshe spent every opportunity I wasn’t interrupting her to correct her because she wasn’t listening to try and undermine me, and turn my past behaviour back on me. that I liked dressing up and looking nice, and it made me feel good. that I wasn’t like this before. that she swung both ways when she was younger, too. that I hadn’t even spent any time being a girl - in other words, wearing make-up and dresses and skirts and short shorts and tight shirts. that I just needed to find the right guy. that I could never pass for a guy anyway.\n\nshe suggested getting me a different counselor/therapist, and I’ll admit - I laughed. her intentions were not to support me, and she made that obvious; I’m her baby girl, and she doesn’t want me to feel so uncomfortable in my own body. she decided that a counselor would “fix” me so she could keep trying to live vicariously through me.\n\nevery “argument” she tried to “counter” me with was selfish and uncaring. ultimately, she admitted, before I just couldn’t let her beat me down anymore, that she didn’t even know what “trans” was, much less “transgender”. that, of course, proved to me what I’d known the entire time - she wasn’t listening.\n\nmy father is a bit of a wild card, but seeing as he uses “gay”, “flamboyant”, and “fag” as insults against feminine and/or flamboyant men, I’m glad I waited until he left on a business trip to try and speak with my mother on the subject.\n\nthe biggest issue is that she now makes even more attempts for “validation”; that is, blatantly stating that we are women and we are female and we have to stick together and we need to stand up against men.\n\nthis post turned out longer than I thought it would, but I don’t know what to do - I can’t move out yet, having no driver’s license and no job (much less knowing a place I can stay that will take an unemployed 19 year old with his cat and rabbit). I’m already aware that my mother is emotionally/psychologically abusive, and now she has my gender to use against me as well.\n\nwhile it’s thankfully almost autumn, it’s never very cool in Florida thanks to the humidity. I wear a compression sports bra, a tank top, a t-shirt, and a hoodie. I’ve fortunately got four pairs of men’s pants; all four of them miracles to acquire.\n\nI need to at least curb my dysphoria better, seeing as a counselor (and a plan to transition) are out of the question until I’m out of this house. google has only gotten me so far, and I’m so uselessly limited in what I can do right now and in the near future. I need a plan, or plans, or resources or something. I’m just…so lost in what to do.","can_reply":false}]

One if these has been haircuts. \n\nIn the past, before I was out I would go to my hairdressers with a photo of a boy’s haircut and although it’s a unisex hair salon the girls naturally presumed that I would want it adapted to a girl’s style and although I always hated my cuts I always sighed and told everyone I was happy with it. \n\nYesterday my mam asked if I would like my hair cut as she knew it was getting me down. I explained that I was scared they’d do a girl’s style and my mam simply said “right, come with me” and pulled me into the hairdressers. \n\nI was absolutely terrified as she dragged my hairdresser aside to have a word. She explained my situation but much to my surprise my hairdresser smiled and said “that’s fine, come back in two hours jake”\n\nWhen I returned in two hours, I sat for five minutes before she turned to me and said “ok jake do you want to take a seat”\n\nShe actually listened to me, she called me jake all the way through the cut and even cut my sideburns the way a guy’s should be. She was amazing and while I watched the style take shape I couldn’t help but smile\n\nWhen she had done I went to the desk to pay. She asked for £6.50 instead of the regular £12 and my mam looked confused but the hairdresser simply smiled and said “men’s cut”\n\nI don’t know if she realises how much that meant to me but it meant the world. Her straight out acceptance made the world even less of a scary place and I can’t express how much that means to me. \n\nOver and out, \n\nJake.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"cnbjonghyun","id":97216521662,"post_url":"http://cnbjonghyun.tumblr.com/post/97216521662/scans-partial-trans-awesome-vol-14-cnblue-lee","slug":"scans-partial-trans-awesome-vol-14-cnblue-lee","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 13:03:00 GMT","timestamp":1410440580,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"eJOxxHsu","tags":["cnblue","lee jonghyun","jonghyun","eng trans","trans","awesome"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z4Ud7y1QYZcM_","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":109,"caption":"[Scans|Partial Trans] Awesome Vol. 14 : CNBLUE Lee JongHyun\n\nQ: With uplifting melody, various kinds of instruments, claps, and inserted voice “hoo~!,” Foxy is full of uplifting elements. It is a very attractive song. As for lyrics, it leaves impression that a man is obsessed with a sexy woman. When seeing the lyrics only, it seems like Yonghwa’s composition. haha \nJongHyun: Ah, it may be. \nYongHwa: Wait, Is that my image?! \nJongHyun: It is, no? haha \n\n Q: YongHwa would escort ladies better and JongHyun would be a bit shy.. This is just an impression that people may have. haha \nYongHwa: You see? It’s not like I’m a playboy. Yes, I do better. \nJongHyun: (bitter laugh) I did write it with fun. Lyrics too, it’s a funny situation, isn’t it? Although the genre is different from that of songs I’ve made before, but I found it interesting to write. \n\n Q: Monster’s lyrics is also unique. Jonghyun, your composition seems to have grown wider recently. Do you challenge new genres consciously? \nJongHyun: I don’t really care about genres. \nYongHwa: Jonghyun makes rap. \nJongHyun: Oh, yes I do. I have liked hiphop.That’s true. Since every genre has its own strong point, I find it interesting to combine those strong points. What is important is to make good songs, not genre.\n\nQ: What is your favorite song in Wave album? \nJongHyun: Of course I have attachment to every song, but if I choose one, I choose the last track, \"How awesome.\" Even if I do say so myself, I write the lyrics very carefully. \n\n Q: It has a strong message. \nJongHyun: Yes, it is about ourselves. I wrote about our daily life, performing live everyday.. To live this way itself is wonderful. I titled it \"How awesome\" in this way, and it can be a message to fans, too.\n\nJongHyun: I want to try bass. In the end, band’s ability depends on bass. To understand band better, I’m still learning to play drums and bass.\n\nQ: Your new song seems to be about a man chasing after a sexy lady. Are you like that too?\nJongHyun: Do you mean my relationship style? I don’t chase after woman (says in a very direct way). But I like sexy woman. I think what “sexy” means differs in each of us members, but I like woman who are confident. I think woman who are confident are sexy.\n\nScanned by YFfTW (CLICK HERE for more scans)\n\nTranslated by @happytmg & the heck are pronouns? Help support your trans friends! Here’s our guide on what pronouns are, why they matter, and how to use new ones!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"atranspaige","id":97209182726,"post_url":"http://atranspaige.tumblr.com/post/97209182726/so-lucky-to-be-a-boy-with-breasts","slug":"so-lucky-to-be-a-boy-with-breasts","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 09:48:00 GMT","timestamp":1410428880,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"ex4mFUeS","tags":["trans activism","transsexual","transgender","trans","my life story"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZoCmnm1QY7ce6","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"title":"So \"Lucky\" to be a Boy with Breasts","body":"A little while ago I saw a post where some trans woman was using boys who develop breasts as a point to try and guilt a lesbian who wouldn’t sleep with them. You can read the post and my response here. Besides annoying me greatly, it made me think about the trans women who have called me lucky and wish they had had some sort of odd physical development. \n\nBefore I go any farther, a few quick facts. When a male develops breasts it’s called gynecomastia. There are two types. Pseudogynecomastia is what obese men get and is just fat. True gynecomastia is actually not that uncommon. It’s usually a small lump of breast tissue about the diameter of a quarter. The majority of times it goes away on it’s own within 2 years.\n\nIn my case it didn’t. Before hormones I was 5’6” 180lbs and wore a 40C.\n\nLook I get it. I know exactly why a number of trans women think I’m lucky. They made passing a lot easier from the start. And if I believed differently, they could easily be used to argue that I really am a woman. \n\nThose trans women couldn’t be more wrong. There was nothing “lucky” about it!\n\nYes, many women can understand the feelings of shame and hatred at their body’s development. They can emphasize with me in ways that few men can. Only another male who experienced developing breasts can fully comprehend the depth of shame we go to though.\n\nJust take a moment and try to imagine having your body develop in ways it shouldn’t. Everyone around you treats it like a deformity and you’re a freak. Multiple doctors poke and prod you before declaring that you must have surgery. Not because of any health reason, but purely cosmetic since they agree your deformed. Just imagine what that does to a person’s sense of self worth.\n\nMany guys jump at the chance of surgery too. They’ll do anything if it means not being a freak any longer. Not me though.\n\nThe thought of surgery terrified me. No offense to any trans men who might read this, but I didn’t want to trade breasts for dead, trimmed nipples that might fall off and a chest covered in scars. I couldn’t see how that would make me feel less ashamed of my body.\n\nInstead I spent over a decade wearing a binder. Wishing they weren’t there but unwilling to get rid of them. Its only been in the past year that I’ve been able to start connecting with this part of myself. To stop feeling shame and disgust, replaced with feeling of acceptance and love \n\nThis is why you can’t say I’m lucky. The vast majority of men who have experienced this definitely don’t consider themselves “lucky”. Even for someone like me who transitioned, the psychological trauma far outweighs any minor benefit to passing that fate has bestowed upon me.\n\nAnd those of you who would use me to prove a point, your the worst!\n\nYou hide the complexity of life and rob me of my humanity. You turn me into an object. Evidence A, a pair of breasts and a dick. And in so doing, you completely miss the real truth.\n\nIt doesn’t matter what my existence proves or disproves. What matters is being a boy with breasts is a part of the male experience. A rare part, but decidedly male none the less. To be a boy with breasts only makes sense through a male lens. The effect it has had on my life only makes sense when you understand that I’m male. \n\nLastly, you strip all the men who don’t transition of their manhood. You become no better than the boys who held me against a wall when I was 13 and groped me to see if my breasts were real and whether I was a guy or girl.\n\nYour predators preying on those you feel are weaker than you! All you’ve done is show how little you care about other people, and proved nothing in the process.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"allaboutwu","id":97209154602,"post_url":"http://allaboutwu.tumblr.com/post/97209154602/140911-ureallywestlifeforever-sowk-press","slug":"140911-ureallywestlifeforever-sowk-press","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 outwu","id":97207707667,"post_url":"http://allaboutwu.tumblr.com/post/97207707667/140911-contemporary-pop-music-weibo-wu-yi","slug":"140911-contemporary-pop-music-weibo-wu-yi","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 etc.","body":"Mr. Cee (of hot 97) got “caught” for the third time now seeking sex from various trans prostitutes. It’s a “sex scandal”.\nThe hip-hop community (and all media community) seems to disregard the difference between “trans woman” and “man”. You know, the bit where one person is a woman and the other is a man.\nEven Mr. Cee refers to the prostitutes he visited as “men”, while referring to himself as “not gay”. He would rather mislabel his own sexuality than for a second consider that transwomen are women.\n\n The entire community is talking about Mr. Cee’s “supposed homosexuality”, and are even pseudocompromising by calling it a fetish or quirk — before ever stopping to consider once that trans women are women.\n\n The prostitution aspect is minimal, and this “scandal” wouldn’t exist if cis people viewed trans people as their valid identities, but cis-society prevents this conversation from ever happening because it seems like it won’t even occur to most people to respect these women as who they are.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"fcyeah","id":97206141282,"post_url":"http://fcyeah.tumblr.com/post/97206141282/pronouns","slug":"pronouns","type":"link","date":"2014-09-11 08:00:28 GMT","timestamp":1410422428,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"194e2L4w","tags":["pronouns","gender","gender diversity","trans","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z0Gi5x1QXy05Y","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"Pronouns","url":"https://minus18.org.au/index.php/resource-packs/pronouns","description":"Check out this awesome new ap, video, and article about PRONOUNS!!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"thefeministagonyaunt","id":97206060921,"post_url":"http://thefeministagonyaunt.tumblr.com/post/97206060921/okay-so","slug":"okay-so","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 07:57:00 GMT","timestamp":1410422220,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"RRgFoZMh","tags":["trans","LGBTQ","LGBT","cisgender","cis","cultural appropriation","feminism","feminist","tumblr culture"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zvph_m1QXxiTv","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"title":"Okay, So","body":"It really annoys me, and I’ve seen it a fair few times on this website, when someone will anonymously be like “oh, some question about trans/cis/queer” and the owner of the blog will be like “pipe the fuck down you cishet piece of shit! You better check your goddamn privilege!!!”\n\nLike dude, not everyone knows what cishet means, stop being so angry.\n\nAs I say, I’ve seen this a lot of times.\n\nSo basically, I’m going to compile a basic list of some things you might not know, and if you want to ask anything or need to know more, please ask! I promise I will never be rude or tell you to check your privilege. Those things are frankly unhelpful to the cause; I will tell you, because the grand majority of people mean well, just don’t know quite the right way to do or say something. Here we go.\n\nCisgender/cis: Having a gender identity or gender role that society considers appropriate for the sex one was assigned at birth. (i.e. female on birth certificate and identify and feel like a female)\n\nCishet: Someone who is both cisgender and heterosexual (sexually/romantically attracted to the opposite sex)\n\nTransgender: Someone who feels that they identify with a gender other than what they were born with, or a person who feels that the body into which they were born doesn’t represent their true gender (i.e. female on birth certificate but strongly identifies as male or feels like a male)\n\nNon-Gender-Binary: A bit more complicated, this could mean you identify with both genders, no genders or fluid about the whole thing (i.e. if you feel like a boy one day and a girl another day)\n\nFeminism: It’s just equality, we want to be equal. Nothing evil or “man hating”, it’s just about the fact that we’ve been treated unfairly and we want that to stop. We want to be able to sleep with whoever we want and get cool jobs that pay the same as men’s and get abortions/birth control if we need them. Just equality. \n\nWhy can’t I call a black person an N word because they say it/ a queer person queer because they say it: They can call themselves queer if they identify as such or it makes them feel good to describes themselves as that way, but bottom line is, that word has been offensive for so long that it can really hurt if a straight person calls you queer, even if you say that about yourself (awful example: I call myself several cruel “ginger” names for fun, but it stings when someone calls me an ugly ginger fucker).\n\nCultural appropriation: When someone who doesn’t know much about another culture does something sacred to that culture just because it’s fashionable - it can be pretty offensive (i.e. me going to a Hindu temple when I travelled around Nepal, a country that I’m fascinated by, and receiving a bindi = fine. Skinny, white hipster wearing a bindi to a music festival to seem cool and boho = not really fine) \n\nThat’s about all I can think of for the time being, please let me know if this was helpful, want anything else added to the list, or if you need more questions answered, even if they seem a little silly, this is a safe space to ask! :)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"dirtygaythreesome","id":97206006753,"post_url":"http://dirtygaythreesome.tumblr.com/post/97206006753/15-experts-debunk-right-wing-transgender-bathroom-myth","slug":"15-experts-debunk-right-wing-transgender-bathroom-myth","type":"link","date":"2014-09-11 trans\n\nhowever i had a lot of worries which i will list here (and will then explain if/how they got worked out underneath)\n\n1: i go to a catholic college right now so just in case they find out about me being trans and/or queer, can they kick me the hell out???? bc i can’t afford to sue\n\ni checked my school’s title IV stuff and their student code of conduct and it explicitly states that my school doesn’t discriminate against gender identity, gender expression, or sexual orientation. so i should be fine (but i might have to switch into a boy dorm next year which would be GR8 4 ME)\n\n2: what if my parents hate me and i DO have to leave school and they won’t let me live with them????\n\nmy stepbrother who i have only met once bc he has a bad relationship with my stepdad is out as gay. but my mom was saying that he’s been wearing a lot of makeup and girl-esque clothes and she said “i mean we knew he was gay, but maybe he’s trans? i mean we just don’t know yet, of course we aren’t gonna have a problem with it.\n\n3: trying to start t? will insurance cover it? will my parents see it on the insurance? will my mom try to come to the doctor with me? or try to make me wait? will the doctor try to make me see a therapist? cost? do i have to needle myself? will being non binary make them not wanna give me t?  ???????\n\nlots of research. pretty sure my insurance covers it. my parents can’t MAKE me let them come. i checked like, the law, and doctors can’t force me to see a therapist/counsellor as long as I’m 18 (i am). needles aren’t the ONLY way (creams and gels also exist), but i might still do needles. they can’t not let me get t because I’m non binary so thats cool.\n\n4: i am sort of with a guy what if he decides to be like BYE if i come out???\n\nhe already knows I’m non binary and if he isn’t cool with be coming out then his ass doesn’t deserve me in the first place so like????? even tho he makes me really happy and smily i want someone who wants me In the apprenticeship program, similar to a beauty school model, TransTech offers creative technology services including but not limited to, web development and graphic design, that are worked on by students and educators at affordable prices for consumers. 100% of the profits go back into the program. TransTech is a social enterprise structure that is meant to maximize economic improvement and well-being within the LGBTQ community, rather than focusing on maximizing profits for external shareholders.\n\nTTSE envisions a world where no trans person ever underestimates their value. We believe in a world where trans-identified people can improve their skills and increase their value and self-worth without the threat of harassment and discrimination. A future where everyone feels empowered. \n\nWe recognize the unlimited potential for growth in what we offer, how we offer it, and who we offer it to. Our trainings are delivered on-site and online. Our training focuses on basic jobs skill like data entry and administrative tasks to advanced skills like graphic design, and web-coding. We structure this academy around empowerment, and education, with the goal to secure employment.\nThese three tenets, Empower, Educate and Employ, are each important parts of the educational structure and will include instructions on topics ranging from Power, Privilege, and Oppression and Scholarship Essays to Coding Skills and How to Build a Professional Network.\n  We believe providing a space where anyone can interact with trans people in a business atmosphere will create a stronger relationship with the entire community and also demonstrate the capabilities and worth of Trans People.\n\nOnly 5 days left - please donate + 04:53:00 GMT","timestamp":1410411180,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"PVsVnlXG","tags":["facialhairwars","ftm","trans","transgender","transwife"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZDD2Qy1QXTxsw","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"caption":"Yeah… no.","image_permalink":"http://lickyvobo.tumblr.com/image/97198259642","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":211,"height":238,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_250.png"},{"width":100,"height":113,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_100.png"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_75sq.png"}],"original_size":{"width":211,"height":238,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/f382821b96b7ab83ed5ea9e2e59b39c7/tumblr_nbq08c2vE71qamncoo1_250.png"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"twotransmen","id":97198185981,"post_url":"http://twotransmen.tumblr.com/post/97198185981/about-this-blog","slug":"about-this-blog","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 04:51:46 GMT","timestamp":1410411106,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"SXzOthFU","tags":["transgender","trans","ftm transgender","ftm transition","ftm","transition"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zt5QWm1QXTftz","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"About This Blog","body":"Cecil and Sebastian are two trans men from Columbus, OH. Though discovering their gender dysphoria separately, the two came together in late 2013 to pursue their goals. Cecil moved from NY, to Columbus to share a life and love with Sebastian, as well as to share the experience of transitioning together.\n\nRecognizing that most trans men resources on the web are written from the perspective of young and healthy men, we cooperatively decided to run a blog together about our experiences of transitioning as people beyond the age of 25, as well as of people suffering from disorders and disabilities, and taking medications. Our story is not necessarily unique, but different enough, and we hope that it can give others like us the hope, courage, and help to continue along their paths in life.\n\nImportant: This blog may contain triggering language, but only when necessary. Activism and posts related to activism may occur. It will contain posts of a personal nature. It will contain photographs, videos, and the life experiences of two people that live a bit outside of the norm. This is not a Social Justice blog. Please enjoy this as a resource, feel free to ask questions, and to reblog. But please try to refrain from harassment, aggression, and personal attacks.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"popculturecatchall","id":97197797843,"post_url":"http://popculturecatchall.tumblr.com/post/97197797843/fairly-soon-i-will-do-something-which-will-utterly","slug":"fairly-soon-i-will-do-something-which-will-utterly","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 04:45:00 GMT","timestamp":1410410700,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"BAVKh46K","tags":["trans","trans woman","transgender","personal","depression","personal history"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-CYhu1QXSB7J","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"Fairly soon I will do something which will utterly surprise every person I know. There may be a little bit of “Oh, that explains some stuff.” There’ll be some “Well, we thought you might be gay or something.” But there will most certainly be absolutely no “Yeah, I knew you were trans but didn’t feel like saying anything.”\n\nIt’s kind of cool, if still incredibly scary. I mean, I assume at this point in life the people in my life probably think they have a very good handle on who I am. I’m 28, not so old that I’m expected to have everything figured out (like anyone ever does), but also not so young that I should have no clue who I am. And it’s not that I don’t. Obviously, I have a very clear idea of who I am. It’s just that I cannot share it with anyone yet. And so it’s put a lot of discovery on hold. I can do self-reflection all damn day, but I can’t go out in the world and get a full sense of how I exist.\n\nI remember being about 23 or so and talking with my siblings over some food. It was likely some holiday, but nothing grand. Let’s just act like it was Labor Day and be done with the speculation. We were sitting around and talking, and one of them said, “When did ______ start reading?” They talked about how they out of nowhere, to them, when I was about 17 or 18 I had this collection of books and this little secret history of reading to where I could recommend all these books, yet they had never seen me reading during these years.\n\nSecret was always the default. Sharing isn’t easy for our family with anything, and when I add in basically hiding half my thoughts by default, that leads to some secret agent level shit. I used to sneak books home, hoping no one would catch me on the stairs and ask what I had in my bag. I would buy something else and hide the book underneath. When I went searching for a book, I did so alone. I had decided I would be a reader and I knew that if it were a true part of me it needed to be hidden from sight.\n\nI wonder what my dad would have answered if he were ever asked what my dream job was. Now, maybe he would know. I eventually brought my books out of the closet and majored in creative writing. But back then, could he even have sniffed the answer? I doubt it.\n\nThe last time I caught my family by surprise I was 17, almost 18. I packed everything I cared about and put it in my car and drove away. There was some vague idea of moving to Mexico and getting a job and writing—though I don’t know if I ever really believed in the possibility. It was an act of escape. I ran away. Outside San Diego my resolve broke and the loneliness seeped in and I realized how dumb I was being and I just wanted to go back. I turned around and drove straight back. Other than stopping for food and driving along the coast, I really didn’t do much. I just drove and thought and thought and thought.\n\nThe return was a smart choice, but it was a coward’s choice. I went back and told a half truth of why I ran. I went back and cut myself off from the world and finished up school on my own. I went back and told myself it was okay. I went back and didn’t talk to people about having left.\n\nWhen I first tried to write about this event it came out completely muddled in one of those underground writing workshops that are more diary sharing hours than actual craft discussions (so, this basically). I was still trying to write around the depression. Some classmates were kind, and found parts to praise. Others were dicks, but that was always their role in those discussions. And I sat there, listening, but knowing “I cannot tell you the whole truth because I will not accept it is true.”\n\nRunning away was a long time coming and the culmination of one of the deepest depressions I’ve ever dealt with. To those that knew me then, it seemed to come from nowhere. To me it was just the unfortunate peak of a lost year. It was the dumb stunt that granted me one of the few moments of control in a life I rarely felt was my own. The six months before I had been depressed and alone, the six months after I was depressed and alone.\n\nI got better, or something like better. I don’t know. It’s hard to see the edges of this for me, but I know it faded and things grew better for me and it’s never really been quite that bad since, even when it’s been really bad sometimes. The depression always seems to lurk and the decisions I make in the fog carry the risk of fucking me over. I nearly quit my credential program with a month left to go and $20,000 of debt, a no gain all loss decision that seemed like the right thing to do in that moment. It grabs hold of your brain and seeps into your life and nothing feels worth the price of effort. That would have surprised everyone.\n\nBut I didn’t. I stuck with it and now I’m teaching and getting paid. The debt won’t go away, but at least I’ll make a couple bucks and have some good work experience—things the depression would have robbed me of. I did everything everyone expected of me. I’m very capable when I try, even when dealing with all of this—though I’ve never let anyone know about it in full. I think they can see it. I think they can feel it. And if I were to tell them I deal with depression they wouldn’t be surprised.\n\nBut no one at all will see me being trans. Being trans is not the only cause of my depression, but it’s a multiplier for sure. But ordering hormones, deciding on this path, this wasn’t a depression choice. This was the other me. The secret me that read books, even if she felt she needed to skip lunch to get money to buy them. The secret me that snuck into the library at school and borrowed Dostoyevsky, but made sure no one saw me enter or leave. I’ve made my moves when no one else would notice, kept everything from their eyes, and cultivated their eventual surprise. This is an act of the full me, and one done from a desire for a future, not a fear.\n\nAnd then, once they’re all surprised, it’ll be my turn. Honestly, I have no idea how people will react, other than generally shocked and less-than-positive. I have a certain idea of how people will act, but only a vague sense at best. The fact is the day after I come out, I don’t know if I’ll still have any of them in my life. I think a few will stick, but who the fuck knows.\n\nI’m rapidly approaching the unknown. But that’s never been the problem; it’s when I think I know all the awful things coming, the pointlessness of tomorrow, that the depression comes. The unknown is the exciting part and I’m ready for that to come.\n\n—Emma","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lickyvobo","id":97197728152,"post_url":"http://lickyvobo.tumblr.com/post/97197728152/t-time","slug":"t-time","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 04:44:07 GMT","timestamp":1410410647,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uwaT0yUs","tags":["trans","transgender","ftm","transwife","senecacrane","testosterone","ttime"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZDD2Qy1QXRw6O","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"T Time","body":"Yesterday was a big day at our house… Jax started testosterone!\n\n I kept waiting for the whole day to be different, but it continued not be.\n\nWe sat in a regular old exam room where they took vitals and went over side effects. Then we walked to Walgreens to fill this life changing prescription, just like you would get medicine for a sinus infection.\n\nNow I keep waiting for facial hair and a deepening voice. Like I’m going to wake up and in a matter of 48 hours he’s going to be Barry White with a ZZ Top beard.\n\n One injection of a low dose of testosterone isn’t going to change things, but it’s most definitely a start in the right direction.\n\nNow I just have to talk Jax out of facial hair ala Seneca Crane from the ‘Hunger Games’.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"eilijohnson","id":97196931987,"post_url":"http://eilijohnson.tumblr.com/post/97196931987/bored-sissors-new-awesome-teen-titans","slug":"bored-sissors-new-awesome-teen-titans","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 GMT","timestamp":1410406844,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"d5fLCNWu","tags":["lgbt","transgender","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZXOutt1QXBWE1","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"Personal...","body":"<!-- more -->\n\nI honestly feel it’s too early to feel this way considering I came to terms with the fact that I’m transgender just a week ago, but…\n\nEver since I’ve made this realization, I’ve been putting a lot more effort into my appearance, but it’s not having any effect. I still get called “sir” or “man” or “dude” endlessly, and it honestly hurts.\n\nWhat’s worse is that I feel like a complete shit-head about it. Even I can grasp the fact that it’s not other people’s fault. They don’t know who I am, and I can’t expect to just suddenly start being referred to as female, but even knowing this, I can’t get over how bad it makes me feel. \n\nI just wish I could tell my Dad and Sister, but I’m too scared of how they’d react. I already feel like a disappointment to my dad because I’m not the son he wanted (I’m a lazy degenerate who leeches off the money he worked years to earn and didn’t have a job until I was 20. And even then I couldn’t hold on to it for more than two months), so how the hell am I supposed to tell him, “Whoops sorry I’d rather be your daughter. Let’s just call this one a mulligan.”\n\nEven before this I know he suspected I’m gay (though is it technically gay now?), though I never outright said it. He probably would be supportive but I can’t stop thinking about what would happen if he wasn’t. He could handle me being gay but wanting to be a woman? What if he hates me?\n\nAnd my sister. She always says I can tell her anything, but I’m scared of even her reaction. Just yesterday I jokingly asked her if she was hoping for a sister when my mom was pregnant and she said, “lol no I actually wanted a brother.” How can I tell her after that?!”\n\nToday fucked me up bad, and I’m scared about tomorrow. 03:33:38 GMT","timestamp":1410406418,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"pPLbfhrV","tags":["asks","trans","transgender","allies","femwork"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZoEgYu1QX9Z3c","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":14,"asking_name":"femwork","asking_url":"http://femwork.tumblr.com/","question":"Hi! Could anyone please help me to start using the correct pronouns and words for transgendered people? Eg. What are the correct pronouns? I want to make sure that I use the words that they prefer and I don't want to cause any offence. I would also like to know what is the best way a cisgendered person can support transgender people?","answer":"All right, let’s tackle this.\n\nIt is not transgendered or cisgendered. It is transgender or cisgender, or trans or cis.\nAlso, it’s not “trans*”.\nAlso, cis does not stand for “comfortable in skin”. Cis is simply the linguistical opposite of trans.\nBeing trans works like being queer - treat us in a similar way, I mean. Ex: don’t out them, don’t constantly compare them to other trans people you know of/have met, don’t say it’s a phase or any other invalidating thing, don’t make them a public spectacle or your token friend, don’t constantly ask them how sex, relationships, transness works ie use them as your go-to reference for “life as a trans person”, and so on.\nThere aren’t any special rules for pronouns for trans people. It’s the same way with cis people - you use the pronouns they want used. Trans women are women, trans men are men. There are no universal pronouns for trans people.\nIf you’re corrected on their identity or pronouns, say you’re sorry and work on using the pronouns they want. If you don’t know or are confused about conjugation, ask privately. \nAll pronouns are valid pronouns. Because words are all made up and language is constantly changing. Therefore, a new pronoun has just as much legitimacy as any other new word in our language.\nAll genders are valid. Gender is a human concept and as such it can be interpreted and classified in a variety of ways just like any other intangible concepts.\nSex is also a human concept. Please do not use terms like “male-bodied” or “female-bodied”, do not identify any bodily characteristics as inherently male/masculine or female/feminine. Use DMAB (deemed/designated male at birth) and DFAB (deemed/designated female at birth) (and other terms like it) sparingly and only when necessary (many people tend to use them as replacements of “male-bodied” and “female-bodied” when that is not what they are). Refer directly to the parts you are speaking about, ex, instead of saying “female reproductive system”, say uterus, ovaries, etc.\nDo not use FTM (female to male) or MTF (male to female) unless the person in question has expressed a preference for these terms. Do not refer to trans people as “trapped in a (wo)man’s body” or “used to be a (wo)man” or “born a (wo)man” - only trans people are allowed to use this as part of their self identification. The proper way to say it - if you are allowed to at all - would be, “used to identify as a (wo)man” and sentiments like it.\nDo not support truscum or T(W)ERFs (trans (women) exclusionary radical feminists). Do not separate trans women from “real women”, or trans men from “real men”. Do not support the idea of “transtrenders”.\nDysphoria is a vague medical term that can be applied to a variety of situations, feelings, interpretations, and so on. It therefore is not the sole determiner in whether someone is trans. Being trans simply means you identify as something other than what you were assigned at birth.\nDo not call raising children gender neutrally child abuse. Do not call allowing children to break gender norms child abuse. Do not raise your children according to gender norms. Make it clear you are open to the idea that your child may be more than what they seem. Allow your children and the children and people around you to explore gender and identity.\nThey/them/theirs should be your default pronoun. Do not assume people’s gender. Do not use (s)he or she/he. Singular they is grammatically correct.\nThese are slurs (forgive me, followers): hermaphrodite, he-she, cuntboy, dickgirl, futa, tranny, and basically any term you’ll find in a pornographic video or website.\nDo not ever misgender someone or deny their transness regardless of what they’ve done, what they’ve said, how they identify, how they appear, etc.\nNonbinary refers to trans people who do not identify as solely women nor as solely men.\nTransphobia and cissexism refer to discrimination against and oppression of trans people. Transmisogyny refers to the specific discrimination against and oppression of trans women, who face unique challenges from other trans people. Cisphobia does not exist.\nDyadism refers to the discrimination against and oppression of intersex people. Intersex and trans are different - intersex people can be cis or trans.\nCasual cissexism refers to the alignment of being a (wo)man to certain bodily characteristics, bodily functions, or biological or social issues (breast development, reproductive health, certain cancers, jokes about lesbians hating penises, etc).\nDo not argue with people about trans headcanons (or any headcanons involving marginalized people).\nTag appropriately; try to tag transphobia/cissexism, transmisogyny, hate crimes, truscum, radfems, casual cissexism, etc. Ask your followers what they need you to help them avoid.\nDo not use “same-sex marriage” or “same-gender marriage” as blanket terms for the marital rights movement. Do not use “opposite gender/sex”.\nHere are relevant tags to browse: #trans | #trans rights | #transphobia | #casual cissexism | #transmisogyny | #dyadism","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"graveyardaro","id":97192464563,"post_url":"http://graveyardaro.tumblr.com/post/97192464563/its-late-and-dash-is-slow-like-reblog-if-u-post","slug":"its-late-and-dash-is-slow-like-reblog-if-u-post","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 should be a rule that every person on tumblr should put their gender and pronouns in their sidebar/about. Jesus fucking Christ.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"sir-james","id":97191257106,"post_url":"http://sir-james.tumblr.com/post/97191257106/i-had-an-interview","slug":"i-had-an-interview","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 03:11:30 GMT","timestamp":1410405090,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"6lyruugH","tags":["Ftm","Trans","Transman","UOW"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZJKQ9v1QX3EGI","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"I had an interview","body":"Today,\n\nIt was for a local university’s gender and sexuality week. Their TV channel asked me to represent trans people and shed some light on the relevant issues and, I guess, what it’s like to be me.\n\n I feel like I’ve done a really positive thing in terms of trans visibility and educating the masses, and perhaps making them feel more connected to transgender people. Normalised it for them.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"mcrdeviantclub","id":97191174681,"post_url":"http://mcrdeviantclub.tumblr.com/post/97191174681/hello-could-i-request-a-ficlet-of-trans-kobra-binding","slug":"hello-could-i-request-a-ficlet-of-trans-kobra-binding","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-11 03:10:00 GMT","timestamp":1410405000,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"L5J5OnsK","tags":["mcr","my chemical romance","killjoys","trans","transgender","ficlet","pp","kk","wb","gi","trans kobra","anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZFuPEt1QX2w8P","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":30,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Hello! Could I request a ficlet of Trans!Kobra binding with Ace bandages and one of the others finding out and freaking out and telling him that he shouldn't do that? :3","answer":"Suggest a ficlet!\n\n Kobra Kid took a roll of elastic bandages from the steel kitchen cabinet, then knelt down in front of the oven. He pulled off his yellow zebra-patterned shirt, then sucked in his breath and looked at his reflection in the oven door. After pressing an arm over his chest and seeing how it would look if it were flat, he glanced out the doorway. The main area was empty. Party Poison was still in the gas station, and Fun Ghoul and Jet Star were on their way to Zone Two. Kobra swallowed down his nerves, then unrolled the bandage.\n  [[MORE]]\n  Holding his breath, he wrapped the bandage once around his chest and pinned it into place, wincing when the safety pin jabbed his skin. When he exhaled, his chest ached from the tight compression. He wrapped the bandages around himself as closely as he could, pulling tight as if he were wrapping a Christmas present. His breathing grew restricted and the pain increased, but his chest looked flat in the oven reflection.\n\n  Just when he was about to snip off the bandage from the roll and pin it together, someone said “Kobra! No!” Kobra whirled around to see Poison standing in the doorway, wearing the blue gas station apron. “Shit, Kid, what are you doing?” he said, hurrying into the kitchen.\n\n  He looked down at his chest in confusion. “I’m just wrapping my chest,” he said. “To make it flatter. What? You didn’t think I was injured, did you?”\n\n  “Oh, no. It’s those bandages. You better take those off, Kid. Those could crack your ribs.”\n\n  Kobra’s eyes widened. “What? Seriously?”\n\n  “Yeah. They can be dangerous.” Poison crouched down beside him. “Come on, you better take them off. Do you need some help?”\n\n  “I think I’ve got it.” He unwound the bandages, then dropped them on the floor and wrapped his arms around his chest. The tight compression was gone, and he took a few deep lungfuls of air.\n\n  “It looked like you had them on pretty tight,” Poison said, winding the bandage around the roll. “That could’ve hurt you pretty badly.” Suddenly he paused. “You haven’t done this before, have you?”\n\n  “Oh, no,” Kobra said as he slipped his T-shirt back on. “This is the first time. I heard a couple of guys on the radio talking about it.”\n\n  “Well, don’t listen to them. D and I were talking about this a few months ago. He’s known kids that had to go to the medic’s after using these.” Once the bandage was rolled up, he said “I’ll call D later today. He might know somebody that can make you a binder.”\n\n  “Yeah? What’s that?”\n\n  Poison gestured around his chest. “It’s like an undershirt. It flattens your chest without hurting you. We’ll have to find someone that can sew one for you.”\n\n  “You sure that won’t be expensive?”\n\n  “Nah. It won’t be too bad.” He climbed to his feet, then said “C’mon. Let’s see if we can find a tight shirt or something.”\n\n  After opening the steel cabinet and digging around in the pile of T-shirts, jackets, long-sleeved shirts, and sweaters, Kobra unearthed a green T-shirt with a Frankuloid picture on the front. “Hey, I remember this,” he said, turning it back and forth. “I got it when I was fifteen. Think it’s small enough?”\n\n  “What’s the size?”\n\n  Kobra squinted at the faded tag. “Size A4.”\n\n  “Yeah, that’s tiny. Try it on.”\n\n  After taking off his yellow shirt, Kobra pulled the Frankuloid shirt over his head and squeezed his arms through the sleeves. It clung tightly to his body, but not enough to be painful. He slipped on the yellow shirt over it, then smoothed it down and examined his chest. It was flatter than it had been before.\n\n  “Yeah, that looks good,” Poison said, holding him at arm’s length. “Just wear that until we can get a binder, okay?”\n\n  “Yeah. Thanks, man. I probably would’ve ended up breaking a rib if you hadn’t come in.”\n\n  “No problem, kiddo.” He patted his shoulder. “Just let me know if you need help with this stuff, okay?”\n\n  “Will do. Thank you.”\n\n  Poison smiled at him. After closing the cabinet, Kobra joined him in the gas station, where he helped him figure out an order they needed to place. Despite the mild tightness around his chest, he felt freer than he had in a long time, and even smiled brightly at every customer that walked in.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"becoming-daniel","id":97190952330,"post_url":"http://becoming-daniel.tumblr.com/post/97190952330/today-i-decided-that-i-refuse-to-be-miserable-any","slug":"today-i-decided-that-i-refuse-to-be-miserable-any","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 03:07:33 GMT","timestamp":1410404853,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"h2PnP6Kv","tags":["ftm","ftm transgender","trans","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZMHoam1QX23sA","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"title":"","body":"today i decided that i refuse to be miserable any longer.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"twisted-witch","id":97190832375,"post_url":"http://twisted-witch.tumblr.com/post/97190832375/id-really-appreciate-a-non-dysphoric-trans-person","slug":"id-really-appreciate-a-non-dysphoric-trans-person","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 03:05:57 GMT","timestamp":1410404757,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"7RC9IKmv","tags":["trans","dysphoria","non dysphoric","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZPIi6u1QX1cZt","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"I’d really appreciate a non-dysphoric trans person explaining how they figured out they were trans. things"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZHDWqx1QWuusw","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"asking_name":"ruffleyourjimmies","asking_url":"http://ruffleyourjimmies.tumblr.com/","question":"Why do so many non-cis people see cis-people as being inherently ignorant or contemptible? I'm not at all saying that you do it, I don't really know if you do or not, but I've been noticing a bit of a pattern such as how \"cis-scum\" is a (seemingly) extremely common term and acting as if all cis-people are detestable seems to be a very common orientation. Again I'm not in any way insinuating that you partake in this but it just seems like people are trying to fight bigotry with bigotry.","answer":"yeah trans people who hate cis people by proxy are unfortunately some of the loudest voices within the tumblr movement and it’s fucked up because out of all the majority groups (straight, male, white, etc.) cis are the most varied as far as other characteristics that would make them clearly not bigoted - there are plenty of good cis social justice bloggers that don’t fuck up regularly and yet are shut down merely on the basis of their gender identity\n\nthey do this partially as a defense mechanism, which is somewhat understandable considering the real and present danger to many trans people in the real world (and sometimes even on this site from those few strangely bigoted blogs that exist despite the majority of this site being minorities)\n\nbut it’s not understandable if you toss out the phrase cissexist like damn confetti whenever you think it’ll bolster your argument. it’s not understandable to send hate to fucking thirteen year old cis girls on this site and making them think it’s a crime just because they’re not trans and/or don’t know everything about the identity (yes, this happened; can’t find the link right now but i’m sure some people on my dash remember hearing about this).\n\nit is not fucking okay. i’m not cis and i think a large number of my peers need to take a fucking step back and realize how little they’re accomplishing and how much damage they’re actually doing to how the movement is viewed.\n\nand i know some of them will cry “people already view the movement poorly! we’re not making it any worse!” but re: loudly cis-hating trans folk on this site, i promise you, you are. here, have an anecdote that may help you view your wrongness.\n\nmy college has started a brand new sorority (rather, some people are starting up the branch for our college finally) that is 100% by and for LGBT people/allies. some of the people in charge are doing a fantastic job recruiting by being welcoming and very civilly educating people when they see that they’re willing to learn. one of the recruiters, however, is very abrasive and at times aggressive to people who make mistakes in the learning process, and she’s having a harder time getting people to want to stay and better themselves and become a good part of the community. i get the anger behind it because being oppressed fucking sucks, yeah. it does. but we have to learn not to expect the worst from people, especially if they seem like they’re willing to improve. \n\nso…… yeah.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ray-chan-san","id":97187934315,"post_url":"http://ray-chan-san.tumblr.com/post/97187934315/a-little-art-set-i-put-together-than-im-kinda","slug":"a-little-art-set-i-put-together-than-im-kinda","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11
