02:18:00 GMT","timestamp":1410401880,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"vk4KHz2o","tags":["trans","transition","anti-flag","ivy","ryan","mtf"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZG7Wgt1QWpGow","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"I had a sub par day, let’s say, and nothing terrible even happened. It’s like- damn, my mind is so far ahead of my body, gender-wise. I know I want to be a woman, and I find it funny that I even once questioned such a thing. But my body is like… snails, turtles, sloths and other slow-moving creatures. Anyway, I don’t work this week, but I told my coworkers, half-jokingly, that I was going to come back a woman. My boss, the same one I made that post about earlier this year listing the many bigoted things he says, said basically “yeah, we know, we just didn’t know if you were going to have the surgery yet”. So, on one hand- fuck yeah, everyone knows, on the other- shit, I hope they don’t expect me to come back a completely different person, I mean, nothing can make me magically pass in a week, even ignoring the fact that I’m not going to have any surgeries for quite a while, if ever, I’m going to look mostly the same as the last time they saw me, and they’re gonna see just how terribly slow a gender transition is. Anyway, I just might be like “ok yall, I’m a chick now” and hope they understand.\n\nAnother thing about me- okay, I work with all het males mostly, and their jokes about me are pretty consistent- every night, at least a few times a night- somebody will say something regarding me being feminine or me liking men or something of that nature, often overtly sexual things. A lady who sometimes works with us came up to me one time and said “I really hope you kick their ass for some of the things they say about you”, I said that I don’t mind it, and in fact, I encourage them to talk that way. Because, at this point, I really don’t mind it, and I think it’s a way of them reacting to someone quite different from themselves in a not-overtly-hostile way while still managing to retain their status as a het male (and all trivial machismo crap that goes along with maleness), a status I gladly gave up long ago. Also, a few guys have told me one-on-one, stuff like “you know all that stuff we say about you…we don’t really mean that right?” and I ‘m like yeah, I’m cool with it, because I am.\n\nI was driving home tonight, and I listened to a song from Justin Sane’s solo album (which, tbqh, wasn’t that great) several times, the song that goes “i’m a boxer, I’m from the southside of town, and I’m the toughest motherfucker around”, on a side note- this is an instance where I like that his voice is high-pitched for a guy.. Ok, so I might not be the toughest of anything- nor do I want to be- but sometimes we can talk about ourselves better after a disappointing day and staring at an uncertain future, or some shit. I don’t really know where I’m going with this…do I wanna change my name to Ivy or keep it as Ryan or go by Rivy, I don’t know if I’m ready for a female name yet, it still feels like something I don’t deserve at this point I have to earn it. This has a been on ongoing theme in my transition- me thinking I’m not worthy of something yet. My therapist said “ya know, you could probably get away with going by Ryan” but she also thought Ivy was a cool name, so who knows, the name Rivy sounds cool too…. maybe want all three. Just like sometimes I wish I had a completely female body, and other times, I feel fine with a feminized male one.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"thenonbinarytrekkie","id":97186952928,"post_url":"http://thenonbinarytrekkie.tumblr.com/post/97186952928/if-each-one-of-my-followers-donated-20-to-my","slug":"if-each-one-of-my-followers-donated-20-to-my","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 02:17:19 GMT","timestamp":1410401839,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"pdKlScs1","tags":["top surgery","trans","transgender","non binary","transmasculine"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZCWYux1QWopRW","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"If each one of my followers donated $20 to my gofundme I’d reach my goal.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"hazardousprototype","id":97186788864,"post_url":"http://hazardousprototype.tumblr.com/post/97186788864/is-it-easier-to-lose-weight-when-you-are-on-t","slug":"is-it-easier-to-lose-weight-when-you-are-on-t","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 02:15:15 GMT","timestamp":1410401715,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Fo2i5ae1","tags":["ftm","trans","i have so many questions please help me"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Za3uGv1QWoBO0","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":7,"title":"","body":"is it easier to lose weight when you are on t?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"t-skittle","id":97186734014,"post_url":"http://t-skittle.tumblr.com/post/97186734014/so-yesterday-i-finally-did-it-i-transitioned-from","slug":"so-yesterday-i-finally-did-it-i-transitioned-from","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 02:14:31 GMT","timestamp":1410401671,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"k2fnIxbM","tags":["mtf","transgender","mtf trans","trans","comming out"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z2v8Lt1QWnz__","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"caption":"So yesterday I finally did it, I transitioned from Travis to Tristin. A transgender person’s gender is “on the opposite side” from the one which they were assigned at birth. Cis means “on the same side”, so cisgender people are on the same side as their assigned gender. You follow? Good.\n\nSo imagine if we didn’t look at a newborn’s genitals and immediately go “there, a penis; it’s a boy!” If that penis-having baby grew up to be a woman in the aforementioned society, she would not be a trans woman. We would not really have the need for trans/cis labels because there would be no assigned gender to oppose or side with. The person could perhaps still experience dysphoria and want to undergo surgery, but they would always have been considered a woman simply by the merit of their self-assertion as a woman. In this formula there would also be no truscum. No pathologizing of identity = no truscum.","can_reply":false}]

all","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"maliciouswolf","id":97181882414,"post_url":"http://maliciouswolf.tumblr.com/post/97181882414/i-tried-talking-to-my-aunt-about-my-gender","slug":"i-tried-talking-to-my-aunt-about-my-gender","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 01:13:06 GMT","timestamp":1410397986,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"5XKOZcUz","tags":["lgbt","transgender","trans","gay","lesbian","gender","gender queer","gender confused","ftm","noh8","pride","rant"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZBnRix1QWVTWk","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":20,"title":"","body":"I tried talking to my aunt about my gender confusion and to tell her that I may be transgender and honestly, some of the things that she said offended me. I know that she doesn’t know the ‘correct’ way to say things because she’s never really heard about transgender before (except for all the quote on quote ‘negative’ and stereotypical things.) it was as if she didn’t believe me. I told her things that not too many people know from my childhood as ‘proof’ that I am ACTUALLY feeling this way. how do you tell someone what they’re feeling isn’t valid??? I told her that I am more comfortable with myself than i have ever been in my life and she used that against me. she used “comfortable” as an excuse. she compared my comfortable to her comfortable of getting home from a 12 hour shift at work and lounging on her couch in pajamas all by herself. I tried to define my “comfortable” differently so she would comprehend it correctly and it was like talking to a wall. I then described it as feeling normal. normal in my boxers and baggier jeans. she didn’t know how to respond. I brought up the fact that I haven’t worn makeup in probably 3 months or so and she said she was well aware of it and was concerned. she was concerned that I would get “stuck in that phase.” she then went on to talk about me coming out as gay and how even though I was gay, I could still wear make up and be girly and shit and i got pissed and showed her plenty pictures of feminine lesbians and said that thats not how I want to look and that I am pretty damn cute the way I am right now. she compared me to being a dyke/ a butch. nothing wrong with either, but that is not how I see myself and is not how I would ever ‘label’ myself. She showed me pictures of an older friend of hers who is a lesbian and had short hair, no makeup and whatnot, as an example of what she fears i’ll end up like. guess what, the lady was fucking smiling. really smiling. shes happy, so who the fuck cares. I just hate that she fucking doubted the way that I have been feeling for months upon months. that she basically told me that this was all because I came out as gay. she also brought up some shit she supposedly learned in psychology; something like if you feel a certain way inside but cant/ don’t know how to let people know, you tend to reflect whatever it is on the outside that meets the stereotype. Example she told me: I had a secret that I liked girls but didn’t really let anyone nor knew how to, therefore, I became like the ‘stereotypical lesbian’ (whatever the fuck that is.) I began dressing differently, cut my hair, etc. she told me that I’m just fucking trying to FIT THE STEREOTYPE WHICH PISSED ME OFF SO MUCH HOLY FUCK. another thing that I hate when people say, which of course she said, is that I DON’T KNOW WHO I AM. I HAVEN’T HAD ENOUGH EXPERIENCE. i absolutely hate hate hate hate hearing those two things. it’s basically like telling me that the way i feel isn’t fucking valid and no one has the stupid fucking right to say that, ever. she then told me that I would ‘grow out’ of this in a few years. I’ll grow my hair back out, i’ll love to do my make up, i’ll be ‘back to normal.’ no. no. no. you don’t have the ability to predict my life. just because it would be easier for you to accept, doesn’t mean that’s whats going to happen. now, I will give her credit for a few positive things in this conversation; she told me that I would eventually develop into whoever I was supposed to be, and I said “yeah, even if I end up being transgender and becoming a boy.” and she smiled and said “correct. even if you do choose to.” she also advised me to not worry about it right now and to just be myself (which I have been doing and its great even though i feel restricted because of my mother) and that frankly, no body really gives a fuck what I label myself as. and I know I dont need to label myself, I’m just trying to understand what I’m feeling. It’s a constant battle in my brain over this. over who i am, who I want to be, and who I fear being. I hope that I can settle this debate with myself and be fully satisfied with whatever outcome and be surrounded by people who fully accept me. sorry for the rant, i’m sure 99.9% of you won’t read this.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"chutzpadik","id":97181800929,"post_url":"http://chutzpadik.tumblr.com/post/97181800929/female-and-male-are-gendered-in-exactly-the-same","slug":"female-and-male-are-gendered-in-exactly-the-same","type":"text","date":"2014-09-11 01:12:01 GMT","timestamp":1410397921,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"CNGOdrl6","tags":["noa.txt","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZuN1vn1QWV9dX","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":102,"title":"'female' and 'male' are gendered in exactly the same way as 'man' and 'woman' are 2k14","body":"stop misgendering trans ppl’s bodies","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"viceroy-bubbles-von-salamancer","id":97181473299,"post_url":"http://viceroy-bubbles-von-salamancer.tumblr.com/post/97181473299/cis-person-why-is-your-legal-name-different-from","slug":"cis-person-why-is-your-legal-name-different-from","type":"chat","date":"2014-09-11 01:07:45 GMT","timestamp":1410397665,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"p2CElniz","tags":["skeleton war","trans","transgender","preferred name","cis people","skeletons /","bones /","skulls /","just in case k?","war /","wars /","violence /","armies /","mothers /","parents /","death jic /"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZuzoPs1QWTveJ","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":36,"title":"","body":"Cis person: Why is your legal name different from the one you want me to use?\nMe: It was the name given to me when I was recruited for the Skeleton War.\nCis person: But it's not the name on your birth certificate....\nMe: I was recruited after the mortal vessel I call 'mother' brought me into this world and branded me with a human name. Hella yes","body":"","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"adventuresinlearning","id":97177862340,"post_url":"http://adventuresinlearning.tumblr.com/post/97177862340/brand-new-book-i-am-jazz-by-jessica-herthel","slug":"brand-new-book-i-am-jazz-by-jessica-herthel","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-11 00:18:25 GMT","timestamp":1410394705,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"bhnfhZyy","tags":["Education","gender","trans","transgender","books","kids","I am jazz","laverne Cox","Jazz Jennings"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZfO8Wy1QWG834","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":95,"caption":"BRAND NEW Book!\n\nI Am Jazz by   Jessica Herthel Summery: \n\nI Am Jazz is the story of a transgender child based on the real-life experience of Jazz Jennings, who has become a spokesperson for trans kids everywhere.\n\nFrom the time she was two years old, Jazz knew that she had a girl’s brain in a boy’s body. She loved pink and dressing up as a mermaid and didn’t feel like herself in boys’ clothing. This confused her family, until they took her to a doctor who said that Jazz was transgender and that she was born that way. Jazz’s story is based on her real-life experience and she tells it in a simple, clear way that will be appreciated by picture book readers, their parents, and teachers.\n\nThis new book is awesome! Glad Gender is becoming more of a nuance conversation! Great to think kids can have a book to help them feel more at home in their body! Excited to get this for our class. We are very sensitive to this in our class and we are hoping to create a community in our class that in open to any identity that students feel good about themselves. The class is Gender, Class and Race in Media. The course description is as follows: “Course description and purpose: An examination of mass media portrayals of gender and race, from years past to present. Students will analyze media artifacts, identify recurring themes, and explore research about the societal effects of stereotypical media portrayals. By the end of this class the student will be able to interrogate and discuss the power, presence and difficulties concerning the representations of minorities in American mass media.”\n\nThe important part though is that I’m looking for pieces that fall under the course purpose, but also discuss transgender people, identity and/or politics.\n\nThis is in an effort to alleviate transphobia and transmisogyny being taught, so if you have any resources, please let me know!\n\nThanks you so gender is complicated and I’m a demiboy.<!-- more -->I am twenty years old. That means that for five years now, I’ve identified as a trans boy. I’m twenty years old now and gender… gender is complicated.\n\nI grew up knowing I wasn’t a girl. For me, as a young teen in the midwest with a limited understanding of gender, sexuality, and identity, “not a girl” meant “boy.” There simply were no other options. Not that I really minded - for me, “not a girl” was (and continues to be) the most important, and quite possibly the only, marker of gender that meant anything to me. I experience dysphoria entirely because I’m not a girl and being seen as one or seeing myself as one causes me significant discomfort. To me at age 15, this meant that I must be a boy. To me now, this seems more indicative of something of which I’m becoming increasingly aware - I don’t really understand gender all that well, nor does it matter to me overmuch.\n\nI identify with the word “boy.” I also identify with the words “small,” “cute,” “neuroatypical,” “student,” and “queer,” and honestly, I can’t decide which means the most to me. I do not, on the other hand, identify with the words “girl,” “normal,” “man,” or “rude.” I’m not sure how important gender is to me at all, beyond the fact that I’m not a girl. I do know that a binary male identity doesn’t fit as well with who I am as I previously thought.\n\nAll that exposition, dear friends, leads us to the fact that I am somewhat a boy and somewhat… not. Halfway between boy and agender. I’m twenty years old, gender is complicated, and I’m a fucking mirror in and split my knuckles on the glass. I hate being trans. I hate my body. I hate that these pictures aren’t even for me. Because if it was I wouldnt even take them unless I got the suit. I would be like I never existed senior year which is fine by me. But I can’t and I have to take them. I hate that i have ro sit there and smile like everything is fucking okay. When its not; its really not. Im stuck there trying to amile like i enjoy this and inside im crying because the words repeat over and over that these arent for you theyre something we want to give out to the family… I hate that I cant tell my mom who was really concerned on the phone why taking the pictures bothered me so much and I hate that my dad is so fucking concerned about how the family looks on the outside to care about the hurtful shit he says. I dont hate my family hate is for no one. But I cant love them either because once I come out I wouldnt be able to take the pain of losing people you love. Im sorry for the rant I’ll go back to happy blogging and cheer you guys and me up if your having a bad day. This just really sucked.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"inadistantworld","id":97169521597,"post_url":"http://inadistantworld.tumblr.com/post/97169521597/tomorrow-around-2-there-will-be-a-knock-on-the","slug":"tomorrow-around-2-there-will-be-a-knock-on-the","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 22:22:35 GMT","timestamp":1410387755,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"JbFDnscU","tags":["genderfluid","ftm","trans*","trans","genderqueer","boy","nikolai","binder"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z10foo1QVmJkz","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"Tomorrow around 2 there will be a knock on the door. I’ll open it and see a guy in a UPS outfit holding a package. He’ll hand it off and walk away, not thinking about what was in the package, not caring about how I feel about that package. I’ll open it up and there will be a nude colored binder. And I’ll probably freak out from fear and nerves and excitement. Because this is going to feel so right, but I don’t know how to do this on my own. I don’t know what I’m doing anymore. But I’ll finally be flat. He pushed me and pushed me and pushed me to be comfortable to be out to say my name when people asked. He taught me how to pack, how to dress to conceal curves. He pushed me to get boy pants because I was scared but I wanted them. And he told me to get a binder but I was worried about my parents. And the one time I really was going to get one but needed that extra push, that little bit more to get me to buy one, he just brushed it off and said ‘Get one’ and proceeded to talk about what he was doing and how he was. Like it didn’t matter. So I didn’t get one. And then he left and I was shrinking away, becoming less than what I was, trying to push Nikolai back into the hole he was in before, but obviously he had grown too big and I couldn’t fit him all in there. And my friends gave me that push I needed to buy this binder. My friends said it would be good for me. Not him. My friends talked me through it. And now I bought it and it’s coming and I’m terrified because I’m still not what I was. I’m still trying to fit any piece of my boy life back in that hole. I’m still afraid. I still need someone like him to say I’m a prince when I feel like a boy, not a princess, to fully see me as male, no questions asked. I don’t have anyone like that now, he was the only one. And now I’m doubting myself and I don’t know what to do. But I ordered it and for at least a minute I’m going to feel right. I’m going to be flat. He was my confidence, and now I have to figure out how to be everything he was for When we first started, we got 200 followers in the first week!\n\nI love each and every one of you, and I don’t want to suggest you’re not enough. But I really do think this blog can be helpful to a lot of folks. I’ve reblogged thing about this, and talked about it a little: there’s a lot of trans folks who identify with and find strength in monsters, and it’s nice for us to connect with each other over a shared appreciation for monster characters, art, and stories.\n\nSo I’m looking for ideas on how to get our existence out there to more non-binary and/or genderless folks. always been the following:\n\nAhoy there, I’m Holly! Pleased to meet you :) I’m a pre-everything trans woman…in other words no, I’m not on hormones, no I haven’t had any surgeries. If you’re still reading this, then I’m guessing you don’t have a problem with that (and if you DO have a problem with that…get over yourself :D )\n\nI stuck it in there first because I figured it would save me some annoying conversations later.\n\nWhat I actually found was that it was doing one of three things:\n\n1. Putting lots of people off - This is a good thing, obviously, because it means most of the time, if people aren’t interested in a relationship with a trans girl they will leave me alone\n\n2. Bring in perverts - Not sure if this is specifically to do with trans or just for being female. Either way, I get a small amount of pervert messages.\n\n3. Invite ‘allies’ to ask questions - I’ve had so called allies message me and start asking me if I was depressed as a child and if I’ll have surgery. Nice.\n\nAnyway, my profile is several paragraphs. Not a lot of reading, but more than most people I guess. community can be doing to prevent suicides of people struggling with gender identity. I am just as guilty as anyone. Handwringing can only go so far. Last weekend I started the process of volunteering for the Trevor Project. It is a very small step but a lot of small efforts from many people can make a BIG difference.\n\nI also think that, for those of us in the trans community, it is good for us all to stop at least this one time of year and look at how we are talking about suicide amongst ourselves. It is a subject that at times needs to be acknowledged and discussed, but when it does it must be done mindfulness—both for the people who are listening to our words and also for our own selves so that we are aware of how to keep our own mental wellness when we are engaged in these conversations.\n\nI know that some LGBT and Trans-focused organizations and individuals have done a lot of advocacy in this area year round. I have named the Trevor Project, but there are others out there. I would appreciate it if you know of any of these resources to please reply to this thread with information as I would like to compile as many as I can and make them available online.\n\nThere are a few other things that I would like to see happen and am willing to be involved in creating if I can find a few partners.\n\nI think someone might have already done this but I can’t find it (again—please send me links or contact info if you know where it is.) I think that there needs to be some readily accessible guidelines for how members of the trans community might want to think about when talking about suicide. I have watched countless threads on internet forums where a gender questioning visitor (usually a young person or, increasingly, children) will ask if they should start the process of transition. In most of these threads a number of respondents (much older adults) will immediately tell that person that they will likely get to the same point that they themselves did - ready to get a gun out and pull the trigger. I really do believe that we are helping “normalize” suicide within the trans community by speaking of it so often especially in occasions such as this. (If anyone is familiar with trans forums they will know exactly what I am talking about.) For many, I believe that this moment of very seriously contemplating or (in many cases) attempting suicide has almost become part of the Trans Mythos - a story of rebirth out of the debris of a life that had been there before. I am not here to discount those stories. I believe most of them are true. I even have one myself. But I believe that for those of us in the older “trans generations” can help younger generations find a new narrative, and set a tone where suicide is not something that is presented to someone right as they are “walking in the door” as it were. Let’s be mindful in our speech. \n\nI sometimes search for the term “detransition” on social media because that is something that I am STILL struggling through. So many of the results I get are along the lines of “I would rather kill myself than detransition”. I totally support the right of people to say that, but just keep in mind that for someone trying to hold their detransition together seeing this stuff online does have an impact and will have consequences of one form or another. If you need to say it, do say it. But maybe it is something you need to be saying to a therapist instead of shouting blindly out into the internet.\n\nA lot of trans people use social media to make suicide threats. I think it is a good thing that they are at least calling out for help. Many in the trans community rally around to assist these people in their time of crisis to keep them talking and distracted enough so that the suicidal moment will pass. Again, I would like to see guidelines for how these conversations should be conducted. Maybe this is already out there on the net (I know there are a number of things for the general population and I will be gathering those as well as publishing them.) If anyone has anything they can let me know about I would appreciate it. \n\nThe reason why guidelines are important here is twofold - both equally important. Firstly, it is important to know how best to interact with someone in this situation and how to make sure that they are safe and will ensure that they connect with the resources and professionals who it is critical they speak to. Secondly, and just as important, how to keep one’s self healthy in the process. Talking to someone about suicide can be extremely draining and, if not done mindfully, can seriously impact the “helper’s” own mental wellness. Boundaries are really important here. I think a lot of people don’t really take care of themselves when they are trying to help others.\n\nOne of the resources available to anyone in the US is the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ Their phone number is 1-800-273-8255. For those who are not familiar with how the crisis line operates, it is a federally funded non profit organization that serves as a coordination point for 165 independent crisis centers through out the country, fielding calls from people in crisis. If you are trans and in crisis, this could be a good resource for you if you are unable to find anyone else to talk about.\n\nI deliberately used the word “could” because right now I know that a lot of trans people will not call this number because they feel that the people answering the calls will not be sensitive to their trans identities. I was curious about this so I reached out to the training department (in another lifetime I used to do training and quality control for a group of call centers so I am interested in this stuff.) I was surprised to learn that they have not received any guidelines on how to handle trans* identified people in crisis. (This is what I was told—if this is not the case, again someone please let me know.)\n\nWhen I first approached the training department, I believe they thought I was suggesting some sort of intensive new training curriculum for “all things trans” that I wanted the crisis line and all of its independently affiliated call centers to adopt. This is not the case. I think it can be as simple as a one sheet page of things to be mindful. I think that there is probably a way of establishing that when a caller in crisis comes through that caller is immediately given the confidence that they will be treated with the dignity and lack of judgement that is their birthright. It is also important to find a solution to “neutralize” the negative impact that a callers perception of being “misgendered” might have on them. For those call centers (or individual counselors) who have difficulty using the caller’s prefered pronouns, a few tips for effective “gender neutral” communication would be extremely helpful. It goes without saying that crisis counselors should not attempt to ”counsel” the caller’s actual gender identity struggles. I think a reminder in guidelines would be helpful.\n\nI would like to work with others to put together such guidelines. I believe I can offer some valuable input, but I do not have the expertise to do this alone. Additionally this really needs to be put together by a diverse but unified group of stakeholders. If anyone would like to assist me in this or has recommendations of people I can approach to partner with please let me know j@retransition.org.\n\nThere is no guarantee that the National Suicide Prevention Crisis Line would follow these guidelines—but I say it is at least worth a try and I believe these may be useful for other non LGBT-specific points of contact for people in crisis. \n\nAlso, I am hoping that some of the more prominent activists out there will build awareness that, yes, being referred to as one’s affirmed gender is important, getting “misgendered” is not the end of the world—especially in matters of life or death. I believe that if the gravity and catastrophizing of getting “misgendered” was de-escalated a bit a lot of our trans family would find more wellness. \n\nAnd speaking of “wellness”, there is one last point I want to make. I have watched over the last ten years as the subject of “mental health” has been purposely driven from the larger conversation we are having about trans issues today. This is also happening at the therapeutic level—so many who express feelings of gender confusion actually lose potentially helpful psychological assistance because of the fear on the part of many providers that to dig a little deeper looking at and working through potential root causes for GID would be to dishonor their patient. A false equivalence has been set up between the unspeakable and unnecessary damage done by so-called “reparative therapy” to some members of the LGB population with spending a little bit of time with a client presenting with gender identity issues to look for what really might be going on. I believe that it is possible to live in a world where we acknowledge that being gender non-conforming is a perfectly valid (and quite possibly immutable) foundation of many people’s identities, while also recognizing that some cross-gender behavior and ruminations can also be a red flag for something much more serious going on in the background.\n\nAnd that is the final point I want to make. We all know that the suicide rate (and the number of people who have at least contemplated it) is unacceptably high in the trans community. A lot of this IS situational. The effects of bigotry and discrimination due have their cumalative toll and there is no doubt they have been a contributing factor to some trans people’s arrival at a place where they felt they truly had no more options. Again, practicing steps toward mental wellness can be helpful here, as well as the continued efforts to promote a more tolerant and compassionate world. But I also strongly believe that there are also many deaths within our community that actually have little to do with being trans. What makes me frustrated is that I believe that many of these are preventable, but because mental illness has now been deliberately stigmatized even further in the trans community than it is for the general population (where it already carries a huge stigma all on its own) these people are slipping through the cracks. \n\nI say it is time to step forward to work toward building an environment that is safer for all and is even more respecting of everyone’s dignity. My fellow detransitioner thirdwaytrans is trying to untangle some of this in his website. Again, I know there are others out there (again, please let me know of any that you are familiar with.) In the coming days I too will be launching a website devoted to trans mental health based on some of what I have described here. It will be simple—it is just meant as another signpost for those who are struggling to find their way. In my case, my own path involved detransition, but I know this is certainly not for everyone so that is why I am planning on this second site that only focuses on trans mental health. My hope is to be one of many trans related sites that remind those who are suffering that we always have more options in life than we realize. We are never really “stuck” as long as we are here in this world alive today. \n\nI hope you join me in this conversation.\n\nJoel\nSurvivor","image_permalink":"http://retransition.tumblr.com/image/97161661248","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":1280,"height":439,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_1280.png"},{"width":500,"height":171,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_500.png"},{"width":400,"height":137,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_400.png"},{"width":250,"height":86,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_250.png"},{"width":100,"height":34,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_100.png"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_75sq.png"}],"original_size":{"width":1280,"height":439,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/72bbe4a024d95eb3ef3b3d5bb9397591/tumblr_nbpdbrx79j1siqeg0o1_1280.png"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"glaminthebox","id":97161294208,"post_url":"http://glaminthebox.tumblr.com/post/97161294208/i-swear-these-two-hate-their-photo-anywhere-but","slug":"i-swear-these-two-hate-their-photo-anywhere-but","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 experience"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZshbAw1QVCPI_","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"About trans* and LGB+ health care.","body":"This came up on my fb feed:\n\nMost of the comments are all “there’s no need for this!!! We all have the same needs!” and going about how it sounds like segregation.\n\nMost of them have forgotten trans people again.\n\nI think most of the people here understand how difficult it could be for a trans woman to go to get her prostate checked or for a trans male to get a pap smear.\n\nMost of the people probably just think “well, suck it up and go to the doctor, it can’t be that bad” while it actually is bad enough for us to avoid them, it’s not that simple.\n\nThe doctors don’t usually know what to do with a trans person who has been taking hormones for years and suddenly they’ve started getting their periods/spotting or anything else related to reproductive organs.\n\nThey haven’t been trained for those cases. I have had a doctor who didn’t even know that it’s possible to have reproductive organs removed without having a cancer or other dangerous reason for it.\n\nAnd I want to tell something from a personal experience that could have been solved in a so much easier way if we had a hospital that was specialized in trans people:\n\nDuring the summer my periods stopped. I haven’t gone on T yet and I were happy about not getting my periods, because periods are something I don’t want to think about ever let alone deal with.\n\nBut they were replaced with this continuous pain. It wasn’t as bad as period cramps, but it hurt and sometimes when I stood up I couldn’t stand because the pain became sharp and strong.\n\nIt didn’t stop during the summer but I didn’t want to go to a gynecologist. This is countryside and all of the doctors that work in the reproductive health side are really clueless about trans people. They don’t even realize that misgendering trans people is wrong.\n\nSo of course I refused to go to the doctor. I knew I’d have to go to a gynecologist if I went there. \n\nI dealt with the pain for months. My pain meds didn’t work and I admit that I were terrified about possibly having a cancer (there have been quite a lot of cancer cases in my family).\n\nI never went to the doctor and turns out the reason why my periods stopped was that I didn’t eat enough (my body had gone in to the starvation mode). That would have been solved so much quicker and easier by just going to a doctor but going there is a straight-up hell for me because of their unawareness about trans people.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"t3hsiggy","id":97159994200,"post_url":"http://t3hsiggy.tumblr.com/post/97159994200","slug":"","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 20:16:02 Except T shirts and gym shorts or sweatpants? And I just feel like utter shit and like I don’t belong anywhere and like even the majority of other trans dudes don’t understand me because yeah I’m on T but no my results aren’t like yours and it seems like the misgendering will be endless\n\nI’m scared to do interviews for jobs, like I hate the idea of leaving my house at all 98% of the time, even for school or groceries\n\nDysphoria is impeding every aspect of my life and it’s turning into self loathing like I haven’t felt since when I was a fucking preteen / early adolescent getting hospitalized for my anxiety and depression\n\nI renting","id":97156961125,"post_url":"http://trans-parenting.tumblr.com/post/97156961125/the-advocate-had-an-article-today-on","slug":"the-advocate-had-an-article-today-on","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 19:34:00 GMT","timestamp":1410377640,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"y5rHnKWR","tags":["transparenting","trans","transgender","transmasculine","art","photography","gender","gender identity","gender expression","Chris Rijksen"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnO4pr1QV0PDb","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":42,"caption":"The Advocate had an article today on transmasculine Dutch artist Chris Rijksen’s latest work “Gender as Performance.” \n\nGender as performance is an interesting topic for someone like me, whose sex, gender identity, and expression do not always line up. In some ways it feels shallow to imagine that such a core part of my identity is just about performance, but when you consider “gender performance” as more than just clothes and as something we all engage in (consciously or not), it becomes a little more nuanced and complex. We all have range and variance in our identities, we all deal with the difference between our own expression and others’ perceptions, and we all negotiate the expectations (on our appearance & behavior) of different spaces and contexts.\n\nThis quote from the article in particular stuck out to me in thinking along those lines:\n\n\"Some people ask me which one of the pictures I identify most with. This is a funny question, since the goal of my photo series was to go beyond this unambiguous \"real\" identity and to propose a multitude of possible identities. I do not believe in one form of identity. The spectator most likely projects its own framework of identity on the person in front of them, whether it is a photograph or a real person.\n\nWith my photos I ask viewers to reconsider the fixed recognising my existence the right way.\n\n People also seem to be staring at me a lot less…this feels reaaally good, I no longer feel like a freak who bothers them or like an outcast etc etc walking in the streets without getting wierd looks is like the best thing ever it makes me feel a bit more free„, dont get me wrong though, some people will still stare at me but they are really much much less now so its ok :)\n\n Physical changes continue to develop steadily, Im pleased, next week I have an endo appointment,she said to me 3 months ago that she might put me in a higher dose (that would be awesome)\nMentally there is no change, Im still a very emotional 12 years old girl.\n\n My next huge step would be having people see me as a girl in my university,it starts in october,I ll try my best to have a convincing female appearance,i ll let you know what happens…\n\n I also plan to have vfs soon and change my name after that (man no words can explain the dysphoria my old name gives me Please","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"fairyjerbear","id":97154481197,"post_url":"http://fairyjerbear.tumblr.com/post/97154481197/toronto-school-board-member-is-finally-called-out-for","slug":"toronto-school-board-member-is-finally-called-out-for","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 18:57:02 GMT","timestamp":1410375422,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"nbvswIig","tags":["LGBTQ rights","school board","Toronto","trans","transgender","Transphobia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-YGat1QUsxmj","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"Toronto School Board Member Is Finally Called Out For Anti-Gay Rants, Is Left Speechless | ThinkProgress","body":"Toronto School Board Member Is Finally Called Out For Anti-Gay Rants, Is Left Speechless | ThinkProgress\n\nPoliticians with anti-LGBTQ attitudes increasingly are finding that homophobia and transphobia are no longer acceptable to large swathes of the voting public, particularly in urban areas. In this case it was a politicians negative idea about transgender people that landed him in hot water. Here’s the story from ZACK FORD writing for Think Progress…\n\n“Toronto School Board Member Is Finally Called…\n\nView On WordPress","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"supertsean","id":97154403383,"post_url":"http://supertsean.tumblr.com/post/97154403383/just-self-injected-like-a-boss","slug":"just-self-injected-like-a-boss","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 18:55:44 GMT","timestamp":1410375344,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"338OYAIN","tags":["ftm","trans","t","testosterone","transman","three weeks"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZVXKom1QUsemt","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"caption":"Just self-injected like a boss.","image_permalink":"http://supertsean.tumblr.com/image/97154403383","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":960,"height":960,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_1280.jpg"},{"width":500,"height":500,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":400,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":250,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":100,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":960,"height":960,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/daf5d9a31110b1ca00cc03c51836876d/tumblr_nbp8kwKLLH1tj1liko1_1280.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"be-up-in-arms","id":97154045661,"post_url":"http://be-up-in-arms.tumblr.com/post/97154045661/feminismus-der-bei-der-muschi-aufhort","slug":"feminismus-der-bei-der-muschi-aufhort","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 18:50:00 GMT","timestamp":1410375000,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"vbBulD8c","tags":["feminismus","gender","sexismus","terf","trans","Transsexualität","transgender","sheila jeffries","gender hurts","transphobie","transphobia"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-_oDo1QUrHRT","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"title":"Feminismus, der bei der Muschi aufhört","body":"Mein heutiger Post bezieht sich auf einen Beitrag der feministischen Website „Die Störenfriedas“, der bei mir nicht auf sehr viel Zustimmung gestoßen ist (http://diestoerenfriedas.de/gender-hurts-von-sheila-jeffriesroutledge-verlag-oder-gender-tut-weh-und-transgender-auch/). Da mich das, was da so geschrieben wurde, ziemlich nervt, wird dieser Text wahrscheinlich recht lang. \n\nDer Beitrag ist im Grunde eine Inhaltszusammenfassung des Buchs „Gender Hurts“ von Sheila Jeffries, wobei dem Inhalt des Buchs kritiklos zugestimmt wird. Im folgenden zitiere ich aus dem Artikel und stelle den Zitaten meine Meinung gegenüber. \n\nEine kurze Begriffserklärung für die, die sich damit noch nicht auskennen:\n\nTransfrau: Eine Frau, die bei der Geburt als „männlich“ eingestuft wurde\n\nTransmann: Ein Mann, der bei der Geburt als „weiblich“ eingestuft wurde\n\nCisfrau: Eine Frau, die bei der Geburt als „weiblich“ eingestuft wurde\n\nCismann: Ein Mann, der bei der Geburt als „männlich“ eingestuft wurde\n\nDer Beitrag ist betitel mit „Gender Hurts - und Transgender auch“. Das hat mich stutzig gemacht. Dass Gender, also die gesellschaftlich fabrizierte Vorstellung von Geschlecht, „wehtut“, dieser Meinung bin ich auch. Ohne diese festen Vorstellungen, wie Männer bzw. Frauen sein sollten, oder dass es nur diese beiden Geschlechter gibt, wären wir alle besser dran. Aber Transsexualität tut doch niemandem weh. Oder?\n\nDer Text beginnt mit einer kurzen Einführung zum Begriff Gender und Transsexualität. \n\nSheila Jeffries argumentiert, dass „Gender“ Menschen und die Gesellschaft verletzt („Gender Hurts“). Das Konzept von Gender unterstützt ihrer Meinung nach die Idee, dass es so etwas wie ein natürliches Geschlecht gibt, mit einer dazugehörigen Psyche und Verhaltensmustern, die genau zu Menschen mit bestimmten Körpern passen.\n\nSo weit, so gut. Doch dann begann der Text für mich ziemlich schräg zu klingen: \n\nAus der feministischen Perspektive aber ist Gender die Basis für das politische System männlicher Dominanz. Oder einfacher gesagt: ohne Transgender gäbe es kein Gender. Transgender unterstützt die Idee stereotyper Geschlechterrollen. Die Grundlage des Feminismus ist es aber, dass Frauen unabhängig sind von männlicher Definition von Weiblichkeit.\n\nOhne Transsexualität gäbe es kein Gender? Ich will mich ja nicht zur Wissenschaftlerin aufschwingen, aber der Anteil der Transmenschen an jedweder Bevölkerung ist äußerst gering. (Auf Wikipedia spricht man z.B. von 0,01%). Und so eine kleine Gruppe, so eine Mini-Minderheit, soll dafür verantwortlich sein, dass die komplette restliche Bevölkerung an das Konzept Gender glaubt? Wow, diese Transleute müssen ja wirklich ganze Arbeit leisten. \n\nDieses Buch wurde von ihr als notwendig erachtet, da bezüglich der Idee von Transgender eine Normalisierung eintrat. \n\nIch weiß ja nicht, in welcher schönen neuen Welt die Autorin lebt, aber hierzulande kann man leider definitiv nicht von einer „Normalisierung“ von Transsexualität sprechen. Fragen Sie mal Leute auf der Straße, wie viele Transsexuelle die kennen. \n\nEs ist für Feministinnen wichtig zu wissen, ob jemand behauptet eine Frau zu sein, obwohl nur stereotype Ideen des Frauseins propagiert werden. \n\nHier wird darauf angespielt, dass Transfrauen keine Frauen sind, sondern dies nur behaupten. Und wenn ich als Cisfrau behaupte, eine Frau zu sein? Wollt ihr in meiner Unterhose nachgucken, ob meine Geschlechtsteile das Gütesiegel „original biologisch weiblich“ verdienen? Wollen wir jetzt allen Frauen misstrauen, ob sie „richtige“ Frauen sind, und solche, die ein kantigeres Gesicht oder vermehrten Haarwuchs haben, erst mal verdächtigen, ein Mann zu sein?\n\nEin (sic!) begünstigender Faktor für den Transgenderaktivismus sieht Sheila Jeffries in der Entwicklung und Nutzung des Internets. Durch das Internet konnten Männer sich für ihre besonderen sexuellen Interessen zusammenschließen. \n\nBitte was? Transsexualität ist kein „besonderes sexuelles Interesse“ oder ein Fetisch. Es handelt sich dabei um die Geschlechtsidentität einer Person. Geschlechtsidentität und sexuelle Neigungen haben nix miteinander zu tun.\n\nAuch die Gruppe Body Integrity Identity Disorder (BIID), die Amputationen über Gliedmaßen suchen. (…) BIID und TG ähneln sich, laut Jeffries, da beide für sexuelle Befriedigung sorgen (und sicherlich möchten auch beide Körperteile entfernen und können sich nicht mir ihren vorhandenen Körpern identifizieren).\n\nAuch hier ist es wieder unklar, woher Sheila Jeffreys das Wissen zieht, dass bei Transleuten die „sexuelle Befriedigung“ im Vordergrund steht – sicherlich nicht aus persönlichen Gesprächen mit Betroffenen. Da ich cis bin, kann ich nicht für Transleute sprechen, aber ich habe eine Menge Texte von ihnen gelesen, und in keinem von ihnen wurde Transsexualität als sexuelle Neigung beschrieben. \n\nNoch dazu möchte ich sagen, dass Transmenschen nicht in erster Linie das Bedürfnis haben, sich Körperteile entfernen zu lassen. Eine Transfrau möchte sich nicht aus Spaß den Penis entfernen lassen, sondern sie möchte eine Vulva bzw. Vagina. \n\nUnd wer, bitte, geht auf Grund eines rein sexuellen Fetischs so weit, sich die Geschlechtsteile operieren zu lassen? Transleute machen das, weil sie darunter leiden, den falschen Körper zu haben.\n\n  Die Transgenderidee wurde, ihrer (Sheila Jeffreys’) Ansicht nach, aus ähnlichen Gründen (wie die Idee der Homosexualität) geschaffen, denn sie trennt nicht akzeptables Genderverhalten von akzeptablem Genderverhalten. Das Nichteinhalten von Geschlechterrollen könnte nämlich das hierarchische System der Geschlechter bedrohen. \n\nNochmal: Transleute haben sich das Konzept der Transsexualität nicht ausgedacht, um damit die Gender-Ideologie oder das Patriarchat zu unterstützen. Ich habe das Gefühl, hier müssten mal ein paar grundlegende Punkte zum Thema Transgender angesprochen werden: Transleute sind Menschen, deren Geschlecht nicht mit dem übereinstimmt, was ihnen bei der Geburt zugeschrieben wurde. Damit alle sehen können, zu welchem Geschlecht sie wirklich gehören, bedienen sie sich Möglichkeiten wie zb. der Hormontherapie oder zum Beispiel auch geschlechterspezifischer Kleidung wie Krawatten oder High Heels, damit die Botschaft auch wirklich bei jedem ankommt. Wollt ihr wirklich den Transleuten vorwerfen, dass sie nicht androgyn gestylt sind? (Abgesehen davon, dass es auch nicht-binäre Transleute gibt.)\n\nHeute werden die, die zu anderen Zeiten als homosexuell gesehen wurden und cross-dressing machten, als Transgender bezeichnet.\n\nEine homosexuelle Person, die cross-dressing betreibt, ist nicht transsexuell, sondern eine homosexelle Person, die cross-dressing betreibt. Ist das denn so schwer zu unterscheiden? Zum Beispiel kann ein Transvestit (oft als Drag Queen bezeichnet) ein schwuler Cismann sein. Nur weil ich homo bin und gern mal nonkonforme Klamotten anzieh, bin ich doch nicht gleich trans. BTW: Das wissen die Betroffenen immer noch am besten – und nicht irgendwelche anderen Leute. \n\n  Die Kunden der Geschlechtsumwandlungsoperationen waren mehrheitlich männlich. (…) Männliche Kunden fallen in zwei Kategorien: homosexuelle Männer, die sich unfähig fühlten Männer zu lieben solange sie selbst Männer waren, und heterosexuelle Männer, die transgendern um ihr cross-dressing zu einem neuen Höhepunkt zu bringen. 2-3% aller Männer empfindet sexuelle Erregung durch das Tragen von Frauenkleidung. \n\nDiese Statements sind doch völlig an den Haaren herbeigezogen. Ein schwuler Mann ist doch nicht das gleiche wie eine Hetera-Frau. Außerdem: „Crossdressing zu einem neuen Höhepunkt bringen“ und „eine komplizierte und teure OP, langwierige Hormontherapie und gesellschaftlichen Hass in Kauf nehmen“ sind nicht das gleiche. Nochmal: Warum sollte jemand das aus Spaß machen?\n\nWeiter wird der Soziologe Ekins erwähnt, der darlegt, dass einige Männer zum Beispiel vom Gefühl einen BH auf der Haut zu spüren, sexuell erregt sind. (…)\n\nKlar gibt es das. Aber das sind nicht Transfrauen. In diesem Artikel wird Transfrauen abgesprochen, eine „richtige“ Weiblichkeit zu besitzen; Transfrauen sind offensichtlich in Wirklichkeit nur „perverse“ Männer. \n\nDurch diese sexuelle Erregung erklärt sich Sheila Jeffries auch, wieso es Transgender Mann-zu-Frau so wichtig ist in die Toilette für Frauen zu gehen. Die sexuelle Erregung entsteht vor allem dadurch die unterwürfige Position einer Frau zu erlangen, sozusagen entmännlicht zu sein.\n\nEin heißer Tip von mir: Transfauen ist es daher so wichtig, auf die Frauentoilette zu gehen, weil sie Frauen sind. Und weil sie ihr ganzes Leben lang fürchten müssen, als Mann angesehen zu werden, gehen sie dann sicherlich nicht aufs Männerklo.\n\nAußerdem muss ich jetzt als Frau mal sagen: So erniedrigend ist es jetzt auch nicht, ne Frau zu sein.\n\nInsbesondere das Transgendern von Kindern ist durch die Normalisierung des Transgendern von Erwachsenen zunehmende Praxis geworden. Kindern soll die Qual einer Pubertät im falschen Körper erspart bleiben.(…) Ihre Reproduktionsrechte werden hierdurch auch noch beschnitten, denn sie werden durch die frühe Behandlung unfruchtbar und können diese Entscheidung als Erwachsene nicht mehr rückgängig machen.\n\nAuch hier frage ich mich, in welcher Welt die Autorin lebt. Wo ist es bitte „normal“, dass Kinder, also bis zu 12jährige junge Menschen, einer geschlechtsumwandelnden Operation unterzogen werden? Wenn ein Kind der Meinung ist, trans zu sein, zieht man normalerweise – WENN die Eltern nicht transphob sind! – in der Pubertät eine reversible Hormontherapie in Betracht (Bart/Brustwachstum etc). Und ganz ehrlich: Die Akzeptanz für Transkinder ist nicht besonders groß und ihnen wird auch nicht besonders oft geglaubt, dass sie trans sind. \n\nPartnerinnen von Männern, die zu Frauen transgendern, werden auch beschrieben. In diesem Zusammenhang findet der Fokus auf sich selbst und auf die eigenen Bedürfnisse, der Egoismus der Männer, besondere Erwähnung.\n\nWie oft soll ich eigentlich noch sagen, dass „Männer, die zu Frauen transgendern“ Frauen sind. Frauen. Transfrauen, ja, aber: Frauen. Und ich finde es auch nicht besonders egoistisch, wenn diese den Wunsch haben, den ungemeinen Leidensdruck, der sich daraus ergibt, als das falsche Geschlecht wahrgenommen zu werden, zu beenden. \n\n  Frauen die transgendern werden als völlig anderes Phänomen gesehen als Männer die transgendern, denn sie wechseln in der Hierarchie nach oben zu den Männern und erhöhen somit ihren Status. \n\nNur komisch, dass das von den Transleuten selbst überhaupt nicht so gesehen wird und Transfrauen und -Männer mehrheitlich die gleichen Gründe für ihre Transition angeben. Nämlich dass sie sich in dem momentanen Köper nicht wohlfühlen. \n\nDie meisten Männer die transgendern sind heterosexuelle Männer, aber die Mehrheit der Frauen die transgendert ist lesbisch und war lange Zeit ein Teil der lesbischen Gemeinschaft. (…) Die moderne Medizin hat hier sozusagen die unerwünschte gesellschaftliche Rolle der vermännlichten lesbischen Frau entfernt und ein heterosexuelles Paar, durch Transgender, hergestellt.\n\nAuch dies ist eine völlig freie Behauptung. Es gibt auch schwule Transmänner. Wie erklärt ihr euch die? \n\n  Toiletten zum Beispiel stellen einen besonderen intimen Rückzugsort für Frauen dar und müssen sicher sein vor Übergriffen. Sheila Jeffries erwähnt hier explizit das Pornogenre „upskirts“, in dem Frauen ohne ihr Wissen während der Toilettennutzung aufgenommen werden.\n\n… denn Transfrauen sind ja, wie wir alle wissen, nur MÄNNER IN VERKLEIDUNG und schleichen sich in Frauenklos, um Nacktfotos von den Frauen dort zu machen! Denn sie sind Männer! Sie haben ein Männergehirn! Und wie wir alle wissen, sind Männer schwanzgesteuerte Triebtäter, die sich auch mal ebenjenen Schwanz abschneiden lassen, um endlich in Frauenklos spannen zu können. Ganz ehrlich: So viel Geschlechter-Essentialismus ist mir schon lange nicht mehr untergekommen. Hier wird komplett verneint, dass der biologische Körper nicht mit der Geschlechtsidentität übereinstimmen könnte. \n\nEs könnte zukünftig auch zu der Situation kommen, dass Frauennotrufe und Einrichtungen Männer-zu-Frauen Transgender einstellen müssen und von sexueller Gewalt betroffene Frauen sich ohne ihr Wissen an Männer zu Hilfe wenden müssen oder dies dann auch nicht mehr tun werden.\n\nTransfrauen… sind… Frauen… \n\nUnd noch dazu: Ich persönlich würde mich sehr gerne an eine Transfrau wenden, wenn ich von sexueller Gewalt betroffen bin. Eine kurze Google-Suche wird zeigen, dass Transfrauen nämlich viel, viel öfter als Cisfrauen mit (sexueller und/oder transphober) Gewalt konfrontiert sind. Daher versteht mich die durchschnittliche Transfrau vermutlich sogar besser.\n\nIm „Chrismon“ kürzlich wurden übrigens für „Man-for-a-Day“ Kurse in einem Artikel beschrieben. Hier können Frauen erlernen sich wie Männer anzuziehen und zu bewegen, und gehen in dieser Rolle auch in die Öffentlichkeit. Es ist also alles leicht erlernbar und viele weitere dieser Beispiele sprechen gegen die Idee einer eine femininen Essenz und für die soziale Konstruktion von Gender. Wenn stereotypes Geschlechterrollenverhalten einfach angeboren wäre, müsste es nicht mühselig eingeübt werden, denke ich zumindest.\n\nDie hier als fälschlicherweise als „Frauen“ bezeichneten Transmänner müssen deshalb das stereotype männliche Verhalten lernen, weil sie ihr ganzes Leben lang als Frau angesehen wurden und daher das stereotype weibliche Verhalten lernen mussten. Transleute eignen sich lediglich geschlechterspezifisches Verhalten an, damit sie besser als eine Person des Geschlechts „durchgehen“, als das sie sich identifizieren. \n\nDer große Irrtum, dem die Autorin des Buches und auch die des Artikels bei den „Störenfriedas“ aufsitzt, ist folgender:\n\nEs wird angenommen, dass Transleute an sich Verhalten entdecken, das nicht geschlechterkonform ist und daher denken, das ginge ja nicht und sie müssten jetzt das Geschlecht wechseln. Tatsächlich ist es jedoch so, dass Transleute merken, dass ihr Körper nicht zu ihnen passt und sie sich daher mit jenen identifizieren, die den von ihnen gewünschten Körper besitzen. \n\nMeine beiden Töchter glaubten beide im Alter von 2-3 zeitweise Jungen zu sein (…) und insistierten auch, dies zu sein. (…) In jedem Fall ist die Vorstellung erschreckend was alles hätte passieren können, wenn sie andere Eltern gehabt hätten, die auch noch ÄrztInnen gefunden hätten, die eine Identitätsstörung diagnostiziert hätten. \n\nEin wenig Zynismus kann ich mir an dieser Stelle nicht verkneifen. Da hat die Autorin ja gerade noch einmal Glück gehabt; haarscharf ist sie daran vorbeigeschlittert, dass ihre Töchter im zarten Alter von zwei Jahren mit einem Penis ausgestattet worden sind. Wo doch alle anderen Eltern sofort zum Skalpell greifen, sobald ihr Kleinkind Verwirrung über die eigene Geschlechtszugehörigkeit äußert. Auch hier wieder ein heißer Tip von mir: In diesem Alter verstehen die meisten Kinder das Konzept Geschlecht sowieso nicht. \n\nIch lasse mir auch von niemandem absprechen eine Frau zu sein, nur weil ich in Teilen männliche Verhaltensmuster zeigen könnte. Diese Idee macht mich sehr wütend.\n\nHat doch niemand behauptet. Mir ist schleierhaft, warum sich die Autorin von der bloßen Existenz von Transleuten derart bedroht fühlt.\n\n___________\n\nWarum mich dieser Artikel so aufregt, ist vielleicht jetzt etwas klarer. Transmenschen stehen vor ihrer Transition unter einem enormen Leidensdruck und haben danach mit Diskriminierung und Verfolgung (auch polizeilich) sowie (sexueller) Gewalt zu kämpfen, die viel zu oft in Mord endet. Dieser Artikel (und das zugehörige Buch) scheißt auf die Rechte von Transleuten, in dem er sie pathologisiert und als sexuell pervertierte Abweichler und / oder Menschen darstellt, die nicht damit klarkommen, ein paar nicht geschlechtskonforme Eigenschaften zu haben. Das ist nicht okay. Es ist nicht okay. Es schürt ein Klima des Misstrauens und des Hasses gegen Transleute. Und das alles im Namen des Feminismus. Das ist nicht mein Feminismus. Das ist gar kein Feminismus: Wenn die Frauenrechte bei der Frage aufhören, ob eine Frau seit ihrer Geburt eine Muschi hat oder nicht. \n\nWenn ihr Gender abschaffen wollt, warum klammert ihr euch dann so sehr daran fest, wer eine Frau sein darf und wer nicht?","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"daleks-and-other-stuff","id":97152886281,"post_url":"http://daleks-and-other-stuff.tumblr.com/post/97152886281/its-interesting-something-ive-noticed-happening","slug":"its-interesting-something-ive-noticed-happening","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 18:31:00 GMT","timestamp":1410373860,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"KczdA48M","tags":["pointless post","personal","this has been yet another rambling gender feelings post","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZCMdyo1QUmsO9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"","body":"It’s interesting. Something I’ve noticed happening more lately is that I’ll see a letter addressed to me by my old name and title and not be nearly so bothered by it as I used to be.\n\nI guess it’s a matter of getting more ‘detached’ from it as more and more people call me by my actual name, so I don’t associate myself with that particular name so much. I mean, I still get a bit uncomfortable when people call me that name to my face or within earshot, but again, that happens less and less lately, and it doesn’t feel like the complete punch in the gut it used to.\n\nEither way, it seems to be a good thing (not least because that means there’s a certain Hitchcock movie I might finally be able to stomach watching)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"doubleohmogar","id":97152832841,"post_url":"http://micheoff.co.vu/post/97152832841/hey-quick-dumb-question-what-does-cis-gender-or","slug":"hey-quick-dumb-question-what-does-cis-gender-or","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-10 18:30:37 GMT","timestamp":1410373837,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"WfbYV1O2","tags":["gender","trans","truscum","tucute","whitestripedmagician","ask","v answers things"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZHDWqx1QUmfL9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"asking_name":"whitestripedmagician","asking_url":"http://whitestripedmagician.tumblr.com/","question":"hey quick dumb question, what does cis-gender or truscum or however you spell it mean? I've never really known many of the names so it gets confusing a bunch of the time","answer":"well those are two very different terms and i suggest that you look into the gender portal on Wikipedia or genderspectrum.org for a more complete education on the ground level but here are some basics\n\n[all pertinent terms will be bolded with each use - i prefer bolding to quotations as quotations can sometimes give the impression that the writer doesn’t take the quoted word seriously.]\n\ncisgender: a gender identity that aligns with the physical sex you were assigned at birth (so words describing gender (girl, boy) and words describing sex (female, male) can be the same in layman’s terms, especially for cisgender [cis] people).\ntransgender: a gender identity that does not align (either partially or fully) with the physical sex you were assigned at birth; subdivisions of transgender [trans] include genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, bigender, etc., but these terms and classifications might be defined differently for every trans person you ask.\ntruscum: a class or niche community of trans individuals who believe that being trans is a medical condition, and that you must experience physical dysphoria (aka discomfort with your physical primary or secondary sex characteristics or anything else that causes people to perceive you as a different gender than you identify as) to be considered trans. \n——this movement finds its opposition in the next term….\ntucute: a class or niche community formed in response to truscum; people who label themselves tucutes believe that you need not experience physical dysphoria to classify yourself as trans - you simply must identify with, or have gender “feelings” of, a label other than cis. \none could say there are varying degrees of tucute. some are simply people who do not wish to go through GRS (gender reassignment surgery), nor do they experience physical dysphoria, yet they consider themselves not cis (like my identification with the genderfluid label - i am happy presenting feminine and keeping my biologically-classified-as-female physical characteristics, but i feel like my gender is both male and female at times, or it switches, and i would be equally happy presenting as masculine except i personally feel i can’t pull it off right now).\nothers are more radical - these are the ones who come up with new gender identities daily and insist that people use nouns as pronouns (which goes against the linguistic purpose of pronouns it’s not supposed to be that repetitive that’s why they invented pronouns foir fuck’s sake) despite the fact that the pronouns may not even relate to their gender identity in any tangible way. the most extreme form of tucute (and perhaps the most pure, as it transitioned from just anti-truscum) is the idea that anything can be a gender identity and anything can be a pronoun set. \nhope that cleared some things up.\n\nnote: if anyone in these tags feels like taking me to task for the use of the words “physical sex” or “biological _______” or anything i have said that’s based in well established science, you better come correct. there’s a 99% chance i will shut you down for your ignorance - however, if you have extensive and up-to-date experience in biology and can inform me differently, i’ll welcome that knowledge/debate.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"originalplumbing","id":97152611692,"post_url":"http://originalplumbing.tumblr.com/post/97152611692/issue-14-is-here-grab-your-copy-now","slug":"issue-14-is-here-grab-your-copy-now","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 18:20:17 GMT","timestamp":1410373217,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"mG27ZkzH","tags":["coming out","transgender","trans","friends","family","parents"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZXo_lx1QUkEsf","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":17,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"How do I tell my parents I'm transgender how do I even tell my friends??","answer":"Zak: There isn’t one single universally good way of coming out. It really depends on your relationships with your parents and friends, what you’re comfortable sharing with them, how you think they’ll respond, and the method you’re most comfortable with (some people express themselves better in writing, other people prefer face-to-face conversation). We have an article on coming out to parents that contains some advice that might help a bit. We don’t have anything specifically on coming out to friends, but a lot of the advice would be the same. \n\nI personally told a lot of my distant friends and acquaintances through a Facebook note where I could explain everything, I told many of my family members via letter, and my close friends in person. I didn’t just sit everyone down and tell them at once, for most of my friends I came out to them by telling them I was questioning my gender (because at the time I was) and keeping them updated as I figured stuff out. Since many people already have everything figured out by the time they come out to people, it makes more sense to do things differently then that.\n\nOne thing you could do with friends is show them a movie with a trans protagonist, a youtube video of a trans person, or bring up a story about a trans person and then you can start the conversation by saying “that’s kind of how I feel about myself” or something like that. In general, I think that giving them some context or information about what it actually means to be trans can really help make it easier and make more sense to them. Again, there’s no right way to do it. Just try to figure out what makes the most sense to you.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"myemberromance","id":97151529058,"post_url":"http://myemberromance.tumblr.com/post/97151529058/i-need-help-i-have-binding-down-ive-been","slug":"i-need-help-i-have-binding-down-ive-been","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 18:08:47 GMT","timestamp":1410372527,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"mch6mHcp","tags":["ftm","ftmt","ftm problems","trans","transgender","transgender problems","ftm transgender","binding","packing","help","personal","personal problems","boy","male"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZzUWjr1QUhh1Y","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"caption":"I need help.. 17:24:32 GMT","timestamp":1410369872,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"NSnOm7UP","tags":["ftm","top surgery","transgender","trans","dr. rumer","pennsylvania","mytransition"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZxWuho1QUXrCo","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"title":"Top Surgery","body":"I would like to start off by thanking everyone for the good wishes. I had been super nervous days before, and was glad that I maintained a calm composure (for the most part). I arrived at the surgery center around 6:20, waited for it to open, and headed in around 6:45. I filled out some paper work and then got taken back to get prepped for surgery probably some time after 7:00. I got into my dressings, got my vitals checked, and then signed a few more things. Another nurse came by to hook up my IV and then soon after, Dr. Rumer came over and drew on me with a purple marker.\n\nFrom there, I hopped back into bed and was then wheeled to the surgical room.\n\nMy surgery time listed on my paperwork was 7:40, but I heard a few nurses say I would be taken back at 8:00. I had no way to tell the time, so I assume I went to the operating room some time between.\n\nMy emotions and nerves were coming out in awkward laughs. I remember rolling from the bed onto the surgery table, spreading out my arms, getting my legs wrapped in something…and then nothing!\n\nI awoke in the recovery room with absolutely no memory. I was so out of it, and was trying really hard to wake up. A nurse kept checking on me and we had like mini conversations with me half awake. As I gained my focus back, she came over again and fed me graham crackers and apple juice, followed by a Percocet. I was still super giddy, but she commented that it was nice that I was a cheerful patient and was glad I wasn’t crying or screaming from pain. It was also great that I was not nauseous or dizzy!\n\nI was not in pain so much as discomfort, but even that wasn’t so bad. I felt like I had a super tight binder and could feel a slight ache in my chest. Honestly, from having my arms spread out, my arms were a lot more sore. \n\nSurgery was two hours long, but basically it was a gap in time for me. I was in recovery for an hour. I was supposed to fall back asleep during that time, but once the adrenaline kicked in, I was wide awake and ecstatic.\n\nThe nurse helped me get dressed and shortly after, my parents came to get me. She went over the post-op basics and the medications I had to take. She then showed me how to measure and empty my drains.\n\nFrom there, I was helped out of bed, put in a wheelchair, and taken down to my car. My dad reclined my chair, and I brought a pillow to prop myself up and be comfortable.\n\nThe car ride was fine, and I arrived at my home a little after 12:00 PM.\n\nI took some pictures for my own documentation while my parents got the couch (aka my new temporary bed) situated. I took my first antibiotic and will take my pain killers later today. And then tomorrow, I will also start back on Arnica for a week to help with the bruising.\n\nThat is it for now; I will keep you updated! Right now I am just on a happy high and am waiting to crash!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"transtrenby","id":97148709118,"post_url":"http://transtrenby.tumblr.com/post/97148709118/destroy-the-concept-that-being-comfortable-in","slug":"destroy-the-concept-that-being-comfortable-in","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 17:20:25 GMT","timestamp":1410369625,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"BRRwOf22","tags":["trans","cis","dmab","transfem"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZqiDnv1QUWwZ_","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":285,"title":"","body":"destroy the concept that being ‘comfortable in your own skin’ and being trans are mutually exclusive","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"shantsir","id":97148610238,"post_url":"http://shantsir.tumblr.com/post/97148610238/transition-blog","slug":"transition-blog","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 17:18:40 GMT","timestamp":1410369520,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"dP909JO7","tags":["ftm","trans","transman","transguy","trans guy","transgender","lgbt","lgbtq","blog"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZopG0q1QUWYQ_","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"Transition Blog","body":"For those of you who are interested, I have now made a separate blog for my transition. I’ll be doing a different course completely, I was doing Outdoor Education but I’ve changed to Counselling Studies and I register on the 16th September! I’m so excited and I feel like this course is something I really want to do. When I was last at university, there were issues with my transition. I was bullied by the other members of my course because I came out in my 2nd year, and everyone else was really super masculine, misogynistic and all round nasty to me because I identify as male now instead. I’m confident that this won’t happen again, but in case it does, the college has a great support network.\n\nNext update…I have a job! I’m currently working at shitty old Subway, it might not be the best place to work but the people are fantastic and make the job worthwhile. I hate the job but I love the people. The management know about my transition and are all great about it, the only issue is that the bitchy area manager told one of the members of staff that I’m trans…she had no reason to do this and it was a complete dick move, but I’m in need of the money so I have to stick it out.\n\nSome of you may know, for the last 2 months I’ve been homeless. I’ve finally found somewhere to live! I should be moving in within the next 3 weeks and its a lovely place with people I all know really well (one of them is my girlfriend). I’m super hyped to live there and it feels like everything is finally coming together.\n\nI’m starting T next week. This has been almost two years coming and I am beyond excited. As of yet I’m unsure of the actual date I’ll be starting but I’m so keen. I was not intending sex but then again I don’t tend to plan sex it just sort of happens I don’t say no :P I mean I was not seeing him for sex I was seeing him to just get to know what seemed like a nice new person who was local. I also thought, hey he seems nice I’ll be upfront and honest with him to start the friendship out on the right foot. This was the response I got and it knocked me back.\n\nHonestly I was nearly in tears in the office because it made me feel so separate and different from cis-girls. I do not like people treating those headcanons like they are actual representation, because that excuses the fact that acknowledged, canon trans people are woefully under-represented in media. So trans headcanons = yes, yay, great. But please don’t act like they replace actual canon representation, because they do not.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"alexisarealboy","id":97141912862,"post_url":"http://alexisarealboy.tumblr.com/post/97141912862/so-i-just-gave-myself-my-first-shot-and-it","slug":"so-i-just-gave-myself-my-first-shot-and-it","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 15:15:20 GMT","timestamp":1410362120,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"gRIvQPhH","tags":["transsexual","transgender","transguy","hormones","trans","ftm","testosterone"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZZzDoo1QU6-KU","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"So I just gave myself my first shot and it actually wasn’t even hard. \n\nIf the needle were any bigger, we might have a problem though…","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"aidenparkerstransition","id":97141873294,"post_url":"http://aidenparkerstransition.tumblr.com/post/97141873294/had-my-blood-work-done-today-if-everything-goes","slug":"had-my-blood-work-done-today-if-everything-goes","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 15:14:32 GMT","timestamp":1410362072,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"a8KVBpMU","tags":["ftm","trans","female to male","transguy","transman","f2m","ht","testosterone","transition","t"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-49cm1QU6rgE","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"","body":"Had my blood work done today!
