drawing trans women FTW and it works, yay for me!","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"returnthegayze","id":97141080761,"post_url":"http://www.returnthegayze.com/post/97141080761/funeral","slug":"funeral","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 14:58:00 GMT","timestamp":1410361080,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"3jeR1FPm","tags":["darkmatterrage","poetry","poem","spokenword","trans","lgbt","violence","america","queer","sadness","depression","trauma"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zeieis1QU3qAv","followed":false,"post_author":"queerlibido","highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":263,"title":"funeral","body":"our train is delayed and i am late for lunch\n  with a boy i like because he makes me feel\n  less lonely and that seems like a sufficient\n  definition for love these days\n  in this city where it is possible to be surrounded\n  by the warmth of millions of apartment lights and\n  still feel cold\n\n  the lights turn off.\n  and it’s one of those moments\n  when we are forced to look up from our screens \n  and remember that we exist outside of them\n\n  they tell us that someone jumped in front of the tracks\n  that he died upon impact\n  so we just sit there in silence \n  as they remove his remains. \n\n  and some part of us\n  is happy because this, \n  this is the first time we have\n  felt like part of something greater than ourselves in a while\n  in this city where sometimes it takes\n  an accident to remember what the purpose of a\n  body is to begin with.\n\n  when the train starts up again\n  the woman next to me starts complaining\n  and asking why he didn’t do it at home\n  how he could have saved us the trouble and time\n  by taking a bottle of pills before leaving the house\n  how selfish it is to delay others with your death\n\n  and i want to hug her \n  say: “remind me the purpose of this arm” \n  want to love her \n  say: “remind me the purpose of this heart” \n\n  but you see this is america\n  where people scatter on streets like discarded leaves – \n  only touching accidentally as we\n  land on these cities we grew up circling on maps\n  saying “remind me happiness”\n  and somehow convinced ourselves they did\n  the same way we believed in the borders between\n  countries so well that we built a wall around\n  them: called it ‘mine’\n\n  this is america \n  where pain is a ritual we are required to conduct in private:\n  an elaborate symphony on mute\n\n  call it “he died in his sleep peacefully”\n  (as if the stroke did not tear him to pieces)\n\n  call it “he lived to be eighty six years old”\n(as if he didn’t hate himself for at least thirty of them)\n\n  call it “accident”\nnot no healthcare \n\n  call it “casualty” \nnot calculation\n\n  in america:\n\ndeath is a distraction.\n  it is thirty of us sitting together underground on a subway train\nunable to hold each other and weep so instead\nwe sit in silence and wait until we can move again\nback above ground\ninto the light\nand forget how much death must be in the soil\nto grow such \nbeautiful \ndenial\n\ni want to text the boy above ground waiting for me, ask:\n\"have you ever been to a funeral with complete strangers?\"\n  but instead i look at the woman next to me, the one\n  who told a dead man to die more considerately and\n  i remember that to live in america is to attend\n  a funeral with complete strangers: \n  how many ghosts does it take for a cemetery to call itself a country? \n\n  to live in america is to blame the\n  dead for their own death, not\n  the country for creating the very\n  conditions that already killed them\n  before they caught up and\n  made things more clear\n\n  which is why when i tell the\n  liberal who wears words like ‘diplomacy’\n  and ‘democrat’ that i will not pay his taxes\n  because i do not want my coins to cause carnage\n  and he calls me a terrorist\n  (i understand)\n\n  which is why when i tell him\n  that i do believe in monsters who come\n  out at night, call them ‘men’ for short\nand he tells me that i only dress femme because i want to be bashed\n  (i understand)\n\n  which is why when i tell him\n  that the very women who started our movement\n  are still being murdered in the same cities where\n  men are getting married and calling it momentous\n  and he gasps: “that happens here? in america!”\n  (i understand)\n\n  the ways we have been taught\n  to apologize for our sadness.\n  to blame ourselves for the hurt.\n  to erase the violence.\n  to numb the pain.\nto normalize the death.\n  to wake up in the morning and\n  deny that sometimes when the\n  train crawls into the station that\n  we may see a pill in its place. \n  that we may wonder what it\n  would mean to have people\n  empathize with our suffering\n  for once in our goddamn life\n  what it would feel like\n  to hold the captive attention\n  of a funeral of strangers\n\n  so i want to embrace to this woman on the train\n  and say: “i am afraid too” \nsay: “remind me trust”\n  say: sometimes this silence feels like the highest pitch of screaming. \n  say: i understand. say: these past thirty minutes were the first time i have \n  been forced to publicly grieve death in a long time\n  and there is something\n  beautiful about that \n  say: what if we stopped moving more often, \n  took a second to \n  absorb the pain,\nlet it fill us a little less empty.\n\n  but instead i will sit here and wait until the train starts up again.\n  i will exit the car without saying goodbye to her.\n  i will walk up the stairs to the boy outside with the smile that makes me feel less lonely. \n  i will apologize for being late.\n  i will not have the words for a type of loss that is so distant it is intimate.\n  after lunch later i will get back on the train.\n  i will remember. \n  i will soon forget.\n_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ \nthis is an original poem by alok of returnthegayze.com . please consider supporting the artist","can_reply":false}]

Seto Koji’s Blog 3\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nスーパームーン\n\n昨日9日は、月が地球に接近し通常よりも大きくみえる“スーパームーン”とやらでした。\n\n輝きも普段より力強く、綺麗に輝いていた気がします。\n\n数分間スーパームーンは拝めたが、だんだん雲がかかってきてスーパー感がなくなってきたので、部屋に戻りスーパーなモノを。\n\nマスカットに巨峰に梨、スーパー美味しかった！\n\n月、そしてフルーツからパワー貰いました。\n\nSuper Moon\n\n Yesterday the 9th, the moon approaches the Earth and looked bigger than the usual moon, the “super moon”.\n\nIts radiance was stronger than usual, it feels like its completely shining.\n\nA few minutes after seeing the super moon, though the super feeling was gradually lost by the clouds covering it, I went back to my room and felt like having something super.\n\nMuscat, Kyoho grape and pear, was super delicious!\n\nI received power from the moon and also from the fruits.\n\ntrans. cr; shin @ bakamitaii ; take out with full "url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cd2129bcfd3a781f5d5b54da88140c05/tumblr_nbovhpaHph1qelavzo3_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":533,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cd2129bcfd3a781f5d5b54da88140c05/tumblr_nbovhpaHph1qelavzo3_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":333,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/cd2129bcfd3a781f5d5b54da88140c05/tumblr_nbovhpaHph1qelavzo3_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":133,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cd2129bcfd3a781f5d5b54da88140c05/tumblr_nbovhpaHph1qelavzo3_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/cd2129bcfd3a781f5d5b54da88140c05/tumblr_nbovhpaHph1qelavzo3_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":480,"height":640,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/cd2129bcfd3a781f5d5b54da88140c05/tumblr_nbovhpaHph1qelavzo3_500.jpg"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"maxgat","id":97138804648,"post_url":"http://maxgat.tumblr.com/post/97138804648/i-cant-explain-how-happy-it-makes-me-that-i-no-longer","slug":"i-cant-explain-how-happy-it-makes-me-that-i-no-longer","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 14:11:39 GMT","timestamp":1410358299,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"WYskWep6","tags":["trans","going to subway for my lunch and passing 100% made me realise this","ftm"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zr-yXw1QTx8Ue","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"I can't explain how happy it makes me that I no longer get mistaken for female by strangers in public or over the phone. There are no words.","body":"","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"princess-passion-flower","id":97138794756,"post_url":"http://princess-passion-flower.tumblr.com/post/97138794756/we-can-solve-the-gender-sex-questions-that","slug":"we-can-solve-the-gender-sex-questions-that","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 14:11:30 GMT","timestamp":1410358290,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"vFr2X532","tags":["trans","transgender","cis","ciscentric","cissexism","transphobia","trans exclusionary"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z84hrt1QTx644","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":38,"title":"","body":"We can solve the gender/sex questions that healthcare asks that is ultimately ciscentric by replacing “what is your sex/gender” with “what are your chromosomes.”","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"actsofgreatness","id":97138783661,"post_url":"http://actsofgreatness.tumblr.com/post/97138783661/for-trans-students-college-can-be-a-safe-haven-but","slug":"for-trans-students-college-can-be-a-safe-haven-but","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 14:11:00 GMT","timestamp":1410358260,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"ALNj4pVc","tags":["transgender","trans","ftm","ftm transition","ftm trans","lgbt","lgbtq","lgbtqteens","youth","college","Lance Cox"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZOVy1n1QTx3Mj","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"For Trans Students, College Can Be a Safe Haven....But What If Campus Isn't Trans-Inclusive?","body":"This week, transgender writer and activist Lance Cox — who is currently a Junior at an art college — describes his personal experiences facing barriers to trans-inclusion on campus, and pinpoints where changes need to happen.\n\n[This piece is excerpted from a longer anthology chapter entitled “Did I Ask For This?” in Manning Up: Transsexual Men on Finding Brotherhood, Family, and Themselves (Transgress Press, 2014)]. \n\n~~~\n\nAs I entered my senior year of high school, I couldn’t help but count down the days until I could escape my town, my small-minded classmates, and even my family. I decided on an art school that I thought would completely fit my needs: it had a diverse curriculum and a supposedly diverse community, with resources for LGBTQ students and several queer events each semester. […] I hoped that by leaving my hometown, I could get a new start in the city and leave everyone, including my “former self,” behind. \n\nAnd, in essence, I succeeded. \n\nWhen I started college, I got the fresh start I was looking for, found allies on campus and off, and now have a sizable community of other trans*, queer, and allied individuals that love and support me. \n\nBut at what cost?\n\n~~~\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nThis experience hasn’t turned out to be everything I expected.\n\nWhen I came to campus, there wasn’t a process to get one’s preferred name on class rosters, IDs or any other documents. I had to email every administrator and instructor I was going to come into contact with and explain not only what the word “transgender” means, but that I will need them to make a mental note of my name and pronoun preference.\n\nI was frustrated by having to disclose my identity without meeting these people beforehand, but I was also scared. I constantly found myself wondering, What happens if an instructor disregards my requests and uses an incorrect name or pronoun during class? What will the other students think? Is this safe?\n\nI didn’t have the answers and I was terrified — not only that I might be misgendered, but that the other students in the room wouldn’t know what that meant and that they would react in a violent way.\n\nAt the absolute least, being misgendered in the classroom was a huge distraction. Around week ten, after everyone in my classes started to get to know each other, I once had an instructor refer to me with female pronouns. I could sense each of the fifteen students in the room take a breath together, and time seemed to stop to allow everyone to process what had just happened.\n\nAfter that, not only were my classmates confused because they knew me as a man, but I became completely closed off; it made learning astonishingly difficult. There were times that I would skip class in order to avoid being put in that situation again.\n\n~~~\n\nGender-inclusive housing wasn’t an option for me either and I found myself living with four girls.\n\nI ended up spending most of my time outside of my dorm, in study lounges or with friends, and avoided being “home” as much as possible. My roommates would consistently use my preferred name and disregard pronouns, which made me weary of spending time with them or around anyone I hadn’t yet met. \n\nEvery time I walked up to my apartment door, I began worrying that someone would see me enter it or spot our names on it and wonder why there was a male name among four female ones. What would happen if someone saw that? Would they ask someone about it? Would they ask me about it?\n\nMy first year in college was meant to be a new beginning — a way out of a destructive space. The problem is, as an incoming freshman, I wasn’t prepared to embark on a journey of activism or become the face of the trans* rights movement on my campus.\n\nPolicies should have been in place to accommodate my requests as a transgender student before I ever set foot there. I shouldn’t have to be asked time and time again to educate the faculty and staff, regardless of whether or not I would like to do so. Theoretically, I should be able to let my studies come first but the fact is, it doesn’t always happen that way.\n\n~~~\n\nFor some students, entering college may be a time when drugs, alcohol and socializing are their main focus; for others, student organizations and leadership roles fill that space. For me and other transgender students, activism becomes our main priority because it has to.\n\nThe need for safe, gender-inclusive housing and restrooms, a name-change process, inclusive health insurance, and a large range of queer studies courses is stronger than ever. College is a time of awakening, self-discovery, and growth, but until institutions embrace gender variance, higher education will continue to be as dangerous as elementary, middle, and high school can be.\n\n[…] Today, after finally coming to terms with my trans* identity as well as my queer sexuality, I have found myself in an incredible place. Sure, I’m working non-stop to pay my bills, both transition-related and otherwise, and I’m always a little worried that someone is going to disclose my identity without my consent in the classroom.\n\nBut now I choose to tell my story to faculty, staff, and students alike to create impactful change on our campus.\n\nIn the year that I’ve been doing this work, a name-change process has been put in place, single-stall restrooms now have proper, gender-inclusive signage, and we are working on safer, trans*-friendly housing. \n\nI didn’t necessarily seek to be an activist, but I’m not sure anyone does. Activism comes with a sense of necessity: If my college isn’t inclusive enough for me to be fully content, how do I make it so? How will what I do affect those who come after me?\n\nSo, did I ask for this? No. Is it fair? Definitely not. Does it take away from my studies and other college experiences? Sometimes. But is it important? Is it rewarding? Absolutely.\n\n~~~\n\nPhoto courtesy of Flickr. Thanks to Transgress Press and Manning Up co-editors Zander Keig and Mitch Kellaway for permission to reprint the excerpt.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"incrediblypaintedghost","id":97138656051,"post_url":"http://incrediblypaintedghost.tumblr.com/post/97138656051/if-someone-elses-identity-threatens-yours-you","slug":"if-someone-elses-identity-threatens-yours-you","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 14:08:39 GMT","timestamp":1410358119,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"A8nCGZSq","tags":["queer","lgbtqa","genderqueer","trans","identity politics"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z1g4ms1QTwaCp","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"","body":"If someone else’s identity threatens yours, you need to look at the foundations of your own identity instead of attempting to scrutinize theirs into non-existence.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"parrotfishbackinwater","id":97138306531,"post_url":"http://parrotfishbackinwater.tumblr.com/post/97138306531/good-news","slug":"good-news","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 14:01:15 GMT","timestamp":1410357675,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"tLqNgQSL","tags":["trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZP2O9r1QTvEtZ","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":3,"title":"Good news!!!","body":"I have an appointment with the psychiatrist who specializes in LGBT issues at my school! 13:43:00 GMT","timestamp":1410356580,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"8F9sCEds","tags":["seto koji","setokojiblogtranslation","setokojitrans","trans","seems like he just posted another one......","seto are you bored"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z7Imlo1QTs8Go","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":8,"source_url":"http://ameblo.jp/koji-seto-we/entry-11922904822.html?frm_src=thumb_module","source_title":"ameblo.jp","caption":"140910 Seto Koji’s Blog 2\n\n<!-- more -->\n\nこれが酔うってこと？\n\n昨日、音尾さんのLIVEが終わった後、山田と飯を食いに行った。\n\nあっ、山田とは．．．\n\n関西版D-BOYS 劇団Patchのメンバーで、アニメとアイドル、そしてなぜか僕の事が大好きな男の子？です。\n\n彼は今年7月に行われた瀬戸ソロイベント『ぬるま湯くらいのポテンシャルで』の大阪公演に来てくれた。\n\nそれがきっかけで仲良くなり、彼がちょうど東京に来ていたので一緒に飯を食いに行った。\n\nこんな事言ったら関西の方に怒られるかもしれないが、関西の方はよく喋ると言うのは本当だった。\n\n終始しゃべり倒してた(笑)\n\nそれに乗せられて僕は、珍しくお酒を飲んだ。\n\nまずはビール。\n\nこれは1口飲んで山田にあげて、次は梅酒。\n\nこのくらい飲んだ。\n\n「えっ？全然飲んでないやん！」\n\nという声が聴こえてきますが、僕にとってこの量は凄いことっす。\n\nなんだか頭はホワ～ンとするし、目はトロ～ンとするし、これが酔うってことなのか？\n\nおそらく僕は初めて酔いを体験した…\n\nIs this about getting drunk?\nYesterday, after the Otoo-san LIVE was over, I went to eat with Yamada.\n\nAh, Yamada is…\n\nA member of Gekidan Patch, a Kansai version of D-BOYS, he is a guy that loves anime and idols, and somehow me? \n\nHe came to my solo event “Potential in about Lukewarm Water” in July this year when it was held in Osaka.\n\nThat was a chance to be friends with him, just nice he came to Tokyo so we went to eat together.\n\nIf I say this it might anger those living in Kansai, but I heard that Kansai people can speak really well and its true.\n\nI was defeated by him speaking from the beginning to the end (laughs)\n\nLeaving that aside I, drink liquor which was uncommon for me.\n\nStarting with beer.\n\nI drank a sip and gave it to Yamada, next is plum wine.\n\nI drank about this much.\n\n\"Eh? You aren’t even drinking at all!\"\nI heard a voice saying that, but for me drinking this amount is already amazing.\n\nSomehow my head felt howan~, and my eyes felt toran~, is this getting drunk?\n*howan and toran are sfx, basically there are things mostly used in manga for sound effects.\nHowan - soft and warm\nToran - drowsily\n\nPerhaps this is the first time experiencing being drunk.\n\ntrans. cr; shin @ bakamitaii ; take out with full aii","id":97133243912,"post_url":"http://bakamitaii.tumblr.com/post/97133243912/140910-seto-kojis-blog-more-put-your-hands","slug":"140910-seto-kojis-blog-more-put-your-hands","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-10 I am currently on testosterone that I pay $300 for ever 6 months for the rest of my life. I have also recently had a full hysterectomy and now I NEED to have my breast removed and that costs $10,000. I did have a person agree to loan me the $7000 I need (I already saved some money) but they have change their mind last minute. I asked my parents to help but my father lost his job recently. Any money I have left over I will pay it forward and give it out to other transgender people who need the money like I do. I NEED money by 22nd November. I came out to my mom right before uh, sophomore year. So uh, and then this Tuesday actually I took my first injection of testosterone, which is really exciting. Yeah that’s another thing that’s been a long time in the works where basically for five years I’ve been waiting and reading and researching and it’s weird that…it’s like I’m finally here. I’ve finally started. And yeah everyone’s been absolutely amazing and all that so, that’s been good. Um…yes socially I guess I had a bit of a rocky bit here at uh Bennington just because the people who were in charge of the GSA thing….Oh yeah okay so the GSA was called ‘Queer’ and the two people who were in charge of it were very much made being trans and sexual orientation very much the forefront of their identity. Which I think is something that a lot of people…especially when they recently come out or if they come from an abusive or homophobic or transphobic background…something that naturally happens to a lot of people. But for me that hasn’t really been my past and I don’t really make being transgender or whatever the hell my sexuality is now um my identity. I mean it’s part of who I am but I don’t….I wouldn’t say like you know, I’d say there’s more to me than that. And they very much tended to do the same to other people, where if somebody is transgender they kind of make that into what that person is, if that makes sense? And so I…last year I just had a hard time because I realized that some of these people who were my friends that they kind of sought me out because I’m transgender, which I wasn’t too fond of and I started to wonder: do they see me as anything other than transgender or is that all I am to them? But this year’s been great. Those two people graduated and um it turns out there’s a lot of us who felt the same way and were uncomfortable with the whole environment there. And so we made a…we changed the name from Queer to GSMA which is just Gender and Sexuality Minority Alliance. Um and I think it’s a much healthier support group. I truly appreciate it. I’d gotten to a very bad place last night when I woke up in the middle of the night racked with anxiety.\n\nI’m still quite anxious, but today was a mostly good day. Last night’s sleeplessness made for a foggy start. I’d notified my team I’d be working from home today, but I found myself instantly overwhelmed when I checked email this morning. A dear friend invited me to go out for lunch today, and seeing her made a huge difference in the trajectory of my day. I know she didn’t expect the downer dump I ended up laying on her, and I truly hope our lunches together don’t become a place where I cry on her shoulder every time. Figuratively of course, we all know I can’t cry (even though I want to). This friendship has become a very valuable thing to me, and I don’t want to f it up. She invited me to come over to her place for dinner tomorrow and she’s going to start to teach me how to knit. I’m super excited! Her husband always jokes that their house is like a talk show, and I’m grateful to be tomorrow’s featured guest.\n\nLunch was super duper gender affirming, and when I got home I put on one of my favorite dresses and started working. Got a bunch of stupid but important stuff done, and had a productive conference call with some other vendors that we’re partnering up with to do a project for big-ass, Fortune something-something client. I am seriously dreading wearing guy dress-up clothes and driving my ass to Houston next week. Ugh.\n\nAfter the call ended I took care of a few emails, put on some make-up and went to my weekly trans psychotherapy group. I had a lot to share this week, and I received a lot of empathy, understanding, and positive vibes. Group has been and continues to be one of the best things that has ever happening to me. And I received compliments on my outfit, which while seemingly shallow, was actually very nice. I’d chosen what to wear completely on a just-for-me/to-hell-with-everyone-else basis, which is very unlike me. I probably need more to-hell-with-everyone-else in my life…\n\nFeeling positive right now, but I reserve the right to change my mind without a moment’s notice.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"blondybrunette","id":97110255854,"post_url":"http://blondybrunette.tumblr.com/post/97110255854/nkotb","slug":"nkotb","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 03:13:46 GMT","timestamp":1410318826,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"XMuUa5Yv","tags":["lgbtq","transgender","trans","coming out","sisterhood"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZUyMTv1QSEEZk","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"NKOTB","body":"Haha, yeah. I’m that vintage and I loved the New Kids On The Block back when I should have been wearing acid wash guess jeans, pony tails, hair bows, reading seventeen, indulging in other terrible fashion trends and talking with friends on my phone tethered to the wall. \n\nInstead I was the girl hiding from everyone but still listening to NKOTB, only in my case with headphones so to keep to myself. \n\nOne evening in the privacy of my own room I tried to steal a moment for myself to be real. I was rocking to Hanging Tough, it just happened to be the song at the moment. I was singing out loud even though no one else could hear the music playing. My sister walked in on me and caught me singing to her favorite band. I don’t even know if she knew I listened to them before that time, I hid well.\n\nEither way, she laughed, I did too, I was embarrassed but it wasn’t a bad moment. I just thought I was alone. Kind of like when you are caught dancing by yourself and for yourself, you might be startled and embarrassed but it’s not a big deal. I don’t remember much else about that night. I do remember the solitude of my room, the comfort I found there. Sometimes I felt safe enough to peak out and take a look around, in this case singing along to NKOTB as a thirteen year old girl.\n\nSo I told her this memory not even an hour ago by text and she remembered it well. I said, “that was me.” I think something happened to us both. I cried, I think she teared up. We had a moment. We had a moment that connected our new sisterhood to our unknown past sisterhood.\n\nWe can’t read seventeen together or talk about boys, or complain about the mean girls or help each other with the struggles of early fashion and the pressure to be cool, what to say and who to be friends with and all the drama as we both emerge from childhood into our teens, but we can still be sisters even if we missed the dress rehearsal.\n\nWe still are sisters and now we have a memory of our past to share and to build upon as we take on the current challenges of parenthood, marriage, career and life together. \n\nI love you.\n\n-brunette","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"radiowiresoverthesea","id":97110168919,"post_url":"http://radiowiresoverthesea.tumblr.com/post/97110168919/i-just-want-to-give-a-shoutout-to-some-transmen","slug":"i-just-want-to-give-a-shoutout-to-some-transmen","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 03:12:36 GMT","timestamp":1410318756,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"EFTe61Yz","tags":["transgender","ftm","transguy","trans","transman"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZH5pmw1QSDvLN","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":6,"title":"","body":"I just want to give a shoutout to some transmen. Not the rude ones or the misogynistic ones or violent ones. \n\nThe ones who sacrifice their ability to pass, their safety and validation of identity, for fighting misogyny and gender stereotypes. Because they know they are the only ones to learn what male privilege is when they are old enough to understand, and to know what it’s like to be the victims of misogyny.\n\nNot because they deserve some sort of prize, but because when your whole life is at stake,\n\nholding on to the empathy you have for an experience you never identified with\n\n…\n\nwhile risking your safety and identity to do so…\n\nis pretty rad.\n\n(Not that I did/do this all the time. [{"blog_name":"inside-c4t","id":97105708369,"post_url":"http://inside-c4t.tumblr.com/post/97105708369/opened-a-door-for-an-elderly-man-today-at-the","slug":"opened-a-door-for-an-elderly-man-today-at-the","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 02:17:52 GMT","timestamp":1410315472,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"USRCOWZN","tags":["trans","transgender","misgendering","transguy","transboy","passing","coming out"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z9XWbu1QRyuLH","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"Opened a door for an elderly man today at the doctor’s office and he said “Thank you young sir!” in a jolly way, but the woman in front of me knew my biological sex and said “You mean ma’am.” And wow I felt so bad. Like, really? You had to do that? And I felt so bad. Like I pass, and everything, but people know me in this town and they do things like this because not everybody knows I’m trans and I obviously can’t tell everybody. It just sucks. I want to go somewhere nobody knows me so I can just be me. Just be Elliot.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"startfreshtoday","id":97105548414,"post_url":"http://startfreshtoday.tumblr.com/post/97105548414/lgbtq-reality-web-series","slug":"lgbtq-reality-web-series","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 02:15:56 GMT","timestamp":1410315356,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"uqUNukxD","tags":["lgbtq","ftm","trans","gay","queer","bi","lesbian","boys","pride","girls"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZEPC5t1QRyHH_","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":22,"title":"LGBTQ REALITY WEB SERIES","body":"If anyone of the lgbtq community in the inland empire/LA area would like to be part of a reality web series please send me a reply! We need two people between the ages of 18-25 with unique personalities who are going to be completely dedicated to the series. \n\nPlease send me a little bit about yourself and I’ll be sure to answer any questions and give more details.\n\n:)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"welcometofigtown","id":97105173512,"post_url":"http://welcometofigtown.tumblr.com/post/97105173512/so-i-run-a-trimming-business-so-im-on-my","slug":"so-i-run-a-trimming-business-so-im-on-my","type":"text","date":"2014-09-10 02:11:24 GMT","timestamp":1410315084,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"6amrLAYc","tags":["bon secours","insurance","health insurance","contraceptives","trans","cisnormativity","transphobia","HRC","lgbtquia+"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Zculux1QRwrm8","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"So I run a trimming business, so I’m on my husband’s insurance. He works for Bon Secours, a medical care charity/chain thing of sorts. It’s a Catholic organization, but they hire people outside of their religious beliefs. In fact, I’d say a good majority of the people that work for them are not Catholic. Anyway, they’ve recently decided that since they are a religious organization they don’t have to provide contraceptives to their employees. Luckily the ACA says everyone needs access to covered contraceptives. But now I have to have a separate insurance card specifically for contraceptives so that it is absolutely clear that Bon Secours is not paying for them. Every time I use that card, I’m going to think about what a terrible organization they are.\n\nBut the problems don’t end there. Last year when my husband was inquiring about whether or not my specific brand of contraceptive would be covered, the response he was given was “well you don’t qualify for contraceptives” (they were obviously assuming he was a cis male with the “normal” male genitalia without even thinking about it). Wow such cisnormativity…\n\nThen today, when the women in the clinic were talking about the contraceptive change. My husband knew nothing about it. He got no notifications. Even though he has a dependent with a uterus that requires contraceptives. Even though Bon Secours has no fucking reason to believe that he WOULDN’T need to know about this change since it’s not like they keep tabs on what employees’ genitals look like and how they function.\n\nBut then they turn around and pretend that they care about the LGBTQIA+ community through their little HRC (hah, yeah) videos and shit that I don’t really think half the people take seriously (especially employees say things like the “christian in them” won’t let them treat someone different from them badly, as if that is the only thing holding them back from being a complete asshole). If I was working for them, I would be marching my ass down to HR and reporting a hostile work environment for people with uteri and trans people. Because this whole thing is just bullshit. The whole organization is full to the brim with bullshit. “Good Help” my being trans, is sex weird for you? have you ever felt like having a sex change? were you trans before meeting your wife? does your wife call you her wife?","answer":"I will answer these in reverse, because, reasons!\n\nMy wife calls me her partner, just as I call her my partner. It works for us!\nI definitely had trans feelings before I met my now partner. We met in high school, and so at the time I was unfamiliar with the term transgender, and was still very closeted. I had the (false) impression that maybe having a girlfriend might stop them…so I did not tell her until we had been dating a little longer and were both in college. But yeah, I first noticed my gender dissonance around age 10/11 and it has been with me ever since.\nI talked about gender confirmation surgery a little earlier today, so I am not going to rehash that too much. I have done my research, and I am just not interested in pursuing a full medical transition. I have absolutely had days where I have wondered if a social transition with (or without) hormones might be the right path for me, but for now this is where I am…somewhere in a fuzzy middle-ground. It works.\nI do not go too many into (personal) details about sex on here most of the time, but yeah, as a trans person there can definitely be some extra layers when it comes to my gender identity/body dysphoria and intimacy. Is sex weird for me? Not particularly, I am a very sex-positive individual, and have learned to love myself. There may be some extra layers, but that is about And I think I read somewhere that it’s connected to spirituality for some…but that’s about all I know.\n\nAnd I always call bullshit so hard on the belief that trans people have to be a certain kind of way for our identities to be respected. It’s not our burden to be acceptable enough to others in our existence, and definitely not as a requirement for such things as basic respect and healthcare.\n\nSo, I would say: what actually makes it hard for trans people to be respected and access trans related healthcare is the prejudices and cissexism, racism, ableism, etc of cis people and medical industry Holyoke's President Announced a Huge Change for LGBT Students With an Emotional Speech","url":"http://mic.com/articles/91479/mt-holyoke-s-president-announced-a-huge-change-for-lgbt-students-with-an-emotional-speech","link_image":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbnbrtofOq1rge4f6_og.png","description":"It’s the second women’s college to enact this new policy.\n\nFor several years, America’s most prestigious women’s colleges have opened their hallowed halls to scores of eager incoming freshmen — that is, unless you’re transgender.\n\nThis week, Massachusetts school Mount Holyoke became the second women’s college (after Mills Collegein California) to announce it will be accepting applications from female transgender students. Mount Holyoke president Lynn Pasquerella made the decision public during an emotional speech as part of the college’s convocation.\n\n\"We recognize that what it means to be a woman is not static … We acknowledge that gender identity is not reducible to the body,\" Pasquerella said in the speech, appearing to wipe away tears. \"Our new policy formally welcomes applications from … anyone who is female or who identifies as a woman.\"\n\nPasquerella clarified that Mount Holyoke needed a “formal policy” that would “articulate our commitment to core values of individual freedom, social justice and diversity and inclusion.” The college, she said, “has welcomed trans students in the past and for several years ha[s] been in conversation with campus constituencies about how best to foster a respectful environment for all students.” But it was still important for university administrators to send a clear, welcoming message to the trans community.\n\nThe change in policy comes amidst a tense debate within feminism about transgender inclusion. In her speech, Pasquerella referenced the thinking of mainstream feminists, who decades ago argued against biological determinism in order to gain societal advancement. This logic, she observed, can be similarly applied to the decision to accept applications from all students.\n\nSo far, the new policy has received unanimous support from the LGBT community, which has called for women’s colleges to open its doors to trans students in recent years. While they have generally been considered bastions of the liberal arts, women’s colleges have stayed surprisingly conservative in their understanding of gender when it comes to their admissions policies. Some cite the red herring of Title IX which, up until this summer, provided a loophole to women’s colleges regarding their single sex status. The Department of Education has since extended protections to trans students.\n\nThe issue attracted national attention last year, after Calliope Wong was denied admission into Smith College due to a so-called “gender inconsistency” in her application. The Federal Application for Student Aid (FAFSA) identified her as male, and this inconsistency effectively nullified her candidacy. “Your FAFSA,” read Wong’s rejection letter, “indicates your gender as male. Therefore, Smith cannot process your application.”\n\ncontinued…","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"aerinisababe","id":97093000192,"post_url":"http://aerinisababe.tumblr.com/post/97093000192/i-know-there-was-a-post-going-around-a-little","slug":"i-know-there-was-a-post-going-around-a-little","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 I've found this prosthetic tht has absolutely everything I need but it's on the (very) expensive side of things. Do you have any tips on how to save up at least $1,000 + and relatively fast?","answer":"I have no brilliant schemes to making money fast, sorry! My suggestions are probably ones you have already thought of, but: are there ways you can pick up extra work/hours? Someone understanding who you can get a loan (full or partial) from? Odd jobs you can do (animal watching? yardwork? whatever?)? Gofundme? Camming? There are obviously pros and cons to each.\n\nI am no expert on packers, but $1K+ definitely strikes me as expensive. Not saying it is not the right one by any means, but is there any way you can manage with a lesser/cheaper packer while you save up for the perfect one? Might help ease the waiting process a little.\n\nTake my advice with a grain of salt though, my breast forms are on the cheap side…but hey, only Navyy and I get to/have to see them, so it does not bother me. Seriously though, if a perfect packer is important to you, make it am a cis female, but from my extensive work with the trans community, the majority perfer to just be asked \"what are your pgp? (perfered gender pronoun)\" but only if the topic has been brought up. You obviously don't ask a person out of the blue if they're trans. If a misgender has been made, simply say \"sorry\" and move on (drawing attention and making a big deal makes the misgendering worse) and TRY VERY HARD NOT to make the mistake again.","answer":".","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"kityanpoet","id":97085736150,"post_url":"http://kityanpoet.tumblr.com/post/97085736150/fall-tour-season-has-started-im-heading-to-suny","slug":"fall-tour-season-has-started-im-heading-to-suny","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 21:53:58 GMT","timestamp":1410299638,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"CcyBLKw3","tags":["queer","trans","qtpoc","asian american","trans*","lgbtqia","activism","art"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZIp8_q1QQmiJM","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"caption":"Fall tour season has started! I’m actively in search of more tour dates across the country, so please get in touch if you have any interest in an event at your school! I’ve got a show with lots of new spoken word poetry about LGBT, Queer, Trans, and Asian American themes and would love to share them! This year in addition to a full length show, I’ve got TWO workshops I’m touring- an open-level slam poetry writing and performance workshop and an advanced level workshop for teams and active poetry crews! I’m excited to be offering these because I’ve found that after I give a workshop on a campus folks have been self organizing events that include more student poetry exhibitions and excursions. Sometimes venues that are out there aren’t as welcoming and inclusive as we’d like them to be as queer people of color so fuck ‘em and let’s make more spaces for ourselves! Official paperback release date is October 1st. \n\nI am proud of this book. I wasn’t sure about it until I neared the end, and it became clear to me. I feel it will be very important. I don’t say that to be arrogant, just confident. As Morrissey said in his first TV interview. “If you really have something and you’re very sure of it, why hide?” I hope everybody will check it out. I’ll post again with a link when it’s available to purchase. \n\nAbout Show Trans: A nonfiction novel about sex addiction, sex work, navigating the MSM scene, a trip West, dissociative identity disorder, and the struggle to find love, connection, and self-actualization as a non-binary trans person. This book will be my most autobiographical (and arguably scandalous) work to date. I know I would donate.","answer":"I had actually not given it any thought up to this point.\n\nBut I think it speaks volumes to the kind of person you are (and what kind of a kick-ass community there is here on Tumblr) that you would give away money to someone you have never met (in person) so that I can go have someone shoot lasers at my face. You are pretty awesome.\n\nCrowdfunding for trans-related care (hair removal/surgeries/therapy/etc.) seems to be pretty common these days, which is maybe both a good reminder of how cool the internet can be and just how crappy healthcare coverage is for this sort of care. But I am glad that option is out there for people, cool stuff.\n\nThat said, I feel a little hesitant about accepting money from other people for this stuff for me. I may not be as financially comfortable as I would like to be, but I do have a good job and with a little budgeting and the help of Groupon this seems pretty attainable with my current means. I appreciate the offer and generosity, and maybe it is just my own desire to help others first, but my inclination is to say that there are people more in need of the help. 19:51:00 GMT","timestamp":1410292260,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"l4eM5z4O","tags":["transgender","lgbt","trans","gender","gender dysphoria","trans man","trans men","trans woman","trans women","transgender men","transgender women","mankato","mnsu","minnesota state university mankato","minnesota"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z1rxOy1QQD8jS","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":60,"title":"Gender Dysphoria: A Growing Dysfunction","body":"There was an article written in my school paper about Gender Dysphoria and I’m PISSED. While I understand this is an Op/Ed piece and the author is entitled to her own opinion, the first paragraph especially is hate speech. She is uneducated on the topic and I want this kind of uneducated bullshit to stop being published, especially when my school has a large LGBT presence and support. Please boost the shit out of this. Comment on the page. Make them know that hate speech will not be tolerated.\n\n\"In a land of freedom, controversy proceeds. While some new scandalous trend is emerging every day, there’s one particular LGBT (famed for their questionable morals) fad that is hitting the surface: transgendered children.\n\nThis one has republicans dazed and confused and parents wrapped in knots. Children as young as five years old are being given the chance to choose which gender they’d like to mirror. In this, parents allow their daughters or sons to wear the opposite sex clothing, and they take further measures to present the appropriate gender’s style, i.e. long or short hair, or in older ages, makeup.\n\nIt’s arguable to say that there should be no borderline for people and what they do, and all should be able to choose what they wear and do with their hair and faces limitlessly, but it is clear that parents and their children are going for choosing between a boy or a girl for their everyday life. In fact, in ages as young as eleven, parents have taken steps to insuring that puberty is stinted for their children by administering a certain drug. For Dr. Olson, a specialist in this bizarre condition in Los Angeles, it is called ‘Supprelin.’\n\n‘Supprelin’ is an implant that goes in the arm and provides enough hormones to block puberty for a year. It’s a thin, inch-long capsule filled with the hormone stuff. With this, girls who long to be boys may avoid developing breasts and other methods of maturation, and boys wanting to be girls evade facial hair and other pubescent nuances.\n\nThis growing swell of children who seek early gender reassignment suffer from a dysfunction known as “gender dysphoria.”\n\nAccording to the DSM, gender dysphoria is the “conflict between a person’s physical gender and the gender he or she identifies as.”\n\nDr. Olson tells CBS News that the number of people with this odd condition has had a 330 percent increase over the year of 2013. Estimated, it effects 0.5 percent of the adult population, or 700,000 Americans.\n\nWho’s to say why this condition is suddenly poking its head? Is it a matter of more children being born with this dysfunction? Is it something in our food or something in our lifestyle? Or is it merely the way of life morphing into that of a more accepting one? With the growing LGBT support, with numerous allies all across the world, it could be that people who had long suffered with this condition are coming out of the woodworks, and in turn encouraging children to do the same. Our young people are being taught that it’s most important to feel comfortable in your own skin, despite the repercussions.\n\nIn reported cases of gender dysphoria, 89 percent of children experience harassment at school or other social venues. Most children wouldn’t voluntarily choose to be picked on, so who’s to say that these kids actually have a choice as to what skin they live in? This couldn’t be some game to them if it meant risking any friendships they once had to be the black sheep.\n\nMany agree that the parents are to blame, as well. But according to Cristy and Enrique, who let their son dress as a girl at six years old, they felt they had no choice.\n\n“She was in pain,” she tells Braver with CBS News. “I don’t see that there was another option. She was uncomfortable, she was unhappy. You can’t see your child suffer like that.”\n\nHundreds of families like Cristy and Enrique’s will undergo this problem with their children. The next time you see it and judge, however, just think about what you would do.”\n\n(x)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"curo-kuni","id":97075682577,"post_url":"http://curo-kuni.tumblr.com/post/97075682577/somewhat-random-but-necessary-psa-my-heart-goes","slug":"somewhat-random-but-necessary-psa-my-heart-goes","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 19:40:33 GMT","timestamp":1410291633,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"81GBEoqg","tags":["trans","transmen","transwomen","mtf","ftm","cis"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZFAc4x1QQALqH","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"title":"","body":"Somewhat Random but Necessary PSA: My heart goes out to all people who are trans. without any type of SRS, have you given any thought of presenting as Kat at work?","answer":"Sure, definitely have given it thought. it would be a major step, but not an unfathomable one. I do have (admittedly vague) plans to come out to my coworkers/boss within the next year on at least the level of, “you should know this about me,” and I hope to within the much nearer future have that same conversation with our LGBTQ staff director.\n\nJust presenting female at work, while it might go alright, certainly invites more potential for problems with mismatched gender/legal name/bathroom/etc. issues as distinct possibilities. As far as I am concerned if I decide to present female at work I might as well just fully (socially) transition, ie. present female full time, even if I did nothing else in the way of hormones/surgery/etc. That way, with the approval of an understanding judge and/or doctor, I could also get the legal name changes/gender marker changes that would make it smoother logistically. (Sorry if this comes off as rude? I'm just new to all this, haha.) (Also sorry for any possible English mistakes, I'm not a native speaker.)","answer":"Men and women are binary genders, binary meaning “relating to, composed of, or involving two things.”. For a long time gender has been considered binary except for in a few cultures that have third genders based off gender roles. However, in most cases, these genders aren’t considered trans due to the facts that they’re based on gender roles and that third gender members of the cultures have asked to not be considered trans.\n\nNon binary is a word to describe trans people whose gender is not the two binary genders (man and woman).\n\nAgender and bigender are non binary genders.\n\nNon binary people face a unique set of problems specific to them. While trans men and women are gaining visibility and acceptance, though at a slow pace, and have hormone therapy and surgeries available to them, there is currently very little visibility for non binary people, a lot of gender therapist are unaware of non binary genders, and little to no research has been done for hormone therapy and surgeries for them.\n\nAlso, trans people are considered freaks by a lot of people and even more people consider it freakish to desire no sex characteristics or characteristics of both sexes.\n\n  \n\nI’ve personally looked up the possibilities for agender people and came across a story of someone who wished to neutralize the sex characteristics of their body but was instead pushed into a full transition to female instead.\n\nI’ve asked people about it as well and been blown off with a “why would you want to mutilate your perfectly fine body?”\n\nI’m hoping as binary trans people get more recognition, non binary trans people will as well.\n\n(you’re not coming off as rude at all! I made this blog so I could help out and one of the best ways to do that is answer questions. Also, I didn’t notice any english mistakes! You speak it very well.)","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ccxnts","id":97069017091,"post_url":"http://ccxnts.tumblr.com/post/97069017091/so-ive-come-out-to-my-tutors-at-college-and-they","slug":"so-ive-come-out-to-my-tutors-at-college-and-they","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 Just gotta figure out -how- to do it now.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"lgbt-ya","id":97066516168,"post_url":"http://lgbt-ya.tumblr.com/post/97066516168/maxine-wore-black-by-nora-olsen-published-by-bold","slug":"maxine-wore-black-by-nora-olsen-published-by-bold","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 17:10:00 GMT","timestamp":1410282600,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"qEkj7Qhj","tags":["trans","lit","lgbt","lgbt ya","ya","lesbian","bisexual"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZkW7pm1QPdNx8","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"","body":"Maxine Wore Black by Nora Olsen\n\nPublished by Bold stroke books on 14th Oct 2014\n\nPages: 264\n\nGenres: YA, LGBT, queer, trans\n\nBuy on Goodreads\n\nBlurb: Maxine is the girl of Jayla’s dreams: she’s charming, magnetic, and loves Jayla for her transgender self. There’s only one problem with Maxine—she already has a girlfriend, perfect Becky.\n\nJayla quickly falls under Maxine’s spell, and she’s willing to do anything to win her. But when Becky turns up dead, Jayla is pulled into a tangle of deceit, lies, and murder. Now Jayla is forced to choose between love and the truth.\n\n Jayla will need all the strength she has to escape the darkness that threatens to take her very life.\n\nReview: This book is so refreshing! It features a lesbian trans lead, with a sassy bi trans best friend. The writing is really tight and focussed and the background of the characters transition is explained quickly without seeming like an info-dump. \n\nThe story starts at a queer prom, after an intriguing flashforward prologue. I love how the story shows trans people how to deal with unwanted attention and awkward questions about their body and gender, which is something that can be really useful for teenagers.\n\nOverall this seems to be a trans story with a lot of potential! Definitely worth a read. \n\n3/5 stars","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"samaeloliver","id":97066456726,"post_url":"http://samaeloliver.tumblr.com/post/97066456726/my-new-boss-saw-on-my-facebook-that-im-hoping-to","slug":"my-new-boss-saw-on-my-facebook-that-im-hoping-to","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 17:09:55 GMT","timestamp":1410282595,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Tg90WvCm","tags":["trans","transgender","nonbinary","top surgery"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZdU-sv1QPd9QM","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":0,"title":"","body":"My new boss saw on my Facebook that I’m hoping to get top surgery soon and is trying really hard to be inclusive… Which I really love and appreciate, especially on the pronoun front, but she just gave me an article that she took out of a magazine, directed toward women with best cancer getting mastectomies or preventative mastectomies, and coping with the physical and emotional changes. \n\nIt’s just kind of silly because like— I researched the shit out of top surgery the second I realized I wanted it even though I knew I wasn’t getting it anytime in the foreseeable future, and the things the article said were very very basic, and didn’t fully apply cause it was advice for people who didn’t particularly want to have their breasts removed!! \n\nI’m glad that she thinking of me but it was a little embarrassing lol.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"vfpatlas","id":97066387441,"post_url":"http://vfpatlas.tumblr.com/post/97066387441/omg-did-you-know-soy-contains-high-amounts-of","slug":"omg-did-you-know-soy-contains-high-amounts-of","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 17:08:46 GMT","timestamp":1410282526,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"hkG71j0m","tags":["soy","estrogen","mtf","trans","lgbtq","hormones"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z-tKbp1QPcuVn","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":41,"title":"","body":"OMG DID YOU KNOW SOY CONTAINS HIGH AMOUNTS OF ESTROGEN I DID NOT KNOW THAT THAT’S SO WEIRD\n\nMight come in handy for any mtf out there","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ellen-is-on-oestrogen","id":97066338804,"post_url":"http://ellen-is-on-oestrogen.tumblr.com/post/97066338804/why-would-you-argue-against-self-medication","slug":"why-would-you-argue-against-self-medication","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-09 17:07:50 GMT","timestamp":1410282470,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"d5CLm6zH","tags":["transgender","trans","healthcare","self-medication","HRT","DIY HRT","Anonymous","ask auntie ellen"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZwIxis1QPcidq","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":5,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Why would you argue against self-medication?","answer":"If you read my article, you’ll find I’m not. I’m saying that self medication isn’t ideal (it objectively isn’t), but that it’s sometimes necessary and a good option for people who otherwise have no access to healthcare. Self-medication can be life-saving, as I wrote in the article.\n\nStill, in a UK context, where there’s a national health service that’s free to use, the fact that self-medication persists shows that the health & social care system has big problems. Addressing those problems helps everyone.\n\nI’m not against self-medication, but am in favour of making it safer for those participating in the short term while making it easier to get safe healthcare in the long term.\n\nI suggest you actually read the article, though.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"feministroosterteeth","id":97066334111,"post_url":"http://feministroosterteeth.tumblr.com/post/97066334111/side-note-amongt-this-awful-anons-messages-have-you","slug":"side-note-amongt-this-awful-anons-messages-have-you","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-09 17:07:47 GMT","timestamp":1410282467,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"OV9f4vDw","tags":["Anonymous","jazz jennings","frtasks","trans","transgender"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZHQdjr1QPchUV","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":9,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Side note amongt this awful anon's messages. 16:16:38 GMT","timestamp":1410279398,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"zF2DMcwP","tags":["Slate","Christin Scarlett Milloy","trans","passing","mansplaining","socialization","feminism"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZkJR0x1QPRbD9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":2,"title":"Arguing While Trans: A Straight, Cis Man Tells a Trans Woman How to Behave","url":"http://www.slate.com/blogs/outward/2014/09/01/a_straight_cis_man_tells_a_trans_woman_to_take_the_night_bus.html","link_image":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_nbn6jqR8v21r1legn_og.jpg","description":"I was raised and socialized as a boy, and I was read as a boy everywhere I went. Getting to be a boy, socially, was the definite upside to the experience. So by social protocol, a guy can talk loudly, interrupt a certain amount, and arrogantly presume his righteousness, all while remaining safely within the social “bro” zone. On the other hand, if I perform too many of the same behaviors, I would cross the “bitch” threshold, and thereby lose my credibility at the table.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"ellen-is-on-oestrogen","id":97063221359,"post_url":"http://ellen-is-on-oestrogen.tumblr.com/post/97063221359/gender-identity-clinics-have-a-reputation-in","slug":"gender-identity-clinics-have-a-reputation-in","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 16:13:01 GMT","timestamp":1410279181,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"oGvVgwQq","tags":["transgender","trans","trans healthcare","hrt","self-medication","mental health","northern ireland"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZwIxis1QPQpXl","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":85,"caption":"Gender Identity Clinics have a reputation. In times gone by (and still to this date, at some clinics), healthcare providers have required trans people to navigate ridiculous and unreasonable obstacles before being granted access to treatment. Requiring stereotypical gender presentation, being “out” to everyone prior to treatment, “Real Life Experience” (the requirement to change gender presentation prior to treatment, a practice that still exists and puts patients in danger), insistence upon gender-nonconforming career changes, unhelpful mental healthcare and the rejection of patients seen to be “not trans enough” are just a few of the historical problems with GICs. \n\nI don’t think we talk about self-medication in the trans community nearly enough. In a UK context, the fact that self-medication still exists shows big problems with the healthcare system, and addressing the need to self-medicate is useful for addressing larger problems in GICs and gender services as a whole.\n\nI wrote this in a short span, and although I’m not happy with it, I’m out of things to say on the issue right now. Self-medication is (rightly so) a controversial issue, but I don’t think ignoring it does any good, and nor does outright condemning it.\n\nLike everything, middle grounds can be useful.\n\nHave a read, sure! It’s about 2,000 words but it’s not that long.","image_permalink":"http://ellen-is-on-oestrogen.tumblr.com/image/97063221359","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":1280,"height":960,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_1280.jpg"},{"width":500,"height":375,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_500.jpg"},{"width":400,"height":300,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_400.jpg"},{"width":250,"height":188,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_250.jpg"},{"width":100,"height":75,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_100.jpg"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_75sq.jpg"}],"original_size":{"width":1280,"height":960,"url":"http://31.media.tumblr.com/a027ba65f32a3586d2d7e1c17e055d2f/tumblr_nbn6dp50cO1s8lcbvo1_1280.jpg"},"exif":{"Camera":"LGE Nexus 5","ISO":248,"Aperture":"f/2.4","Exposure":"1/100th","FocalLength":"3mm"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"queerinshiningarmour","id":97063141458,"post_url":"http://queerinshiningarmour.tumblr.com/post/97063141458/someone-message-me-and-be-friends-with-me","slug":"someone-message-me-and-be-friends-with-me","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 16:11:33 GMT","timestamp":1410279093,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"nxMWVd4i","tags":["bored","talk to me","ask me","trans","queer","teach me stuff"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnAV5r1QPQW1I","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"Someone message me and be friends with me.","body":"I’m bored and wish to talk about things.","can_reply":false}]

I can’t think of a better day to start on. Holy crap.\n\nThings are going so fast. Instead of a few therapy sessions and maybe a letter, I just sign the informed consent and..that’s it. If I want a really close shave, like if I am going out, I will often shave once with and then once against the grain. That seems to work fairly well for me. I am planning on getting some laser hair removal done in the not too distant future (maybe this next year?) which, if nothing else, should help to reduce the number of darker hairs I have on my face. That is definitely going to be a big help in giving me more confidence to wear less (or no) makeup out more often.\n\nBeyond that electrolysis is the most permanent solution for removing facial hair, and is the recommended route to go (after laser) for most people who are transitioning.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"theyarebangtan","id":97061713336,"post_url":"http://theyarebangtan.tumblr.com/post/97061713336/starcast-bts-changes-into-flower-youngsters-for","slug":"starcast-bts-changes-into-flower-youngsters-for","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 15:45:53 GMT","timestamp":1410277553,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"bdaW8PiR","tags":["bts","bangtan","bangtan boys","star cast","trans"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/Z5Bger1QPL3Mu","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":51,"title":"[STARCAST] BTS, changes into ‘flower youngsters’ for Chuseok! cast","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"just-exquisite","id":97061697810,"post_url":"http://just-exquisite.tumblr.com/post/97061697810/trying-something-new","slug":"trying-something-new","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 15:45:40 GMT","timestamp":1410277540,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"l51xYnRa","tags":["dmab","trans*","trans","nonbinary","queer","submission"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZSLgap1QPK-aI","followed":false,"post_author":"omnimpotent","is_submission":true,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":29,"caption":"Trying something new","image_permalink":"http://just-exquisite.tumblr.com/image/97061697810","photos":[{"caption":"","alt_sizes":[{"width":137,"height":185,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/4ad195f55fcc9cd17bea7e8d8a6af3f2/tumblr_nblit4i92Q1t47kyfo1_250.png"},{"width":100,"height":135,"url":"http://33.media.tumblr.com/4ad195f55fcc9cd17bea7e8d8a6af3f2/tumblr_nblit4i92Q1t47kyfo1_100.png"},{"width":75,"height":75,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/4ad195f55fcc9cd17bea7e8d8a6af3f2/tumblr_nblit4i92Q1t47kyfo1_75sq.png"}],"original_size":{"width":137,"height":185,"url":"http://38.media.tumblr.com/4ad195f55fcc9cd17bea7e8d8a6af3f2/tumblr_nblit4i92Q1t47kyfo1_250.png"}}],"can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"queeniequeerie","id":97061631700,"post_url":"http://queeniequeerie.tumblr.com/post/97061631700/so-i-came-out-to-my-speech-professor-as","slug":"so-i-came-out-to-my-speech-professor-as","type":"text","date":"2014-09-09 15:44:00 GMT","timestamp":1410277440,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"Jd3avsIx","tags":["personal","long post","coming out stories","coming out","trans","nonbinary","non binary","non binary trans","nonbinary trans","trans resources","resources","ollie schminkey","ally excellence"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZhhVMp1QPKlRK","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":1,"title":"","body":"So I came out to my Speech professor as genderneutral last week, and I just wanted to write about how it’s actually been really, really amazing. More after the break, if you care to read. \n\n<!-- more -->\n\n  My Speech professor is an older guy, and a longtime theater professional. He’s performed all over the world, with a ton of very prestigious companies. Therefore, he’s a very intimidating presence in my campus’ theater department. Phil is the kind of person who you would grovel to get his approval, and probably cry if he ever got mad at you. I was thoroughly scared to have a class with him this semester, but I knew as long as I did the work and applied myself, it should totally go okay. \n\n  Well, I discovered that Phil has a very strange way of trying to include everyone. He’s making an effort not to be sexist - which I can totally appreciate - when he says things like ‘ladies and gentlemen’ and things like that. Turns out he was completely ignorant to the category of ‘other’ than I and other non-binary students fall into. \n\n  One day last week, he said something about ‘ladies and gentlemen,’ and for whatever reason, went onto a tangent (as he’s prone to do) about all the million ways one can say ‘ladies and gentlemen.’ I felt so uncomfortable; I’d honestly never wanted to leave a classroom as badly as I did right then. But I took a deep breath, steeled myself, and just chimed up “or others!”\n\n  He stopped, sort of cocked his head, and said, “What does that mean?” \n\n  I said, “Like trans people. Not everyone fits into ladies and gentlemen.” \n\n  He then told us a story about a trans woman actress he used to work with, doing his best to use correct pronouns (something I can sort of excuse - he’s an older gentleman, I give him credit for working to correct himself), and told us that she played “the best Richard III I’d ever seen.” It was a clue that I could continue and correct him to what I was speaking about. \n\n  ”Yes, that’s important, but I was talking more about non-binary trans people.”\n\n  He naturally gave me a look of confusion, having never heard the term before. So I explained in a very general sense what the phrase could mean and the people that could use it, and explained how I personally use it. Now, mind you, this was in front of my whole class, which is a small core of about 12 people that I’ll be spending the rest of my college career with - my voice was shaking and I wanted to throw up. \n\n  However, Phil just sat back, listened patiently, and thanked me for bringing it up. He apologized, saying, “I’m sorry that anything I’ve said has made you uncomfortable, that’s not at all my intention.” And I accepted his apology, told him it was really only that day. \n\n  We continued on with class, and I went home. I felt pretty good about the whole scenario; he had seemed genuinely interested in what I was saying, had agreed to work on using my preferred pronouns, and the class seemed to also show a lot of support. Any sick feeling I had had dissapated, and it was really validating to have found a professor who genuinely cares - I know that’s actually pretty rare to find. \n\n  The next day, I was walking into my morning class and I got a text from Phil. He was thanking me again for bringing something up, and told me that he had been doing research on his own all night the previous evening. I almost started crying in the middle of the hallway - he has no investment in me or non-binary trans people, he doesn’t really have to care, but since I introduced him to it he took it upon himself to seek information. He genuinely wanted to make his classroom better for me and for any student like me who might follow. I was overwhelmed, and I texted him back with a profuse gratitude. I also mentioned that I have a ‘zine written by the amazing Ollie Schminkey, full of information and resources for instructors with trans students. He was so excited and wanted me to email it over to him as soon as I could. \n\n  Well, funny thing. For whatever reason, I kept getting error messages that said the file was too big. The whole weekend went by and I couldn’t get it to him or think of a way to link him to this .pdf on my computer. \n\n  When we walked into class yesterday, he said his hellos and then looked at me with a little point and head nod of ‘oh, I just remembered!’ He asked me about the ‘zine, and if I had sent it. I told him I was having troubles, and he sat with me for about 10 minutes, sending test emails, making sure I had the right address, and eventually came up with a solution to get the ‘zine to him. After class, he even pulled me aside and asked for my help to brainstorm better ways to speak, and very respectfully asked what he had said that bothered me so he could eliminate it. I gave him a huge hug before I left, almost wanting to cry out of joy again.\n\n  I’ll be hearing from him probably tomorrow about the ‘zine, and any other questions he was left with after reading it. I guess I just wanted to write this to let people know that coming out, talking about things you have problems with, and asking for respect isn’t as terrifying as I think most of us believe it is. I knew it could have gone horribly wrong. I know that there are quite a few of my professors that I couldn’t have that kind of conversation with. However, I was stunned to find out that things could also be so positive. I’m still a little in disbelief over the fact that someone I barely knew devoted an evening to research, and actively working to get a better understanding on my situation that didn’t involve drilling me with a million questions. \n\n  Don’t be afraid to demand the things you deserve. Don’t be so petrified by the fear of everything that could go wrong that you never find out if it could be great. \n\n  And thank you again to Phil Hubbard, probably the best teacher I’ve ever encountered. \n\n  For anyone else that wants the ‘zine: I have a .pdf on my computer that I would absolutely be willing to send out. It’s very well-written and is full of other links, resources, and ‘further reading,’ written by the brilliant Ollie Schminkey. They’re one of the leading queer activists and poets, who attend Macalaster University and runs the slam poetry team there. They have one published book of poems, and they’re featured in an anthology compiled by Andrea Gibson. They’re the best of the best and would love the ‘zine to be distributed. If you’d like it, shoot me a message with your email and I’ll send you a Dropbox link, and you can use it to send to your professors before the semester (or during!) as an aid in coming out and asking for your preferred name/pronouns.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"trans-parenting","id":97061557705,"post_url":"http://trans-parenting.tumblr.com/post/97061557705/wondering-why-you-arent-interested-in-a-sex-change","slug":"wondering-why-you-arent-interested-in-a-sex-change","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-09 15:43:04 GMT","timestamp":1410277384,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"8M5QvYbT","tags":["transparenting","trans","transgender","surgery","gender identity","gender dysphoria","questions","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnO4pr1QPKTN9","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":33,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Wondering why you arent interested in a sex change?","answer":"Because for me it is not worth it.\n\nI am really glad gender confirmation surgery options exist for trans people who need them - and I am a huge advocate for making them more accessible and affordable. That said, they are not for me.\n\nMore after a break, because, genitals, oh my!\n\n[[MORE]]\n\nGender confirmation surgery (aka. sexual reassignment surgery…or a “sex change”) is expensive - like thousands or tens of thousands of dollars expensive (often not covered by insurance). You have to jump through a number of medical hoops to make it a possibility, and like any major surgery there can be complications - it is not uncommon to have at least some loss of sensation, and that is not even taking into account what impact it can have on relationships. Trust me, the people who are seeking this surgery really need it.\n\nI do not. I have come to terms with having a penis, and I feel like the trade-offs are simply not worth it. I do not see myself as any less “trans” or any less “feminine” because of it.\n\nTo put it another way, from a recent Huffington Post article by Justin Ropella: \n\nSurgery is absolutely not a requirement for or condition of trans*ness. For some people gender-confirmation surgery is a personal necessity, a life-or-death need. For others it’s not. For some the medical risks aren’t worth it. For some it’s a financial impossibility. And, believe it or not, some trans* people simply don’t want any kind of surgery. Each person is different.\n\nThere are times where having a penis can be inconvenient, like wearing a bikini to the beach - as I pointed out in my post on swimming & dysphoria. And yeah, the whole testosterone thing is not really up my alley. But the rest of the time, non-issue.\n\nMy dysphoria is mostly social in nature - having to do with where/how/when I can express my gender - beyond that my physical dysphoria comes almost exclusively from secondary sex characteristics, rather than genitals. I worry about losing the hair on my head, I feel discomfort with having the extra body hair that testosterone brings, beard shadow is lame, and I can get bummed about not having boobs. I am planning on having some laser hair removal done on my face, and if I were to transition I would most certainly do hormone replacement therapy, but I have no need for surgical interventions.\n\nIf I were to wake up tomorrow in a body that was fully female with nothing else changed I would be happy and have no regrets or feelings of loss. But as it stands, I embrace the body I have and deal with the things that are dissonant as I need to.","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"t-dude-diego","id":97061256071,"post_url":"http://t-dude-diego.tumblr.com/post/97061256071/mornin","slug":"mornin","type":"photo","date":"2014-09-09 15:37:00 I feel shit just thinking about it and dont know what to do…","can_reply":false},{"blog_name":"trans-parenting","id":97059277090,"post_url":"http://trans-parenting.tumblr.com/post/97059277090/did-you-watch-the-can-special-about-the-navy-seal","slug":"did-you-watch-the-can-special-about-the-navy-seal","type":"answer","date":"2014-09-09 14:59:30 GMT","timestamp":1410274770,"state":"published","format":"html","reblog_key":"v8SIbSE7","tags":["transparenting","trans","transgender","lgbt","lgbtq","kristin beck","lady valor","questions","Anonymous"],"short_url":"http://tmblr.co/ZnO4pr1QPBmaY","followed":false,"highlighted":[],"liked":false,"note_count":4,"asking_name":"Anonymous","asking_url":null,"question":"Did you watch the can special about the navy seal transgender? It was on Saturday night. Steve and I watched after the gathering","answer":"Lady Valor about Kristin Beck? I did not catch it, but that is mostly because we do not have cable/network tv at all, just Netflix and our horde of games/moveis. She also has a book Warrior Princess that I have not yet read, but have generally heard good things about. As much as I follow trans related stuff I do not always do a ton of digging into biographical/autobiographical pieces unless the stories are more in line with my own experience, or they come highly recommended. But I am really glad to see that she is raising visibility about trans lives, and hope that she can help to drive changes that will allow trans people to serve openly in the military (if they so choose). ”Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” might be gone, but due to (antiquated) policy that considers being trans a \"psychosexual condition\" that makes someone unfit for service.\n\nAnd just a quick Whether you’re a first-time visitor or avid fan of Acts of Greatness’ work in empowering Canada’s LGBT youth through educational awards and leadership talks, I’m so glad you’ve found your way here!\n\nThis blog is an essential element to AG’s third pillar of empowerment (besides the education and leadership talks): Storytelling. Along with AG’s photojournalism project Fabulous Alberta and stop-motion animation on history LGBTQueerStory, this blog hopes to showcase diverse experiences of LGBTQ people, both in and beyond Canada.\n\nEach week, our group of bloggers will be giving you opinion, personal narrative, advice, video clips and reviews on topics relevant to LGBTQ youth. There’s too many fantastic ideas and happenings that occur in our worlds everyday to not see daily responses!\n\nIf you would like to contribute to our blog — either regularly or a one-off piece — please email me at editor@actsofgreatness.org. Diversity is one of the strengths of our communities, and I’d love to see as many different people giving their takes on life as possible.\n\nThis blog has been months in the making. When AG’s founder, Yiorgos Boudouris first contacted me to run this blog, I wasn’t sure what to expect, or if I would truly find myself one day writing this post and being able to continually post the brilliant ideas of our bloggers. But here I am, and I appreciate Yiorgos’ insistence that writing and storytelling are powerful means to help LGBTQ youth feel reflected and visible.\n\nI should mention, too, that I appreciate him, as a cisgender ally, making it a point to reach out and find a transgender editor for his blog. I’m thrilled to see what Yiorgos, myself, and our fantastic writers have to offer.\n\nSo, without further ado, thank you for visiting Acts of Greatness to learn What’s On Our Mind Today!\n\nMitch
